eng: THE MAN WHO WAS THURSDAY A NIGHTMARE To Edmund Clerihew Bentley A cloud was on the mind of men, and wailing went the weather, Yea, a sick cloud upon the soul when we were boys together.
fr: CHAPITRE PREMIER LES DEUX POETES DE SAFFRON PARK Le faubourg de Saffron Park s'etendait a l'est de Londres, rouge et dechire comme un nuage au couchant, dessinant sur le ciel une silhouette fantastique de maisons bizarres, toutes construites en briques claires.

eng: Science announced nonentity and art admired decay; The world was old and ended: but you and I were gay; Round us in antic order their crippled vices came Lust that had lost its laughter, fear that had lost its shame.
fr: Le sol meme en etait etrangement tourmente.

eng: Like the white lock of Whistler, that lit our aimless gloom, Men showed their own white feather as proudly as a plume.
fr: On devait cette creation a la fantaisie d'un speculateur audacieux, qui possedait quelque vague teinture d'art.

eng: Life was a fly that faded, and death a drone that stung; The world was very old indeed when you and I were young.
fr: Il qualifiait l'architecture de son faubourg tantot de << style Elizabeth >>, tantot de << style reine Anne >> ; sans doute, dans sa pensee, les deux souveraines n'en faisaient qu'une.

eng: They twisted even decent sin to shapes not to be named: Men were ashamed of honour; but we were not ashamed.
fr: Dans le public, on traitait ce faubourg de colonie d'artistes.

eng: Weak if we were and foolish, not thus we failed, not thus; When that black Baal blocked the heavens he had no hymns from us Children we were our forts of sand were even as weak as we, High as they went we piled them up to break that bitter sea.
Fools as we were in motley, all jangling and absurd, When all church bells were silent our cap and bells were heard.
fr: Non qu'aucun art y fut particulierement cultive, mais l'aspect, l'atmosphere en etait << artiste >>.

eng: Not all unhelped we held the fort, our tiny flags unfurled; Some giants laboured in that cloud to lift it from the world.
fr: Endroit fort agreable, d'ailleurs, si ses pretentions au titre de centre intellectuel pouvaient passer pour exagerees.

eng: I find again the book we found, I feel the hour that flings Far out of fish-shaped Paumanok some cry of cleaner things; And the Green Carnation withered, as in forest fires that pass, Roared in the wind of all the world ten million leaves of grass; Or sane and sweet and sudden as a bird sings in the rain Truth out of Tusitala spoke and pleasure out of pain.
fr: L'etranger, qui jetait pour la premiere fois un regard sur ces curieuses maisons rouges, devait faire sans doute quelque effort d'imagination pour se representer la structure singuliere de leurs habitants.

eng: Yea, cool and clear and sudden as a bird sings in the grey, Dunedin to Samoa spoke, and darkness unto day.
But we were young; we lived to see God break their bitter charms.
fr: Et, s'il rencontrait l'un d'eux, son impression n'en etait pas modifiee.

eng: God and the good Republic come riding back in arms: We have seen the City of Mansoul, even as it rocked, relieved Blessed are they who did not see, but being blind, believed.
fr: Cet endroit etait non seulement agreable, il etait parfait pour peu qu'on le considerat non comme truque mais plutot comme un reve.

eng: This is a tale of those old fears, even of those emptied hells, And none but you shall understand the true thing that it tells Of what colossal gods of shame could cow men and yet crash, Of what huge devils hid the stars, yet fell at a pistol flash.
fr: Si ce n'etaient pas des artistes qui habitaient la, l'ensemble n'en avait pas moins un caractere artiste.

eng: The doubts that were so plain to chase, so dreadful to withstand Oh, who shall understand but you; yea, who shall understand?
fr: Ce jeune homme, par exemple, avec ses longs cheveux chatains et sa mine impertinente, ne voyez pas en lui un poete : c'est un poeme.

eng: The doubts that drove us through the night as we two talked amain, And day had broken on the streets e'er it broke upon the brain.
fr: Ce vieux monsieur, avec sa vaste barbe sauvage et son vaste et sauvage chapeau, ce venerable charlatan, ce n'est pas un philosophe : c'est un theme de philosophie.

eng: Between us, by the peace of God, such truth can now be told; Yea, there is strength in striking root and good in growing old. ~~~ We have found common things at last and marriage and a creed, And I may safely write it now, and you may safely read.
fr: Ce personnage aux apparences doctorales, au crane chauve et brillant comme un oeuf, au long cou decharne comme celui d'un oiseau, n'a aucun droit aux dehors de savant qu'il se donne ; il n'a fait aucune decouverte en biologie : mais n'est-il pas lui-meme la plus extraordinaire creature que puissent etudier les biologistes ?

eng: G. K. C. CHAPTER I. ~~~ THE TWO POETS OF SAFFRON PARK The suburb of Saffron Park lay on the sunset side of London, as red and ragged as a cloud of sunset.
fr: Voila, disons-nous, le bon point de vue d'ou il convenait d'observer le faubourg de Saffron Park : non pas un atelier d'artistes, mais une oeuvre d'art, delicate et parfaite.

eng: It was built of a bright brick throughout; its sky-line was fantastic, and even its ground plan was wild.
fr: On avait, en y entrant, l'impression qu'on allait prendre part a quelque comedie.

eng: It had been the outburst of a speculative builder, faintly tinged with art, who called its architecture sometimes Elizabethan and sometimes Queen Anne, apparently under the impression that the two sovereigns were identical.
fr: Ce charme de l'irreel etait surtout sensible le soir, quand les toits bizarres se decoupaient en valeurs sombres sur le couchant et que tout le chimerique endroit se detachait, en quelque sorte, visiblement du monde ordinaire, comme une nuee flotte dans le ciel.

eng: It was described with some justice as an artistic colony, though it never in any definable way produced any art. ~~~ But although its pretensions to be an intellectual centre were a little vague, its pretensions to be a pleasant place were quite indisputable.
fr: Ce charme etait, veritablement, irresistible les soirs de fete locale, quand de grosses lanternes venitiennes, fruits monstrueux des arbres nains, illuminaient les jardinets.

eng: The stranger who looked for the first time at the quaint red houses could only think how very oddly shaped the people must be who could fit in to them.
fr: Et ce charme fut plus sensible, plus irresistible que jamais, un certain soir dont on se souvient encore dans le voisinage et dont le poete aux cheveux chatains fut le heros.

eng: Nor when he met the people was he disappointed in this respect.
fr: Il avait ete, du reste, le heros de bien d'autres soirs avant celui-la.

eng: The place was not only pleasant, but perfect, if once he could regard it not as a deception but rather as a dream.
fr: Il ne se passait guere de jour qu'on ne put entendre, des le crepuscule tombe, la voix haute et professorale de ce jeune homme dicter, du fond de son petit jardin, des lois a l'humanite entiere, et plus particulierement aux femmes.

eng: Even if the people were not "artists," the whole was nevertheless artistic.
fr: L'attitude des femmes, dans ces occasions, etait meme fort remarquable.

eng: That young man with the long, auburn hair and the impudent face that young man was not really a poet; but surely he was a poem.
fr: Elles appartenaient presque toutes -- je parle de celles qui habitaient le faubourg -- a la categorie des emancipees, et faisaient en consequence profession de protester contre la suprematie du male.

eng: That old gentleman with the wild, white beard and the wild, white hat that venerable humbug was not really a philosopher; but at least he was the cause of philosophy in others.
fr: Or, ces personnes << nouvelles >> etaient toujours disposees a vous accorder cet honneur que jamais aucune femme ordinaire n'accorde a aucun homme : elles vous ecoutaient tandis que vous parliez.

eng: That scientific gentleman with the bald, egg-like head and the bare, bird-like neck had no real right to the airs of science that he assumed.
He had not discovered anything new in biology; but what biological creature could he have discovered more singular than himself?
fr: A vrai dire, M. Lucien Gregory meritait qu'on l'ecoutat, ne fut-ce que pour rire, ensuite, de ses discours.

eng: Thus, and thus only, the whole place had properly to be regarded; it had to be considered not so much as a workshop for artists, but as a frail but finished work of art.
fr: Il debitait la vieille fable de l'anarchie de l'art et de l'art de l'anarchie avec une certaine fraicheur, un ragout d'insolence ou l'on pouvait trouver quelque bref agrement.

eng: A man who stepped into its social atmosphere felt as if he had stepped into a written comedy.
fr: L'originalite de son aspect physique le servait a souhait, et il savait en jouer, en connaissant la valeur.

eng: More especially this attractive unreality fell upon it about nightfall, when the extravagant roofs were dark against the afterglow and the whole insane village seemed as separate as a drifting cloud.
fr: Ses cheveux d'un rouge sombre, separes au milieu, etaient longs comme des cheveux de femme ; ils bouclaient en decrivant les molles courbes dont les peintres preraphaelites ne manquent pas d'agrementer les chevelures de leurs Vierges.

eng: This again was more strongly true of the many nights of local festivity, when the little gardens were often illuminated, and the big Chinese lanterns glowed in the dwarfish trees like some fierce and monstrous fruit.
fr: Mais de ce cadre mystique jaillissait une face large et brutale ; le menton avancait avec une expression meprisante qui sentait le cockney.

eng: And this was strongest of all on one particular evening, still vaguely remembered in the locality, of which the auburn-haired poet was the hero.
fr: Ce contraste surexcitait jusqu'a la peur une galerie de femmes neurastheniques : elles goutaient ce blaspheme vivant, cette combinaison d'ange et de singe.

eng: It was not by any means the only evening of which he was the hero.
fr: La soiree dont il s'agit restera memorable tout au moins par son etonnant coucher de soleil.

eng: On many nights those passing by his little back garden might hear his high, didactic voice laying down the law to men and particularly to women.
The attitude of women in such cases was indeed one of the paradoxes of the place.
fr: Un coucher de soleil de fin du monde.

eng: Most of the women were of the kind vaguely called emancipated, and professed some protest against male supremacy.
fr: Tout le ciel paraissait couvert d'un plumage palpable et vivant.

eng: Yet these new women would always pay to a man the extravagant compliment which no ordinary woman ever pays to him, that of listening while he is talking.
And Mr. Lucian Gregory, the red-haired poet, was really (in some sense) a man worth listening to, even if one only laughed at the end of it.
He put the old cant of the lawlessness of art and the art of lawlessness with a certain impudent freshness which gave at least a momentary pleasure.
He was helped in some degree by the arresting oddity of his appearance, which he worked, as the phrase goes, for all it was worth.
fr: Un ciel plein de plumes, de plumes qu'on croyait sentir vous effleurer le visage.

eng: His dark red hair parted in the middle was literally like a woman's, and curved into the slow curls of a virgin in a pre-Raphaelite picture.
fr: Au milieu du dome celeste, ces plumes etaient grises, avec de bizarres touches de violet, de mauve, de rose, de vert pale invraisemblablement.

eng: From within this almost saintly oval, however, his face projected suddenly broad and brutal, the chin carried forward with a look of cockney contempt.
fr: Mais il est impossible de rendre la transparence et le ton passionne de l'occident ; les dernieres plumes, d'un rouge feu, couvraient le soleil comme une chose trop belle pour que personne meritat de la voir.

eng: This combination at once tickled and terrified the nerves of a neurotic population.
fr: Et tout cela etait si rapproche du sol qu'on ne pouvait s'expliquer le phenomene.

eng: He seemed like a walking blasphemy, a blend of the angel and the ape.
fr: L'empyree tout entier semblait l'expression d'un secret impenetrable.

eng: This particular evening, if it is remembered for nothing else, will be remembered in that place for its strange sunset. ~~~ It looked like the end of the world.
fr: Il etait l'image et l'expression de cette splendide petitesse qui est l'ame du patriotisme local : le ciel meme paraissait petit.

eng: All the heaven seemed covered with a quite vivid and palpable plumage; you could only say that the sky was full of feathers, and of feathers that almost brushed the face.
fr: Les uns, donc, se rappelleront cette soiree a cause de l'oppression que faisait peser le ciel ; les autres, parce qu'elle marqua l'apparition d'un second poete a Saffron Park.

eng: Across the great part of the dome they were grey, with the strangest tints of violet and mauve and an unnatural pink or pale green; but towards the west the whole grew past description, transparent and passionate, and the last red-hot plumes of it covered up the sun like something too good to be seen.
The whole was so close about the earth, as to express nothing but a violent secrecy.
fr: Longtemps le revolutionnaire aux cheveux rouges avait regne sans rival.

eng: The very empyrean seemed to be a secret.
It expressed that splendid smallness which is the soul of local patriotism.
fr: Le soir du fameux coucher de soleil, sa solitude prit subitement fin.

eng: The very sky seemed small. ~~~ I say that there are some inhabitants who may remember the evening if only by that oppressive sky.
fr: Le nouveau poete, qui se presentait sous le nom de Gabriel Syme, avait les apparences d'un mortel de moeurs fort douces.

eng: There are others who may remember it because it marked the first appearance in the place of the second poet of Saffron Park.
fr: Les cheveux d'or pale ; la barbe blonde, taillee en pointe.

eng: For a long time the red-haired revolutionary had reigned without a rival; it was upon the night of the sunset that his solitude suddenly ended.
The new poet, who introduced himself by the name of Gabriel Syme was a very mild-looking mortal, with a fair, pointed beard and faint, yellow hair.
But an impression grew that he was less meek than he looked.
fr: On le soupconnait, toutefois, assez vite d'etre moins doux qu'il n'en avait l'air.

eng: He signalised his entrance by differing with the established poet, Gregory, upon the whole nature of poetry.
fr: Son entree fut signalee par un differend entre lui et le poete etabli, Gregory, sur la nature meme de la poesie.

eng: He said that he (Syme) was poet of law, a poet of order; nay, he said he was a poet of respectability.
fr: Syme se donna pour le poete de la Loi, le poete de l'Ordre, -- bien plus : le poete des Convenances.

eng: So all the Saffron Parkers looked at him as if he had that moment fallen out of that impossible sky.
fr: Les gens de Saffron Park le regarderent avec stupeur, comme s'il venait de tomber de l'impossible ciel de ce soir-la.

eng: An artist disregards all governments, abolishes all conventions.
fr: L'artiste nie tous les gouvernements, abolit toutes les conventions.

eng: The poet delights in disorder only.
fr: Le desordre, voila l'atmosphere necessaire du poete.

eng: If it were not so, the most poetical thing in the world would be the Underground Railway."
fr: Si je me trompais, il faudrait donc dire que le metropolitain de Londres est la chose la plus poetique du monde !

eng: "Nonsense!"
fr: -- Ridicule !

eng: said Gregory, who was very rational when anyone else attempted paradox.
fr: Non-sens ! ~~~ s'ecria Gregory qui devenait tout a coup tres raisonnable des qu'un autre se permettait devant lui quelque paradoxe.

eng: "Why do all the clerks and navvies in the railway trains look so sad and tired, so very sad and tired?
fr: -- Pourquoi, continua-t-il, tous les employes, tous les ouvriers qui prennent le metropolitain ont-ils l'air si triste et si fatigue, si profondement triste et fatigue ?

eng: I will tell you.
fr: Je vais vous le dire.

eng: It is because they know that the train is going right.
fr: C'est parce qu'ils savent que le train va comme il faut.

eng: It is because they know that whatever place they have taken a ticket for that place they will reach.
fr: C'est parce qu'ils savent qu'ils arriveront a la station pour laquelle ils ont pris leur billet.

eng: It is because after they have passed Sloane Square they know that the next station must be Victoria, and nothing but Victoria.
fr: C'est parce qu'ils savent qu'apres Sloane Street la prochaine station sera Victoria et jamais une autre que Victoria.

eng: Oh, their wild rapture!
fr: Oh !

eng: oh, their eyes like stars and their souls again in Eden, if the next station were unaccountably Baker Street!"
fr: quel ravissement, comme tous ces yeux morts jetteraient soudain des rayons, comme toutes ces ames mornes seraient emparadisees, si la prochaine station, sans qu'on put dire pourquoi, etait Baker Street !

eng: "It is you who are unpoetical," replied the poet Syme.
fr: -- C'est vous qui manquez de poesie, repliqua Syme.

eng: "If what you say of clerks is true, they can only be as prosaic as your poetry.
fr: Si ce que vous dites des employes est vrai, c'est qu'ils sont aussi prosaiques que votre poesie.

eng: The rare, strange thing is to hit the mark; the gross, obvious thing is to miss it.
fr: Le rare, le merveilleux, c'est d'atteindre le but ; le vulgaire, le normal, c'est de le manquer.

eng: We feel it is epical when man with one wild arrow strikes a distant bird.
fr: Nous admirons comme un beau poeme epique qu'un homme d'une fleche tiree de son arc frappe un oiseau, loin dans le ciel.

eng: Is it not also epical when man with one wild engine strikes a distant station?
fr: N'est-il pas tout aussi epique que l'homme au moyen d'une sauvage machine atteigne une lointaine station ?

eng: Chaos is dull; because in chaos the train might indeed go anywhere, to Baker Street or to Bagdad.
fr: Le chaos est stupide, et, que le train aille a Baker Street ou a Bagdad ou n'importe ou quand c'est a Victoria qu'il devrait aller, c'est le chaos.

eng: But man is a magician, and his whole magic is in this, that he does say Victoria, and lo!
fr: L'homme n'est un magicien que parce qu'il peut aller a Victoria, ayant dit : Je veux aller a Victoria.

eng: Take your Byron, who commemorates the defeats of man; give me Bradshaw, who commemorates his victories. ~~~ Give me Bradshaw, I say!"
fr: Gardez votre Byron qui commemore les defaites des hommes, et donnez-moi l'horaire de Bradshaw qui raconte leurs victoires, donnez-moi l'horaire, entendez-vous !

eng: "Must you go?"
fr: -- Allez-vous loin ?

eng: inquired Gregory sarcastically.
fr: demanda Gregory sarcastique.

eng: And when I hear the guard shout out the word Victoria,' it is not an unmeaning word.
fr: Ce n'est pas un mot depourvu de sens, pour moi, quand c'est le conducteur qui le crie !

eng: It is to me the cry of a herald announcing conquest. ~~~ It is to me indeed Victoria'; it is the victory of Adam."
fr: C'est pour moi le cri du heraut annoncant la victoire : la victoire d'Adam !

eng: Gregory wagged his heavy, red head with a slow and sad smile.
fr: Gregory, lentement, branla sa lourde tete fauve, en souriant avec melancolie.

eng: The girl winced for a flash at the unpleasant word, but Syme was too hot to heed her.
fr: La jeune fille, a ce mot choquant, fit la grimace, mais Syme etait trop emporte pour y prendre garde.

eng: "It is things going right," he cried, "that is poetical!
fr: -- C'est le cours normal des choses qui est poetique !

eng: Our digestions, for instance, going sacredly and silently right, that is the foundation of all poetry.
fr: La digestion, par exemple, qui s'accomplit a souhait dans un silence sacre, voila le principe de toute poesie.

eng: "You don't expect me," he said, "to revolutionise society on this lawn?"
fr: -- Vous n'attendez pas de moi, fit-il, que je revolutionne la societe sur cette pelouse !

eng: Syme looked straight into his eyes and smiled sweetly.
fr: Syme le regarda en face et sourit : -- Non, je ne vous demande rien de tel.

eng: "No, I don't," he said; "but I suppose that if you were serious about your anarchism, that is exactly what you would do."
fr: C'est pourtant ce que vous feriez, je pense, si vous etiez un anarchiste serieux.

eng: "I beg your pardon?"
fr: -- Plait-il ?

eng: said Syme.
fr: fit Syme.

eng: "Am I not serious about my anarchism?"
fr: -- Oui ou non, suis-je un anarchiste serieux ?

eng: cried Gregory, with knotted fists.
fr: interrogea Gregory en serrant les poings.

eng: "My dear fellow!"
fr: -- Mon cher garcon !...

eng: said Syme, and strolled away.
fr: dit Syme. ~~~ Et il s'eloigna.

eng: With surprise, but with a curious pleasure, he found Rosamond Gregory still in his company.
fr: Avec surprise, mais non sans plaisir, il vit Rosamonde se lever pour l'accompagner.

eng: "Mr. Syme," she said, "do the people who talk like you and my brother often mean what they say?
fr: -- Monsieur Syme, dit-elle en le rejoignant, les gens qui parlent comme vous et mon frere pensent-ils souvent ce qu'ils disent ?

eng: Do you mean what you say now?"
fr: Pensez-vous vous-meme ce que vous venez de dire ?

eng: Syme smiled.
fr: Syme sourit.

eng: "Do you?" ~~~ he asked.
fr: -- Pensez-vous vous-meme ce que vous dites ?

eng: "What do you mean?"
fr: demanda-t-il.

eng: asked the girl, with grave eyes.
fr: -- Comment l'entendez-vous ?
fit la jeune fille, et il y avait de la gravite dans son regard.

eng: "My dear Miss Gregory," said Syme gently, "there are many kinds of sincerity and insincerity.
fr: -- Chere miss Gregory, dit Syme doucement, la sincerite et l'insincerite ont bien des formes !
Quand vous dites : << Merci !

eng: When you say thank you' for the salt, do you mean what you say? ~~~ No.
fr: >> a la personne qui vous passe le sel, pensez-vous ce que vous dites ?

eng: When you say the world is round,' do you mean what you say? ~~~ No.
fr: Quand vous dites : << La terre est ronde, >> pensez-vous ce que vous dites ?

eng: It is true, but you don't mean it.
fr: Non, n'est-ce pas ?

eng: Now, sometimes a man like your brother really finds a thing he does mean.
fr: ce que vous dites alors est vrai, mais vous ne le pensez pas.
Eh bien, il arrive parfois qu'un homme comme votre frere finisse par trouver quelque chose qu'il pense reellement.

eng: It may be only a half-truth, quarter-truth, tenth-truth; but then he says more than he means from sheer force of meaning it."
fr: Peut-etre n'est-ce qu'a demi vrai, au quart, au dixieme : mais il le dit avec plus de force qu'il ne le pense, -- a force d'y penser.

eng: Syme broke into a great laugh, that seemed too large for his slight and somewhat dandified figure.
fr: Syme eclata d'un rire enorme qui paraissait trop fort pour sa frele stature, d'un rire excessif pour le dandy qu'il etait un peu.

eng: "Good Lord, no!"
fr: -- Seigneur !
s'ecria-t-il, certes non !

eng: he said, "that has to be done anonymously."
fr: Cela ne se fait que sous l'anonymat.

eng: Once he heard very faintly in some distant street a barrel-organ begin to play, and it seemed to him that his heroic words were moving to a tiny tune from under or beyond the world.
fr: A un certain moment, les sons lointains d'un orgue de Barbarie lui parvinrent et il lui sembla qu'une voix mysterieuse et menue s'elevait du fond de la terre ou d'au-dela pour accompagner ses heroiques discours.

eng: He stared and talked at the girl's red hair and amused face for what seemed to be a few minutes; and then, feeling that the groups in such a place should mix, rose to his feet.
fr: Il n'y avait, semblait-il, que quelques minutes qu'il parlait ainsi, sans perdre du regard la fauve chevelure de la jeune fille, quand, songeant tout a coup qu'en un pareil endroit les couples ne devaient pas s'isoler, il se leva.

eng: To his astonishment, he discovered the whole garden empty.
fr: A sa grande surprise, il vit que le jardin etait desert.

eng: When Syme went out into the starlit street, he found it for the moment empty.
fr: Ayant gagne la rue qu'eclairaient les etoiles, Syme la trouva deserte.

eng: Then he realised (in some odd way) that the silence was rather a living silence than a dead one.
fr: Puis, il se rendit compte obscurement que le silence etait vivant.

eng: Directly outside the door stood a street lamp, whose gleam gilded the leaves of the tree that bent out over the fence behind him.
fr: Juste en face de la porte qui venait de se fermer derriere lui, brillait la lumiere d'un reverbere, jetant un eclat d'or sur les feuilles de l'arbre qui depassaient la grille.

eng: About a foot from the lamp-post stood a figure almost as rigid and motionless as the lamp-post itself.
fr: A un pied, a peu pres, du reverbere se tenait un homme, presque aussi droit et immobile que le reverbere lui-meme.

eng: The tall hat and long frock coat were black; the face, in an abrupt shadow, was almost as dark.
fr: Le grand chapeau et la longue redingote etaient noirs ; le visage, dans l'ombre, paraissait noir aussi.

eng: Only a fringe of fiery hair against the light, and also something aggressive in the attitude, proclaimed that it was the poet Gregory.
fr: A quelques meches de cheveux rouges qui depassaient les bords du chapeau et a je ne sais quoi d'agressif dans l'attitude, Syme reconnut le poete Gregory.

eng: He had something of the look of a masked bravo waiting sword in hand for his foe.
fr: Il avait un peu l'air d'un bravo attendant, l'epee a la main, son ennemi.

eng: He made a sort of doubtful salute, which Syme somewhat more formally returned.
fr: Il esquissa un salut equivoque, que Syme lui rendit plus correctement.

eng: About what?"
fr: Et de quoi ?

eng: asked Syme in a sort of weak wonder.
fr: demanda Syme avec une nuance d'etonnement.

eng: Gregory struck out with his stick at the lamp-post, and then at the tree.
fr: Gregory frappa de sa canne le reverbere, puis un arbre voisin.

eng: "All the same," replied Syme patiently, "just at present you only see the tree by the light of the lamp.
fr: -- Et pourtant, repliqua Syme avec patience, en ce moment meme vous ne pouvez voir l'arbre qu'a la lumiere de la lampe.

eng: I wonder when you would ever see the lamp by the light of the tree."
fr: Pourriez-vous jamais voir le reverbere a la lumiere de l'arbre ?

eng: Then after a pause he said, "But may I ask if you have been standing out here in the dark only to resume our little argument?"
fr: Puis, apres un silence : -- Me permettez-vous de vous demander si vous etes reste ici, dans l'obscurite, uniquement pour reprendre notre petite discussion ?

eng: "No," cried out Gregory, in a voice that rang down the street, "I did not stand here to resume our argument, but to end it for ever."
fr: -- Non ! ~~~ cria Gregory, et sa voix remplit la rue.

eng: The silence fell again, and Syme, though he understood nothing, listened instinctively for something serious.
fr: Je ne vous ai pas attendu pour reprendre notre discussion, mais pour y mettre fin a jamais. ~~~ Le silence retomba.

eng: Gregory began in a smooth voice and with a rather bewildering smile.
fr: Syme, sans y rien comprendre, s'appretait a ecouter, s'attendant a quelque chose de serieux.

eng: "Mr. Syme," he said, "this evening you succeeded in doing something rather remarkable.
fr: Gregory commenca, sur un ton singulierement radouci, avec un sourire inquietant : -- Monsieur Syme, ce soir, vous avez reussi quelque chose d'assez remarquable.

eng: You did something to me that no man born of woman has ever succeeded in doing before."
fr: Vous avez fait ce que, jusqu'a cette heure, personne, ni homme ni femme, n'etait encore parvenu a faire.

eng: "Indeed!"
fr: -- Vraiment !

eng: I am going, at the possible sacrifice of my life and honour, to _prove_ to you that you were wrong in what you said."
fr: Je vais vous prouver, au prix peut-etre de ma vie et de mon honneur, que vous avez eu tort de dire ce que vous avez dit.

eng: "In what I said?"
fr: -- Qu'ai-je dit ?

eng: "You said I was not serious about being an anarchist."
fr: -- Vous avez dit que je ne suis pas un anarchiste serieux.

eng: Gregory stared at him steadily and painfully.
fr: Gregory le regardait fixement, avec douleur.

eng: "And in no other sense," he asked, "you think me serious?
fr: -- Et vous ne me croyez pas serieux en un autre sens encore ?

eng: You think me a _fl neur_ who lets fall occasional truths.
fr: Vous me prenez pour un oisif, pour un flaneur qui laisse parfois tomber de ses levres quelque verite, par hasard ?

eng: he cried.
fr: s'ecria-t-il.

eng: "Good Lord!
fr: Eh !

eng: is this street serious?
fr: bon Dieu !

eng: Are these damned Chinese lanterns serious? ~~~ Is the whole caboodle serious?
fr: qu'y a-t-il de serieux dans cette rue, dans les lanternes venitiennes et dans toute la boutique ?

eng: One comes here and talks a pack of bosh, and perhaps some sense as well, but I should think very little of a man who didn't keep something in the background of his life that was more serious than all this talking something more serious, whether it was religion or only drink."
fr: On arrive ici, on parle a tort et a travers... Peut-etre aussi dit-on quelques paroles sensees ; mais je n'aurais pas haute opinion d'un homme qui ne saurait se reserver a l'arriere-plan de son existence quelque chose de plus serieux que de telles conversations, -- oui, quelque chose de plus serieux, que ce soit une religion, ou seulement de l'ivrognerie !

eng: Syme stood waiting with his usual air of mildness until Gregory again opened his lips.
fr: Syme attendit, avec son expression familiere de douceur extreme, que Gregory ouvrit de nouveau la bouche.

eng: "You spoke just now of having a religion.
fr: -- Vous venez de parler de religion.

eng: Is it really true that you have one?"
fr: Est-il donc vrai que vous en ayez une ?

eng: inquired Syme, as the other paused.
fr: demanda Syme, comme l'autre s'interrompait.

eng: "I will promise you a very entertaining evening."
fr: -- Je vous promets une soiree vraiment amusante.

eng: Syme suddenly took off his hat.
fr: Syme aussitot enleva son chapeau.

eng: "Your offer," he said, "is far too idiotic to be declined.
fr: -- L'offre que vous me faites est trop seduisante pour que je la decline.

eng: You say that a poet is always an anarchist.
fr: Vous pretendez que tout poete est un anarchiste.
Ce n'est pas mon avis.

eng: I disagree; but I hope at least that he is always a sportsman.
fr: Mais j'espere, du moins, que tout poete est un galant homme.

eng: Permit me, here and now, to swear as a Christian, and promise as a good comrade and a fellow-artist, that I will not report anything of this, whatever it is, to the police.
fr: Ici et maintenant, je vous jure, foi de chretien, et je vous promets en bon camarade et compagnon d'art que je ne rapporterai rien de tout ceci -- quoi que ce soit -- a la police.

eng: And now, in the name of Colney Hatch, what is it?"
fr: Et maintenant, au nom de Colney Hatch, de quoi s'agit-il ?

eng: "I think," said Gregory, with placid irrelevancy, "that we will call a cab."
fr: -- Je pense, dit Gregory avec placidite, que nous allons prendre un cab.

eng: He gave two long whistles, and a hansom came rattling down the road.
fr: Il siffla deux fois, longuement ; un cab ne tarda pas a se ranger au pied du reverbere.

eng: The two got into it in silence.
fr: Ils prirent place, en silence, sur la banquette.

eng: Gregory gave through the trap the address of an obscure public-house on the Chiswick bank of the river.
fr: Gregory donna au cocher l'adresse d'un bar obscur, situe au bord de la riviere du cote de Chiswick.

eng: The cab whisked itself away again, and in it these two fantastics quitted their fantastic town.
fr: Le cab partit d'un trait. ~~~ Ainsi les deux fantasques poetes quitterent le fantastique faubourg.

eng: CHAPTER II. ~~~ THE SECRET OF GABRIEL SYME The cab pulled up before a particularly dreary and greasy beershop, into which Gregory rapidly conducted his companion.
fr: * * * CHAPITRE II LE SECRET DE GABRIEL SYME Le cab s'arreta devant un bar particulierement sale et repugnant, ou Gregory se hata d'introduire son compagnon.

eng: "The _p t de foie gras_ is not good here, but I can recommend the game."
fr: Le pate de foie gras n'est pas fameux ici ; mais je peux vous recommander le gibier.

eng: Syme received the remark with stolidity, imagining it to be a joke.
fr: Syme ne broncha pas, croyant a une plaisanterie, et, dans la meme veine d'humour, avec le ton detache d'un homme bien eleve : -- Donnez-moi plutot une langouste a la mayonnaise, dit-il.

eng: Accepting the vein of humour, he said, with a well-bred indifference "Oh, bring me some lobster mayonnaise."
fr: A sa grande surprise, il entendit le garcon lui repondre : -- Bien, monsieur.

eng: To his indescribable astonishment, the man only said "Certainly, sir!"
fr: Et il le vit s'eloigner, sans doute pour aller chercher ce qu'on venait de lui demander.

eng: and went away apparently to get it.
fr: -- Que boirez-vous ?

eng: "What will you drink?"
fr: reprit Gregory.

eng: resumed Gregory, with the same careless yet apologetic air.
fr: Pour moi, je ne prendrai qu'une creme de menthe ; j'ai dine.

eng: "I shall only have a _cr me de menthe_ myself; I have dined.
fr: Mais le champagne de cette maison n'est pas a dedaigner.

eng: But the champagne can really be trusted.
Do let me start you with a half-bottle of Pommery at least?"
fr: Commencez, du moins, par une demi-bouteille de pommery.

eng: "Thank you!" ~~~ said the motionless Syme.
fr: -- Merci, fit Syme impassible.

eng: "You are very good."
fr: Bien aimable...

eng: His further attempts at conversation, somewhat disorganised in themselves, were cut short finally as by a thunderbolt by the actual appearance of the lobster.
fr: Il essaya de renouer la conversation ; mais il fut interrompu, des la premiere phrase, par la soudaine apparition de la langouste.

eng: Syme tasted it, and found it particularly good.
Then he suddenly began to eat with great rapidity and appetite.
fr: Il la gouta, la trouva excellente et se mit a manger de bon appetit.

eng: "Excuse me if I enjoy myself rather obviously!" ~~~ he said to Gregory, smiling.
fr: -- Vous m'excuserez si je ne vous cache pas mon plaisir, dit-il a Gregory, gaiment.

eng: It is commonly the other way."
fr: D'ordinaire c'est le contraire qui arrive.

eng: "You are not asleep, I assure you," said Gregory.
fr: -- Mais vous ne dormez pas, je vous l'assure !

eng: "You are, on the contrary, close to the most actual and rousing moment of your existence.
fr: Vous approchez meme du moment le plus vivant et le plus poignant de votre existence... Ah !

eng: Ah, here comes your champagne!
fr: voici votre champagne...

eng: I admit that there may be a slight disproportion, let us say, between the inner arrangements of this excellent hotel and its simple and unpretentious exterior.
fr: Je conviens qu'il peut y avoir, disons une certaine disproportion entre l'organisation interieure de cet excellent hotel et ses dehors simples et sans pretentions.

eng: But that is all our modesty.
fr: Ce contraste est un effet de notre modestie.

eng: We are the most modest men that ever lived on earth."
fr: Car nous sommes les gens les plus modestes qu'il y ait jamais eu au monde.

eng: "And who are _we?_" asked Syme, emptying his champagne glass.
fr: -- Et qui sommes-nous ?

eng: "It is quite simple," replied Gregory.
fr: demanda Syme en vidant son verre.

eng: "_We_ are the serious anarchists, in whom you do not believe." ~~~ "Oh!"
fr: -- Mais, c'est tout simple : nous sommes ces anarchistes serieux auxquels vous refusez de croire.

eng: said Syme shortly.
fr: -- Vraiment !

eng: "You do yourselves well in drinks."
fr: dit Syme, sechement, vous vous fournissez tres bien en vins.

eng: "Yes, we are serious about everything," answered Gregory.
fr: Et apres un silence, Gregory ajouta : << Oui. ~~~ Nous sommes serieux en tout.

eng: Then after a pause he added "If in a few moments this table begins to turn round a little, don't put it down to your inroads into the champagne.
fr: >> Et il ajouta : -- Si, dans quelques instants, cette table se met a tourner un peu, n'attribuez pas le phenomene au champagne que vous avez bu.

eng: I don't wish you to do yourself an injustice."
fr: Je ne voudrais pas que vous vous fissiez injure.

eng: "Well, if I am not drunk, I am mad," replied Syme with perfect calm; "but I trust I can behave like a gentleman in either condition.
fr: -- Eh bien, dit Syme parfaitement calme, si je ne suis pas ivre, je suis fou. ~~~ Mais je pense que je saurai me conduire convenablement dans l'un et l'autre cas.

eng: "Certainly!"
fr: -- Certainement !

eng: said Gregory, producing a cigar-case.
fr: Et Gregory tira un etui de sa poche.

eng: "Try one of mine." ~~~ Syme took the cigar, clipped the end off with a cigar-cutter out of his waistcoat pocket, put it in his mouth, lit it slowly, and let out a long cloud of smoke.
fr: Syme choisit un cigare, en coupa la pointe avec un coupe-cigare qu'il tira de la poche de son gilet, le porta a la bouche, l'alluma lentement et exhala un epais nuage de fumee.

eng: It is not a little to his credit that he performed these rites with so much composure, for almost before he had begun them the table at which he sat had begun to revolve, first slowly, and then rapidly, as if at an insane seance.
fr: Il eut pu etre fier d'avoir accompli ces rites avec tant de serenite, car, pendant ce temps, la table s'etait mise a tourner, lentement d'abord, puis tres vite, comme a quelque folle seance de spiritisme.

eng: "You must not mind it," said Gregory; "it's a kind of screw."
fr: -- Ne faites pas attention, dit Gregory, c'est une espece de tire-bouchon.

eng: "Quite so," said Syme placidly, "a kind of screw.
fr: -- C'est cela meme, consentit Syme, toujours placide, une espece de tire-bouchon.

eng: How simple that is!"
fr: Que cela est donc simple !

eng: The next moment the smoke of his cigar, which had been wavering across the room in snaky twists, went straight up as if from a factory chimney, and the two, with their chairs and table, shot down through the floor as if the earth had swallowed them.
fr: Le moment d'apres, la fumee de son cigare, qui avait flotte jusqu'alors dans la piece en serpentant, prit une direction verticale, comme si elle montait d'un tuyau d'usine, et les deux hommes, avec leurs chaises et leur table, s'enfoncerent a travers le plancher.

eng: They went rattling down a kind of roaring chimney as rapidly as a lift cut loose, and they came with an abrupt bump to the bottom.
fr: Ils descendirent par une sorte de cheminee mugissante, avec la rapidite d'un ascenseur dont le cable aurait ete coupe et s'arreterent brusquement.

eng: But when Gregory threw open a pair of doors and let in a red subterranean light, Syme was still smoking with one leg thrown over the other, and had not turned a yellow hair.
fr: Mais quand Gregory eut ouvert deux portes et qu'une rouge lumiere souterraine se fut produite, Syme n'avait pas cesse de fumer, une jambe repliee sur l'autre, et pas un cheveu n'avait bouge sur sa tete.

eng: Gregory led him down a low, vaulted passage, at the end of which was the red light.
fr: Gregory le conduisit par un passage bas et voute, au bout duquel brillait la lumiere rouge.

eng: It was an enormous crimson lantern, nearly as big as a fireplace, fixed over a small but heavy iron door.
fr: C'etait une enorme lanterne de couleur ecarlate, presque aussi grande qu'une cheminee, et fixee a une petite et lourde porte de fer.

eng: In the door there was a sort of hatchway or grating, and on this Gregory struck five times.
fr: Il y avait dans cette porte une sorte de grillage ou de judas. ~~~ Gregory y frappa cinq coups.

eng: A heavy voice with a foreign accent asked him who he was.
fr: Une lourde voix a l'accent etranger lui demanda qui il etait.

eng: To this he gave the more or less unexpected reply, "Mr. Joseph Chamberlain."
fr: Il fit a cette question cette reponse plus ou moins inattendue : -- M. Joseph Chamberlain.

eng: The heavy hinges began to move; it was obviously some kind of password.
fr: C'etait evidemment le mot de passe. ~~~ Les gonds puissants se mirent a tourner.

eng: Inside the doorway the passage gleamed as if it were lined with a network of steel.
fr: De l'autre cote de la porte, le passage etincelait comme s'il eut ete tapisse d'acier.

eng: On a second glance, Syme saw that the glittering pattern was really made up of ranks and ranks of rifles and revolvers, closely packed or interlocked.
fr: Syme eut bientot constate que cette tapisserie etincelante etait faite de rangees superposees de fusils et de revolvers.

eng: "I must ask you to forgive me all these formalities," said Gregory; "we have to be very strict here."
fr: -- Je vous prie d'excuser ces formalites, dit Gregory.

eng: "Oh, don't apologise," said Syme.
fr: Nous sommes obliges a la plus grande prudence... -- Ne vous excusez pas, protesta Syme.

eng: "I know your passion for law and order," and he stepped into the passage lined with the steel weapons.
fr: Je sais quelle passion vous avez pour l'ordre et la loi. ~~~ Et il s'engagea dans le passage garni d'armes d'acier.

eng: They were bombs, and the very room itself seemed like the inside of a bomb.
fr: C'etaient des bombes, et la piece elle-meme semblait l'interieur d'une bombe.

eng: Syme knocked his cigar ash off against the wall, and went in.
fr: Syme, en entrant, fit tomber la cendre de son cigare contre l'un de ces engins meurtriers.

eng: "And now, my dear Mr. Syme," said Gregory, throwing himself in an expansive manner on the bench under the largest bomb, "now we are quite cosy, so let us talk properly.
fr: -- Et maintenant, cher monsieur Syme, dit Gregory en s'asseyant avec negligence sous la plus grosse bombe, maintenant que nous sommes vraiment a l'aise, causons comme il faut.

eng: Now no human words can give you any notion of why I brought you here.
fr: Il n'y a pas de mots pour definir le sentiment auquel j'ai obei en vous amenant ici.

eng: It was one of those quite arbitrary emotions, like jumping off a cliff or falling in love.
fr: C'est un sentiment imperieux, fatal, comme celui qui vous obligerait a sauter du haut d'un rocher ou a tomber amoureux.

eng: Suffice it to say that you were an inexpressibly irritating fellow, and, to do you justice, you are still.
fr: Il me suffira de vous rappeler que vous avez ete irritant au dela de toute expression.

eng: I would break twenty oaths of secrecy for the pleasure of taking you down a peg.
fr: Il faut d'ailleurs vous rendre cette justice que vous l'etes encore.

eng: That way you have of lighting a cigar would make a priest break the seal of confession.
fr: J'aurais vingt fois jure de me taire que je violerais vingt fois mon serment, pour le seul plaisir de vous faire baisser le ton d'un cran.

eng: Well, you said that you were quite certain I was not a serious anarchist.
fr: Votre maniere d'allumer un cigare induirait un pretre a rompre le sceau de la confession... Vous vous disiez donc tout a fait persuade que je ne suis pas un anarchiste serieux.

eng: Does this place strike you as being serious?"
fr: La piece ou nous sommes vous parait-elle serieuse, oui ou non ?

eng: "It does seem to have a moral under all its gaiety," assented Syme; "but may I ask you two questions?
fr: -- Elle semble, en effet, cacher quelque moralite sous la gaite de ses apparences, reconnut Syme.

eng: You need not fear to give me information, because, as you remember, you very wisely extorted from me a promise not to tell the police, a promise I shall certainly keep.
fr: Mais, puis-je vous poser deux questions ? ~~~ Ne craignez pas de me renseigner, puisque, tres prudemment, vous m'avez extorque la promesse de ne rien rapporter a la police.

eng: So it is in mere curiosity that I make my queries.
fr: Vous savez assez que, cette promesse, je la tiendrai.
C'est donc par simple curiosite que je vous questionne.

eng: First of all, what is it really all about?
fr: Et, d'abord, que signifie tout cela ?

eng: What is it you object to?
fr: Quel est votre but ?

eng: You want to abolish Government?"
fr: Avez-vous le projet d'abolir le gouvernement ?

eng: "To abolish God!"
fr: -- Nous avons l'intention d'abolir Dieu !

eng: said Gregory, opening the eyes of a fanatic.
fr: declara Gregory en ouvrant tout grands ses yeux de fanatique.

eng: "We do not only want to upset a few despotisms and police regulations; that sort of anarchism does exist, but it is a mere branch of the Nonconformists.
fr: Il ne nous suffirait pas de detruire quelques despotes ou de dechirer quelques reglements de police. ~~~ Cette sorte d'anarchisme existe, il est vrai, mais ce n'est qu'une branche du non-conformisme.

eng: The silly sentimentalists of the French Revolution talked of the Rights of Man!
fr: Les sentimentaux stupides qui firent la Revolution francaise parlaient des droits de l'homme !
Nous detestons, nous, les droits comme les torts.

eng: We hate Rights as we hate Wrongs.
fr: Nous avons aboli le tort et le droit.

eng: We have abolished Right and Wrong."
fr: -- Et la droite et la gauche ?

eng: "And Right and Left," said Syme with a simple eagerness, "I hope you will abolish them too.
fr: dit Syme avec candeur, je pense que vous les abolirez aussi.

eng: They are much more troublesome to me."
fr: Quant a moi, la droite et la gauche m'inquietent beaucoup plus que le tort et le droit.

eng: "You spoke of a second question," snapped Gregory.
fr: -- Vous annonciez une seconde question, fit Gregory sechement.

eng: "With pleasure," resumed Syme.
fr: -- Avec plaisir.

eng: "In all your present acts and surroundings there is a scientific attempt at secrecy.
fr: Dans tout ce que vous faites, dans tout ce qui nous entoure, je vois une savante recherche du mystere.

eng: I have an aunt who lived over a shop, but this is the first time I have found people living from preference under a public-house.
fr: J'avais une tante qui habitait au-dessus d'un magasin, mais c'est la premiere fois que je vois des gens vivre sous un bar.

eng: You have a heavy iron door.
fr: Vous avez une lourde porte de fer.

eng: You cannot pass it without submitting to the humiliation of calling yourself Mr. Chamberlain.
fr: Vous ne pouvez vous la faire ouvrir sans vous soumettre a l'humiliation de vous appeler M. Chamberlain.

eng: You surround yourself with steel instruments which make the place, if I may say so, more impressive than homelike.
fr: Vous vous entourez d'instruments d'acier qui donnent a ce lieu un aspect, si je puis m'exprimer ainsi, plutot guerrier que bourgeois.

eng: May I ask why, after taking all this trouble to barricade yourselves in the bowels of the earth, you then parade your whole secret by talking about anarchism to every silly woman in Saffron Park?"
fr: Comment donc, d'une part, vous cachez-vous dans les entrailles de la terre, et, d'autre part, etalez-vous au grand jour votre secret en professant l'anarchie devant toutes les peronnelles de Saffron Park ?

eng: Gregory smiled.
fr: -- Ma reponse sera bien simple, dit Gregory en souriant.

eng: "The answer is simple," he said. ~~~ "I told you I was a serious anarchist, and you did not believe me.
fr: Je vous ai dit que je suis un anarchiste serieux et vous ne m'avez pas cru : elles ne me croient pas non plus.

eng: Nor do _they_ believe me. ~~~ Unless I took them into this infernal room they would not believe me."
fr: Tant que je ne les aurai pas introduites dans cette chambre infernale, elles ne me croiront pas.

eng: Syme smoked thoughtfully, and looked at him with interest.
fr: Syme fumait, songeur, regardant Gregory avec interet.

eng: Gregory went on. ~~~ "The history of the thing might amuse you," he said.
fr: -- Ecoutez, continua Gregory, ceci vous amusera peut-etre.

eng: "When first I became one of the New Anarchists I tried all kinds of respectable disguises.
fr: Quand je devins l'un des Nouveaux Anarchistes, j'essayai toutes sortes de deguisements respectables.

eng: I was misinformed. ~~~ When on my first appearing in episcopal gaiters in a drawing-room I cried out in a voice of thunder, Down!
fr: La premiere fois que je penetrai avec mes guetres d'eveque dans un salon, je criai d'une voix tonitruante : << Et toi, raison presomptueuse, humilie-toi !

eng: down! ~~~ presumptuous human reason!'
fr: >> Mais les gens devinerent, je ne sais comment, que je n'etais pas du tout un eveque.

eng: they found out in some way that I was not a bishop at all.
fr: La meche etait eventee du coup.

eng: I was nabbed at once.
fr: Alors, je me deguisais en millionnaire.

eng: Then I made up as a millionaire; but I defended Capital with so much intelligence that a fool could see that I was quite poor.
fr: Mais je defendis le capital avec tant d'intelligence qu'un sot aurait compris que je n'avais pas le sou.

eng: Then I tried being a major.
fr: J'essayai de jouer au commandant.

eng: Now I am a humanitarian myself, but I have, I hope, enough intellectual breadth to understand the position of those who, like Nietzsche, admire violence the proud, mad war of Nature and all that, you know.
fr: Tout humanitaire que je sois pour mon compte, j'ai assez de largeur d'esprit pour comprendre Nietzsche et les autres qui admirent la violence, la folle et dure concurrence vitale, etc.

eng: I threw myself into the major.
fr: J'entrai donc dans mon role de commandant.

eng: I drew my sword and waved it constantly.
fr: Sans cesse je tirais mon epee et je la brandissais.

eng: I called out Blood!'
fr: Je criais : << Du sang !

eng: abstractedly, like a man calling for wine.
fr: >> comme on demande du vin.

eng: I often said, Let the weak perish; it is the Law.'
fr: J'allais repetant : << Que les faibles perissent !
C'est la loi.

eng: Well, well, it seems majors don't do this.
fr: >> Je fus tout de suite << brule >> une fois de plus.

eng: I was nabbed again. ~~~ At last I went in despair to the President of the Central Anarchist Council, who is the greatest man in Europe."
fr: En desespoir de cause, j'allai demander avis au president du Conseil Anarchiste Central. ~~~ C'est le plus grand homme d'Europe.

eng: asked Syme.
fr: demanda Syme.

eng: "You would not know it," answered Gregory.
fr: -- Si je vous disais son nom, vous ne le connaitriez pas.

eng: "That is his greatness.
fr: Et c'est la le secret de sa grandeur.

eng: Caesar and Napoleon put all their genius into being heard of, and they _were_ heard of.
fr: Un Cesar, un Napoleon depensent tout leur genie a faire parler d'eux ; ils y reussissent.

eng: He was silent and even pale for a moment, and then resumed "But whenever he gives advice it is always something as startling as an epigram, and yet as practical as the Bank of England.
fr: Il avait pali. ~~~ -- Ses conseils, reprit-il, ont toujours ce double caractere : ils sont a la fois piquants, surprenants comme une epigramme et pratiques comme la Banque d'Angleterre.

eng: I said to him, What disguise will hide me from the world?
fr: << Comment dois-je me deguiser ?

eng: What can I find more respectable than bishops and majors?'
fr: >>, lui demandai-je.

eng: He looked at me with his large but indecipherable face.
fr: << Comment me cacher aux yeux du monde ?

eng: You want a safe disguise, do you?
fr: Que trouverai-je de plus respectable que les eveques et les commandants ?

eng: You want a dress which will guarantee you harmless; a dress in which no one would ever look for a bomb?'
fr: >> Il tourna vers moi son grand visage indechiffrable : << Il vous faut un deguisement sur, n'est-ce pas ?
Il vous faut une tenue qui vous garantisse comme un etre parfaitement inoffensif, un vetement d'ou nul ne s'attende a voir sortir une bombe, n'est-ce pas ?
>> J'inclinai la tete, en signe d'assentiment.

eng: I nodded.
fr: << Eh bien !

eng: He suddenly lifted his lion's voice.
fr: deguisez-vous en anarchiste, espece d'imbecile !

eng: Why, then, dress up as an _anarchist_, you fool!'
fr: >> Et il rugissait si fort que les murs en tremblaient.

eng: he roared so that the room shook.
Nobody will ever expect you to do anything dangerous then.'
fr: << Personne ne soupconnera que vous puissiez faire le moindre mal.

eng: And he turned his broad back on me without another word.
fr: >> Sans un mot de plus, il se detourna, et je ne vis plus que ses larges epaules.

eng: I took his advice, and have never regretted it.
fr: J'ai suivi son conseil, et je n'ai jamais eu lieu de le regretter.

eng: I preached blood and murder to those women day and night, and by God!
fr: J'ai preche l'anarchie devant ces femmes, nuit et jour, et, Seigneur !

eng: they would let me wheel their perambulators."
fr: elles m'auraient donne a conduire leurs voitures d'enfants.

eng: "You took me in," he said.
fr: -- Je m'y suis laisse prendre, dit-il.

eng: "It is really a smart dodge."
fr: C'est bien joue.

eng: Then after a pause he added "What do you call this tremendous President of yours?"
fr: Et apres un silence il ajouta : << Comment appelez-vous ce terrible president ?

eng: "We generally call him Sunday," replied Gregory with simplicity.
fr: >> -- Nous l'appelons Dimanche, repondit Gregory avec simplicite.

eng: "You see, there are seven members of the Central Anarchist Council, and they are named after days of the week.
fr: Le Conseil Anarchiste Central se compose de sept membres, qui portent les noms des sept jours de la semaine.

eng: The gentleman who has for some time past played, with propriety and general applause, the difficult part of Thursday, has died quite suddenly.
fr: L'homme qui a joue pendant quelque temps, et a la satisfaction generale, le role difficile de Jeudi, est mort subitement.

eng: Consequently, we have called a meeting this very evening to elect a successor."
fr: Nous avons, en consequence, convoque pour ce soir un meeting en vue de le remplacer.

eng: He got to his feet and strolled across the room with a sort of smiling embarrassment. ~~~ "I feel somehow as if you were my mother, Syme," he continued casually.
fr: Il se leva et se mit a arpenter la chambre, avec un sourire embarrasse puis, negligemment : -- Syme, j'ai en vous une confiance pour ainsi dire filiale.

eng: "I feel that I can confide anything to you, as you have promised to tell nobody.
fr: Je sens que je puis m'ouvrir a vous sans reticence, puisque vous m'avez promis d'etre discret.

eng: We shall, of course, go through a form of election; but I don't mind telling you that it is practically certain what the result will be."
fr: On va voter, ici, dans une dizaine de minutes ; mais c'est, autant dire, pour la forme.

eng: He looked down for a moment modestly.
fr: Il baissa les yeux modestement.

eng: "It is almost a settled thing that I am to be Thursday."
fr: -- Il est a peu pres entendu d'avance que, Jeudi, c'est moi.

eng: "My dear fellow."
fr: -- Mon cher ami !

eng: said Syme heartily, "I congratulate you.
fr: s'ecria Syme cordialement, je vous felicite !

eng: A great career!"
fr: Quelle belle carriere !

eng: Gregory smiled in deprecation, and walked across the room, talking rapidly.
fr: Gregory sourit pour decliner ces politesses et reprit sa promenade.

eng: "As a matter of fact, everything is ready for me on this table," he said, "and the ceremony will probably be the shortest possible."
fr: -- Tout est prepare pour moi sur cette table. ~~~ La ceremonie ne sera pas longue.

eng: Syme also strolled across to the table, and found lying across it a walking-stick, which turned out on examination to be a sword-stick, a large Colt's revolver, a sandwich case, and a formidable flask of brandy.
fr: Syme s'approcha de la table que designait Gregory. ~~~ Il y avait une canne a epee, un revolver Colt, une boite a sandwichs et une enorme bouteille de brandy.

eng: Over the chair, beside the table, was thrown a heavy-looking cape or cloak.
fr: Sur une chaise, pres de la table, s'etalait une ample pelerine.

eng: "I have only to get the form of election finished," continued Gregory with animation, "then I snatch up this cloak and stick, stuff these other things into my pocket, step out of a door in this cavern, which opens on the river, where there is a steam-tug already waiting for me, and then then oh, the wild joy of being Thursday!"
fr: -- Je n'ai qu'a attendre la fin de ce scrutin, continua Gregory avec animation, puis je prendrai cette pelerine et ce gourdin, j'emporterai ce revolver, cette boite et cette bouteille, et je sortirai de cette caverne par une porte qui donne sur la riviere. ~~~ La m'attend un petit bateau a vapeur, et alors... ~~~ Alors ! ~~~ Oh !

eng: And he clasped his hands.
fr: la folle joie d'etre Jeudi !

eng: Syme, who had sat down once more with his usual insolent languor, got to his feet with an unusual air of hesitation.
fr: Et, de joie, il joignait les mains. ~~~ Syme, qui avait repris de son air de langoureuse impertinence sa place sur le banc, se leva de nouveau.
L'expression toujours insolente de sa physionomie se nuancait d'une hesitation qui ne lui etait pas familiere.

eng: "Why is it," he asked vaguely, "that I think you are quite a decent fellow?
fr: -- Pourquoi donc, je me le demande, Gregory, ai-je de vous cette opinion que vous etes un charmant garcon ?

eng: Why do I positively like you, Gregory?"
fr: Pourquoi donc ai-je pour vous, Gregory, positivement, de l'amitie ?

eng: He paused a moment, and then added with a sort of fresh curiosity, "Is it because you are such an ass?"
fr: Il se tut, puis, avec une curiosite sincere et passionnee : -- Serait-ce parce que vous etes tellement ane ?

eng: There was a thoughtful silence again, and then he cried out "Well, damn it all!
fr: Il y eut un nouveau silence, plein de pensees, puis Syme s'ecria : -- Nom de Dieu !

eng: this is the funniest situation I have ever been in in my life, and I am going to act accordingly.
fr: c'est bien ici la situation la plus comique ou je me sois trouve de ma vie, et je vais agir en consequence.

eng: asked Gregory, wondering.
fr: dit Gregory, etonne.

eng: "Yes," said Syme very seriously, "a promise.
fr: -- Oui, dit Syme tres serieusement, une promesse.

eng: I swore before God that I would not tell your secret to the police.
fr: J'ai jure devant Dieu de ne pas reveler votre secret a la police.

eng: Will you swear by Humanity, or whatever beastly thing you believe in, that you will not tell my secret to the anarchists?"
fr: Voulez-vous jurer, au nom de l'humanite, ou de quelque chose en quoi vous croyiez, de ne pas reveler mon secret aux anarchistes !

eng: "Your secret?"
fr: -- Votre secret ?

eng: asked the staring Gregory.
fr: Vous avez un secret ?

eng: "Have you got a secret?"
fr: -- Oui, j'ai un secret... Jurez-vous ?

eng: "Yes," said Syme, "I have a secret." ~~~ Then after a pause, "Will you swear?"
fr: Gregory le regarda fixement, avec gravite, longtemps, et, tout a coup : -- Il faut que vous m'ayez ensorcele !

eng: Gregory glared at him gravely for a few moments, and then said abruptly "You must have bewitched me, but I feel a furious curiosity about you.
fr: s'ecria-t-il. ~~~ Mais vous excitez furieusement ma curiosite.

eng: Yes, I will swear not to tell the anarchists anything you tell me.
fr: Oui, je jure de ne rien dire aux anarchistes de ce que vous me direz.

eng: But look sharp, for they will be here in a couple of minutes."
fr: Mais depechez-vous, car ils peuvent etre ici d'une minute a l'autre.

eng: Syme rose slowly to his feet and thrust his long, white hands into his long, grey trousers' pockets.
fr: Syme, avec lenteur, fourra ses longues mains blanches dans les poches de son pantalon gris.

eng: Almost as he did so there came five knocks on the outer grating, proclaiming the arrival of the first of the conspirators.
fr: Au meme instant, cinq coups furent frappes au judas, annoncant l'arrivee des premiers conspirateurs.

eng: "Well," said Syme slowly, "I don't know how to tell you the truth more shortly than by saying that your expedient of dressing up as an aimless poet is not confined to you or your President.
fr: -- Eh bien, commenca Syme sans se presser, je ne saurais exprimer la verite plus brievement qu'en vous disant ceci : votre expedient de vous deguiser en inoffensif poete n'est pas connu seulement de vous et de votre president.

eng: We have known the dodge for some time at Scotland Yard."
fr: Il y a quelque temps que nous en sommes informes, a Scotland Yard.

eng: Gregory tried to spring up straight, but he swayed thrice.
fr: Gregory, par trois fois, tenta de sauter en l'air, sans y parvenir.

eng: "What do you say?"
fr: -- Que dites-vous ?

eng: he asked in an inhuman voice.
fr: fit-il d'une voix qui n'avait rien d'humain.

eng: "Yes," said Syme simply, "I am a police detective.
fr: -- C'est vrai, dit Syme avec simplicite, je suis un detective.

eng: But I think I hear your friends coming."
fr: Mais il me semble que voici venir vos amis.

eng: THE MAN WHO WAS THURSDAY Before one of the fresh faces could appear at the doorway, Gregory's stunned surprise had fallen from him.
fr: * * * CHAPITRE III JEUDI Avant qu'aucun des nouveaux venus eut paru Gregory s'etait ressaisi.

eng: He was beside the table with a bound, and a noise in his throat like a wild beast.
fr: D'un bond, avec un rugissement de bete sauvage, il fut aupres de la table, saisit le revolver et mit Syme en joue.

eng: He caught up the Colt's revolver and took aim at Syme.
fr: Syme, sans s'emouvoir, leva d'un geste poli sa main pale : -- Ne soyez pas ridicule, dit-il avec une dignite ecclesiastique.

eng: Syme did not flinch, but he put up a pale and polite hand.
fr: Ne voyez-vous pas que c'est inutile ?

eng: "Don't be such a silly man," he said, with the effeminate dignity of a curate.
fr: Ne voyez-vous pas que nous sommes embarques tous les deux dans le meme bateau ?

eng: "Don't you see it's not necessary? ~~~ Don't you see that we're both in the same boat?
fr: J'ajoute que nous avons passablement le mal de mer l'un et l'autre, par-dessus le marche.

eng: Yes, and jolly sea-sick."
fr: Gregory ne pouvait parler ; il ne pouvait davantage faire feu.

eng: Gregory could not speak, but he could not fire either, and he looked his question.
fr: Et ce qu'il eut voulu dire et ne pouvait, ses yeux le disaient.

eng: "Don't you see we've checkmated each other?"
fr: -- Ne voyez-vous pas que vous m'avez fait mat et que je vous ai fait mat ?

eng: cried Syme.
fr: reprit Syme.

eng: "I can't tell the police you are an anarchist.
fr: Je ne puis vous denoncer a la police comme anarchiste.

eng: In short, it's a lonely, intellectual duel, my head against yours.
fr: En somme, c'est un duel intellectuel, sans temoins. ~~~ Ma tete contre la votre.

eng: I'm a policeman deprived of the help of the police.
fr: Je suis un policier prive de l'appui de la police officielle.

eng: You, my poor fellow, are an anarchist deprived of the help of that law and organisation which is so essential to anarchy.
fr: Vous, mon pauvre ami, vous etes un anarchiste prive de l'appui de cette loi, de cette organisation qui est essentielle a l'anarchie.

eng: I cannot betray you, but I might betray myself.
fr: Je ne peux vous trahir, mais je peux me trahir moi-meme.

eng: Come, come!
fr: Allons, courage !

eng: wait and see me betray myself. ~~~ I shall do it so nicely."
fr: Prenez patience, et attendez que je me trahisse : je le ferai si joliment !

eng: Gregory put the pistol slowly down, still staring at Syme as if he were a sea-monster.
fr: Gregory deposa le pistolet, les yeux toujours fixes sur Syme, comme s'il eut vu en lui quelque horrible monstre marin.

eng: "I don't believe in immortality," he said at last, "but if, after all this, you were to break your word, God would make a hell only for you, to howl in for ever."
fr: -- Je ne crois pas, articula-t-il enfin, a l'immortalite ; mais si, apres ce qui vient de se passer, vous manquiez a votre parole, Dieu ferait un enfer expres pour vous, afin que vous y puissiez grincer des dents pendant l'eternite.

eng: "I shall not break my word," said Syme sternly, "nor will you break yours.
fr: -- Je ne manquerai pas a ma parole et vous ne manquerez pas a la votre, repliqua Syme.

eng: Here are your friends."
fr: Voici vos amis.

eng: "Comrade Gregory," he said, "I suppose this man is a delegate?"
fr: -- Camarade Gregory, dit-il, je suppose que cet homme est un delegue ?

eng: Gregory, taken by surprise, looked down and muttered the name of Syme; but Syme replied almost pertly "I am glad to see that your gate is well enough guarded to make it hard for anyone to be here who was not a delegate."
fr: Gregory, surpris a l'improviste, baissa les yeux et murmura le nom de Syme. ~~~ Mais Syme, d'un ton presque impertinent : -- J'ai vu avec plaisir, fit-il, que votre porte est bien gardee et qu'il serait impossible a tout autre qu'un delegue de penetrer chez vous.

eng: The brow of the little man with the black beard was, however, still contracted with something like suspicion.
fr: Pourtant les sourcils du petit homme a barbe noire restaient fronces, et le soupcon etait visible dans son regard interrogateur.

eng: "What branch do you represent?"
fr: -- Quelle section representez-vous ?

eng: he asked sharply.
fr: demanda-t-il sur un ton cassant, ou quelle branche ?

eng: "I should hardly call it a branch," said Syme, laughing; "I should call it at the very least a root."
fr: -- Ce n'est pas precisement une branche, corrigea Syme en riant, ce serait plutot une racine.

eng: The little man dropped one of his papers, and a flicker of fear went over all the faces of the group.
fr: Le petit homme laissa tomber un de ses papiers. ~~~ Un frisson d'epouvante crispait tous les visages.

eng: Evidently the awful President, whose name was Sunday, did sometimes send down such irregular ambassadors to such branch meetings.
fr: Evidemment, le president Dimanche envoyait quelquefois de ces ambassadeurs irreguliers aux reunions des sections.

eng: "Well, comrade," said the man with the papers after a pause, "I suppose we'd better give you a seat in the meeting?"
fr: -- Eh bien, camarade, dit le petit homme, je pense que nous ferons bien de vous donner un siege a notre reunion ?

eng: "If you ask my advice as a friend," said Syme with severe benevolence, "I think you'd better."
fr: -- Si c'est un conseil amical que vous me demandez, repliqua Syme avec une bienveillance severe, je vous dirai que c'est ce que vous avez de mieux a faire.

eng: When Gregory heard the dangerous dialogue end, with a sudden safety for his rival, he rose abruptly and paced the floor in painful thought.
fr: Quand il put s'assurer que le dangereux dialogue avait pris fin et que son rival etait en securite, Gregory reprit sa promenade de long en large, pour mediter.

eng: He was, indeed, in an agony of diplomacy.
fr: Il etait en proie aux affres de la diplomatie.

eng: It was clear that Syme's inspired impudence was likely to bring him out of all merely accidental dilemmas. ~~~ Little was to be hoped from them.
fr: Il voyait bien que Syme, grace a sa presence d'esprit et a son impudence, saurait se tirer de toutes les difficultes ; rien, donc, a esperer de ce cote.

eng: He could not himself betray Syme, partly from honour, but partly also because, if he betrayed him and for some reason failed to destroy him, the Syme who escaped would be a Syme freed from all obligation of secrecy, a Syme who would simply walk to the nearest police station.
fr: Quant a lui-meme, Gregory, il ne pouvait trahir Syme, partie par honneur, partie par prudence : qu'il le trahit, en effet, et que, pour une raison ou pour une autre, il ne parvint pas a l'aneantir, le Syme qui s'echapperait serait un Syme affranchi de toute obligation et qui s'en irait directement au poste le plus voisin.

eng: After all, it was only one night's discussion, and only one detective who would know of it.
fr: Apres tout, il ne s'agissait que d'une seance de deliberation, en presence d'un seul policier.

eng: He would let out as little as possible of their plans that night, and then let Syme go, and chance it.
fr: Gregory veillerait a ne pas laisser discuter les plans secrets, cette nuit-la, puis il laisserait Syme partir et attendrait le resultat...

eng: He strode across to the group of anarchists, which was already distributing itself along the benches.
fr: Il revint vers les anarchistes, qui commencaient a prendre place sur les bancs.

eng: "I think it is time we began," he said; "the steam-tug is waiting on the river already.
fr: -- Il est temps de commencer, a ce qu'il me semble, dit-il. ~~~ Le bateau a vapeur attend.

eng: I move that Comrade Buttons takes the chair."
fr: Je propose que le camarade Buttons prenne la presidence.

eng: This being approved by a show of hands, the little man with the papers slipped into the presidential seat.
fr: On approuva a mains levees, et le petit homme au lorgnon prit possession du siege presidentiel.

eng: "Comrades," he began, as sharp as a pistol-shot, "our meeting tonight is important, though it need not be long.
fr: -- Camarades, debuta-t-il d'une voix crepitante comme une decharge de pistolet, notre reunion de ce soir est importante, mais elle pourra etre breve.

eng: This branch has always had the honour of electing Thursdays for the Central European Council.
fr: Notre section a toujours eu l'honneur d'elire Jeudi au Conseil Central Europeen.

eng: We have elected many and splendid Thursdays.
fr: Nous avons elu un grand nombre de fameux Jeudis.

eng: We all lament the sad decease of the heroic worker who occupied the post until last week.
fr: Nous deplorons tous la mort du travailleur heroique qui occupait encore ce poste la semaine derniere.

eng: Upon you, comrades, it devolves this evening to choose out of the company present the man who shall be Thursday.
fr: C'est a vous, camarades, qu'il appartient de designer, parmi les membres de cette assemblee, le nouveau Jeudi.

eng: If any comrade suggests a name I will put it to the vote.
fr: Si quelqu'un prononce un nom, je le soumettrai au vote.

eng: If no comrade suggests a name, I can only tell myself that that dear dynamiter, who is gone from us, has carried into the unknowable abysses the last secret of his virtue and his innocence."
fr: Si aucun n'est propose, il me restera a declarer que ce cher dynamiteur a emporte dans les abimes de l'inconnaissable le secret de la vertu et de l'innocence.

eng: Then a large old man, with a long and venerable white beard, perhaps the only real working-man present, rose lumberingly and said "I move that Comrade Gregory be elected Thursday," and sat lumberingly down again.
fr: Puis, un grand vieillard a longue barbe blanche, peut-etre le seul veritable ouvrier qui se trouvat dans l'assistance, se leva peniblement et dit : -- Je propose que le camarade Gregory soit elu comme Jeudi.

eng: "Does anyone second?"
fr: Et peniblement il se rassit.
-- Y a-t-il quelqu'un pour appuyer cet avis ?

eng: asked the chairman.
fr: demanda le President.

eng: A little man with a velvet coat and pointed beard seconded.
fr: Un petit homme a barbiche pointue declara qu'il partageait l'avis du preopinant.

eng: "Before I put the matter to the vote," said the chairman, "I will call on Comrade Gregory to make a statement."
fr: -- Avant de soumettre cette proposition au vote, je prierai le camarade Gregory de faire sa profession de foi, dit le President.

eng: His best chance was to make a softened and ambiguous speech, such as would leave on the detective's mind the impression that the anarchist brotherhood was a very mild affair after all.
fr: Le mieux n'etait-il pas, en effet, de prononcer un discours ambigu et doucereux ? ~~~ Le detective en garderait l'impression que la fraternite anarchiste, somme toute, ne constituait pas pour la societe un reel danger.

eng: He believed in his own literary power, his capacity for suggesting fine shades and picking perfect words.
fr: Gregory avait confiance en son habilete professionnelle de litterateur.

eng: He thought that with care he could succeed, in spite of all the people around him, in conveying an impression of the institution, subtly and delicately false.
fr: Il saurait suggerer de fines nuances et choisir les mots. ~~~ Il saurait, en s'y prenant bien, donner a l'intrus une idee subtilement fausse de l'Institution.

eng: Syme had once thought that anarchists, under all their bravado, were only playing the fool. ~~~ Could he not now, in the hour of peril, make Syme think so again?
fr: Syme avait dit que les anarchistes, malgre leurs airs de bravi, n'etaient que des sots ou des plaisantins : a l'heure du danger, Gregory allait solidement retablir dans la pensee du detective cette illusion.

eng: "Comrades," began Gregory, in a low but penetrating voice, "it is not necessary for me to tell you what is my policy, for it is your policy also.
fr: -- Camarades, prononca-t-il d'une voix basse et penetrante, je n'ai guere besoin de vous dire quelle est ma ligne de conduite, puisqu'elle est la votre.

eng: They learn about anarchists from sixpenny novels; they learn about anarchists from tradesmen's newspapers; they learn about anarchists from _Ally Sloper's Half-Holiday_ and the _Sporting Times_.
fr: Ils connaissent l'anarchie par les journaux, par les romans a douze sous. ~~~ Ils connaissent l'anarchie d'apres Ally Slopers Half-Holiday, d'apres le Sporting Times.

eng: They never learn about anarchists from anarchists.
fr: Ils ne connaissent pas l'anarchie par les anarchistes.

eng: We have no chance of denying the mountainous slanders which are heaped upon our heads from one end of Europe to another.
fr: On ne nous donne jamais l'occasion de faire justice des mensonges sous lesquels, d'un bout a l'autre de l'Europe, on nous accable.

eng: The man who has always heard that we are walking plagues has never heard our reply.
fr: Ceux qui entendent dire que nous sommes des plaies vivantes ignorent ce que nous pouvons repondre a cette accusation.

eng: I know that he will not hear it tonight, though my passion were to rend the roof.
fr: Et ils l'ignoreront ce soir encore, apres que j'aurai parle, et meme si ma voix passionnee parvenait a percer ces murs et ce plafond.

eng: What tales were told of their atrocities by one educated Roman to another?
fr: De quelles atrocites les Romains bien eleves ne les accusaient-ils pas ?

eng: Suppose' (I would say to him), suppose that we are only repeating that still mysterious paradox of history.
fr: Admettez, lui dirais-je, supposez pour un instant que nous nous bornons a reproduire ce grand paradoxe historique qui est un mystere aujourd'hui encore. ~~~ Nous sommes repugnants ?

eng: Suppose we seem as shocking as the Christians because we are really as harmless as the Christians.
fr: Les chretiens passaient pour tels, et c'est que nous sommes inoffensifs, comme ils l'etaient. ~~~ Nous sommes des fous ?

eng: I repeat, we are the true early Christians, only that we come too late.
fr: Je le repete, nous sommes les vrais chretiens primitifs ; seulement, nous arrivons trop tard.

eng: We are simple, as they revere simple look at Comrade Witherspoon.
fr: Nous sommes simples comme ils etaient simples ; voyez plutot le camarade Witherspoon !

eng: We are modest, as they were modest look at me.
fr: Nous sommes modestes comme ils etaient modestes : voyez-moi !

eng: We are merciful " "No, no!"
fr: Nous sommes pleins d'indulgence et de bonte... -- Non !

eng: called out Mr. Witherspoon with the velvet jacket.
fr: non ! ~~~ criait Witherspoon.

eng: "I say we are merciful," repeated Gregory furiously, "as the early Christians were merciful.
fr: -- Je dis que nous pardonnons a nos ennemis, poursuivit Gregory furieux, tout comme les premiers chretiens.

eng: Yet this did not prevent their being accused of eating human flesh.
fr: Cela n'empechait pas qu'on les accusat de manger de la chair humaine.

eng: "Why not?"
fr: Pourquoi pas ?

eng: "Comrade Witherspoon," said Gregory, with a feverish gaiety, "is anxious to know why nobody eats him (laughter).
fr: -- Le camarade Witherspoon, dit Gregory avec une gaite forcee, voudrait savoir pourquoi nous ne mangeons pas de chair humaine ! ~~~ (On rit.)

eng: In our society, at any rate, which loves him sincerely, which is founded upon love " "No, no!"
fr: Dans notre societe du moins ou il est aime, dans notre societe qui est fondee sur l'amour... -- Non !

eng: said Witherspoon, "down with love."
fr: hurla Witherspoon, a bas l'amour !

eng: "Which is founded upon love," repeated Gregory, grinding his teeth, "there will be no difficulty about the aims which we shall pursue as a body, or which I should pursue were I chosen as the representative of that body.
fr: -- Sur l'amour, repeta Gregory en grincant des dents, il ne saurait y avoir de controverses ni de dissentiments sur les fins que nous devons collectivement poursuivre et que je poursuivrais s'il m'etait donne de representer notre corps.

eng: Superbly careless of the slanders that represent us as assassins and enemies of human society, we shall pursue with moral courage and quiet intellectual pressure, the permanent ideals of brotherhood and simplicity."
fr: Superbement indifferents aux calomnies qui font de nous des assassins, des ennemis du genre humain, nous poursuivrons courageusement notre oeuvre de fraternite en exercant sur nos contemporains une pression legale et purement intellectuelle.

eng: Gregory resumed his seat and passed his hand across his forehead.
fr: Gregory reprit sa place en s'epongeant le front. ~~~ Tout le monde se taisait.

eng: The silence was sudden and awkward, but the chairman rose like an automaton, and said in a colourless voice "Does anyone oppose the election of Comrade Gregory?"
fr: Il s'etait fait un silence gene. ~~~ Le President se leva comme un automate et dit, d'une voix blanche : -- Quelqu'un s'oppose-t-il a la candidature du camarade Gregory ?

eng: The assembly seemed vague and sub-consciously disappointed, and Comrade Witherspoon moved restlessly on his seat and muttered in his thick beard.
fr: L'assemblee paraissait hesitante, deconcertee dans son subconscient.

eng: By the sheer rush of routine, however, the motion would have been put and carried.
fr: Le camarade Witherspoon s'agitait en murmurant dans sa barbe des mots incomprehensibles.

eng: But as the chairman was opening his mouth to put it, Syme sprang to his feet and said in a small and quiet voice "Yes, Mr. Chairman, I oppose."
fr: Pourtant par la seule force de l'inertie et de la routine, l'election de Gregory allait etre assuree, le President ouvrait deja la bouche pour prononcer les syllabes sacramentelles, quand Syme profera, dans le silence de tous, avec douceur, ces mots : -- Monsieur le President, je fais opposition.

eng: The most effective fact in oratory is an unexpected change in the voice.
fr: L'effet oratoire le plus puissant provient d'un changement inattendu dans le ton.

eng: Mr. Gabriel Syme evidently understood oratory. ~~~ Having said these first formal words in a moderated tone and with a brief simplicity, he made his next word ring and volley in the vault as if one of the guns had gone off. ~~~ "Comrades!"
