fr: M. Gabriel Syme connaissait, assurement cette loi de la rhetorique : apres avoir articule la formule d'un ton calme et avec une laconique simplicite, il eleva subitement la voix, si haut que cette voix se brisait et se repercutait sous les voutes comme si l'un des fusils etait parti.

eng: he cried, in a voice that made every man jump out of his boots, "have we come here for this?
fr: -- Camarades, s'ecria-t-il d'une voix telle que chacun trembla dans ses bottes, camarades !

eng: Do we live underground like rats in order to listen to talk like this?
fr: Est-ce pour cela que nous sommes venus ici ?

eng: This is talk we might listen to while eating buns at a Sunday School treat.
fr: Vivons-nous sous terre comme des rats pour entendre cela ?

eng: Do we line these walls with weapons and bar that door with death lest anyone should come and hear Comrade Gregory saying to us, Be good, and you will be happy,' Honesty is the best policy,' and Virtue is its own reward'?
fr: C'est la de l'eloquence qui nous conviendrait si nous allions, les jours de fete, manger des gateaux dans les ecoles du dimanche !

eng: There was not a word in Comrade Gregory's address to which a curate could not have listened with pleasure (hear, hear).
fr: Avons-nous fait de ces murs un ratelier d'armes, avons-nous barricade cette porte avec des engins de mort pour empecher les gens de venir ecouter les homelies du camarade Gregory ?

eng: But I am not a curate (loud cheers), and I did not listen to it with pleasure (renewed cheers).
fr: << Soyez bons et vous serez heureux... ~~~ L'honnetete est la meilleure politique...

eng: The man who is fitted to make a good curate is not fitted to make a resolute, forcible, and efficient Thursday (hear, hear)."
fr: La vertu est sa propre recompense... >> Il n'y a pas eu un mot, dans le discours du camarade Gregory, qu'un vicaire n'eut applaudi avec plaisir (Ecoutez ! ~~~ Ecoutez !)

eng: "Comrade Gregory has told us, in only too apologetic a tone, that we are not the enemies of society.
fr: Moi je ne suis pas un vicaire (Applaudissements) et je n'ai pas entendu le camarade Gregory avec plaisir.

eng: But I say that we are the enemies of society, and so much the worse for society.
fr: (Nouveaux applaudissements.)

eng: We are the enemies of society, for society is the enemy of humanity, its oldest and its most pitiless enemy (hear, hear).
fr: L'homme qui ferait un bon vicaire ne saurait etre le Jeudi qu'il nous faut, actif, resolu, implacable ! ~~~ (Tres bien ! ~~~ Tres bien !)

eng: Comrade Gregory has told us (apologetically again) that we are not murderers.
fr: Le camarade Gregory nous a dit, sur le ton de l'apologie, que nous ne sommes pas les ennemis de la Societe.
Et moi, je dis que nous sommes les ennemis de la Societe, parce que la Societe est l'ennemie de l'Humanite, son ennemie antique et impitoyable.

eng: There I agree.
fr: (Tres bien !)
Le camarade Gregory nous a dit, toujours sur le ton de l'apologie, que nous ne sommes pas des assassins : la-dessus, je suis d'accord avec lui.

eng: We are not murderers, we are executioners (cheers)."
fr: Nous ne sommes pas des assassins, nous sommes des executeurs !

eng: Ever since Syme had risen Gregory had sat staring at him, his face idiotic with astonishment.
fr: (Applaudissements.) ~~~ Depuis que Syme parlait, Gregory le considerait, stupide d'ahurissement.

eng: I do not mince words.
fr: Je ne mache pas les mots.

eng: I do not pretend to.
fr: Je ne sais pas macher les mots.

eng: I say that Comrade Gregory is unfit to be Thursday for all his amiable qualities.
fr: Je dis que le camarade Gregory ne saurait etre un bon Jeudi, en depit des qualites qui nous le rendent cher.

eng: He is unfit to be Thursday because of his amiable qualities.
fr: Il en est incapable precisement a cause de ces aimables qualites.

eng: We do not want the Supreme Council of Anarchy infected with a maudlin mercy (hear, hear).
fr: Nous ne voulons pas d'un Conseil Supreme de l'Anarchie infecte de cette charite larmoyante.

eng: I set myself against Comrade Gregory as I would set myself against all the Governments of Europe, because the anarchist who has given himself to anarchy has forgotten modesty as much as he has forgotten pride (cheers).
fr: Je me presente contre le camarade Gregory, comme je me presenterais contre tous les gouvernements d'Europe, parce que l'anarchiste qui s'est donne tout entier a l'anarchie ne connait pas plus la modestie qu'il ne connait l'orgueil.

eng: I am not a man at all.
fr: (Applaudissements.)
Je ne suis pas un individu ; je suis une Cause !

eng: I am a cause (renewed cheers).
fr: (Nouveaux applaudissements.)

eng: I set myself against Comrade Gregory as impersonally and as calmly as I should choose one pistol rather than another out of that rack upon the wall; and I say that rather than have Gregory and his milk-and-water methods on the Supreme Council, I would offer myself for election " His sentence was drowned in a deafening cataract of applause.
fr: Je me presente contre le camarade Gregory avec autant de calme et de desinteressement que je mettrais a choisir dans ce ratelier un pistolet de preference a un autre. ~~~ Oui, plutot que de laisser entrer au Conseil Supreme un Gregory, avec ses methodes edulcorees, je m'offre a vos suffrages...

eng: The faces, that had grown fiercer and fiercer with approval as his tirade grew more and more uncompromising, were now distorted with grins of anticipation or cloven with delighted cries.
fr: La peroraison se noya sous une cataracte d'applaudissements. ~~~ Les physionomies s'etaient faites de plus en plus energiques et approbatives a mesure que la parole de Syme devenait plus violente.
Elles etaient maintenant crispees par l'attente de ses promesses, des cris de volupte retentissaient.

eng: At the moment when he announced himself as ready to stand for the post of Thursday, a roar of excitement and assent broke forth, and became uncontrollable, and at the same moment Gregory sprang to his feet, with foam upon his mouth, and shouted against the shouting.
fr: Quand il se declara pret a prendre le role de Jeudi, on lui repondit par un tonnerre d'assentiment et il fut impossible de maitriser l'emotion. ~~~ Au meme moment Gregory se dressa sur ses pieds, l'ecume aux levres, en couvrant de ses clameurs la clameur unanime : -- Halte-la !

eng: "Stop, you blasted madmen!"
fr: Insenses ! ~~~ Halte-la !

eng: he cried, at the top of a voice that tore his throat.
fr: Mais Syme reprit la parole, en criant plus fort que la clameur de l'assistance.

eng: "Stop, you " But louder than Gregory's shouting and louder than the roar of the room came the voice of Syme, still speaking in a peal of pitiless thunder "I do not go to the Council to rebut that slander that calls us murderers; I go to earn it (loud and prolonged cheering).
fr: -- Je n'irai pas au Conseil pour refuter la calomnie qui fait de vous des assassins : j'irai pour la meriter moi-meme. ~~~ (Applaudissements nourris et prolonges.)

eng: cried Gregory, with frantic face and hands.
fr: hurlait Gregory en faisant des gestes fous.
Tout cela n'est que... ~~~ Le President, d'un ton glace, lui coupa la parole, et repeta : << Y a-t-il quelqu'un pour appuyer cet amendement ?

eng: "Stop it, it is all " The voice of the chairman clove his speech with a cold accent.
fr: >> Un homme long et maigre, la barbiche a l'americaine et la mine fatiguee, se leva lentement au dernier banc.

eng: "Does anyone second this amendment?"
fr: -- Que tout cela finisse !

eng: he said.
fr: repeta Gregory.

eng: A tall, tired man, with melancholy eyes and an American chin beard, was observed on the back bench to be slowly rising to his feet.
fr: Tandis qu'auparavant il criait comme une femme, il s'etait fait maintenant un changement dans son ton, et c'etait plus effrayant que s'il eut crie.

eng: Gregory had been screaming for some time past; now there was a change in his accent, more shocking than any scream.
fr: Les syllabes tombaient lourdes de sa bouche, comme des pierres.

eng: "I end all this!"
fr: Ecoutez !

eng: he said, in a voice as heavy as stone.
fr: Je vais mettre fin a tout cela : Cet homme ne saurait etre elu par vous.

eng: "This man cannot be elected.
fr: C'est un... -- Eh bien ?

eng: He is a " "Yes," said Syme, quite motionless, "what is he?"
fr: demanda Syme, impassible, eh bien ! ~~~ C'est un... quoi ?

eng: Gregory's mouth worked twice without sound; then slowly the blood began to crawl back into his dead face.
fr: Gregory fit deux fois, sans y parvenir, un grand effort pour prononcer un mot, un certain mot, puis on vit le sang lentement affluer a son visage jusqu'alors mortellement pale.

eng: "He is a man quite inexperienced in our work," he said, and sat down abruptly.
fr: -- Cet homme ne connait rien a notre oeuvre, dit-il enfin, il manque totalement d'experience... Et il se laissa tomber sur son banc.

eng: Before he had done so, the long, lean man with the American beard was again upon his feet, and was repeating in a high American monotone "I beg to second the election of Comrade Syme."
fr: Avant qu'il se fut assis, l'individu long et maigre a la barbiche a l'americaine s'etait de nouveau dresse.

eng: "The amendment will, as usual, be put first," said Mr. Buttons, the chairman, with mechanical rapidity.
fr: -- Je suis favorable a l'election du camarade Syme, repetait-il de sa voix nasillarde.

eng: "The question is that Comrade Syme " Gregory had again sprung to his feet, panting and passionate.
fr: -- L'amendement sera donc presente a vos suffrages, declara le president : il s'agit de savoir si le camarade Syme... -- Camarades !

eng: "Comrades," he cried out, "I am not a madman."
fr: gemit Gregory, qui s'etait dresse a son tour, je ne suis pas fou !

eng: "Oh, oh!"
said Mr. Witherspoon.
fr: protesta Witherspoon.

eng: "I am not a madman," reiterated Gregory, with a frightful sincerity which for a moment staggered the room, "but I give you a counsel which you can call mad if you like.
fr: -- Je ne suis pas fou ! ~~~ repeta Gregory avec l'accent d'une si emouvante sincerite que l'assemblee en fut, un instant, ebranlee. ~~~ Je ne suis pas fou ; mais je vais vous donner un conseil que vous pourrez juger fou s'il vous plait.

eng: No, I will not call it a counsel, for I can give you no reason for it.
fr: Bien plus, ce n'est pas un conseil, puisque je ne puis alleguer en sa faveur aucune raison.

eng: I will call it a command.
fr: Je dirai donc que c'est un ordre, et je vous adjure de m'obeir.

eng: Call it a mad command, but act upon it.
fr: Dites que cet ordre est fou, mais suivez-le !

eng: Truth is so terrible, even in fetters, that for a moment Syme's slender and insane victory swayed like a reed.
fr: La verite est si terrible, meme enchainee, qu'on sentit aussitot vaciller comme un roseau la precaire et insensee victoire de Syme.

eng: But you could not have guessed it from Syme's bleak blue eyes.
fr: Mais on ne s'en serait pas apercu a voir les yeux bleus de Syme.

eng: He merely began "Comrade Gregory commands " Then the spell was snapped, and one anarchist called out to Gregory "Who are you?
fr: Il se contenta de dire : -- Le camarade Gregory ordonne... Et le charme fut rompu, et un des anarchistes demanda a Gregory : -- Qui etes-vous ? ~~~ Vous n'etes pas Dimanche !

eng: You are not Sunday;" and another anarchist added in a heavier voice, "And you are not Thursday."
fr: Et un autre ajouta d'une voix plus grave : -- Vous n'etes pas Jeudi non plus. ~~~ -- Camarades !

eng: "Comrades," cried Gregory, in a voice like that of a martyr who in an ecstacy of pain has passed beyond pain, "it is nothing to me whether you detest me as a tyrant or detest me as a slave.
fr: s'ecria Gregory et sa voix etait celle d'un martyr qui, par exces de douleur, ne sent plus la douleur.

eng: If you will not take my command, accept my degradation.
I kneel to you.
fr: Camarades !

eng: I throw myself at your feet.
fr: Que m'importe que vous detestiez en moi un tyran ou un esclave ?

eng: I implore you. ~~~ Do not elect this man."
fr: Si vous repoussez mes ordres, ecoutez mes abjectes prieres !

eng: "Comrade Gregory," said the chairman after a painful pause, "this is really not quite dignified."
fr: Je m'agenouille devant vous, je me jette a vos pieds, je vous implore : ne deleguez pas cet homme.
-- Camarade Gregory, observa le President, apres un faible intervalle, votre attitude manque vraiment de dignite.

eng: For the first time in the proceedings there was for a few seconds a real silence.
fr: Pour la premiere fois depuis le debut de la seance, il y eut quelques secondes de silence absolu.

eng: Then Gregory fell back in his seat, a pale wreck of a man, and the chairman repeated, like a piece of clock-work suddenly started again "The question is that Comrade Syme be elected to the post of Thursday on the General Council."
fr: Gregory s'assit peniblement ; ce n'etait plus qu'une epave humaine, et le President reprit, comme une horloge remontee : -- Il s'agit de savoir si le camarade Syme sera elu pour remplir le poste de Jeudi au Conseil Central. ~~~ Une clameur s'eleva, pareille a celle de la mer.

eng: The roar rose like the sea, the hands rose like a forest, and three minutes afterwards Mr. Gabriel Syme, of the Secret Police Service, was elected to the post of Thursday on the General Council of the Anarchists of Europe.
fr: Les mains se dressaient comme les arbres d'une foret. ~~~ Trois minutes apres, M. Gabriel Syme, de la Police Secrete, etait delegue en qualite de Jeudi au Conseil Central des Anarchistes d'Europe.

eng: Everyone in the room seemed to feel the tug waiting on the river, the sword-stick and the revolver, waiting on the table.
fr: Chacun, dans la salle, semblait avoir conscience du bateau qui attendait sur la riviere, de la canne a epee et du revolver qui attendaient sur la table.

eng: The instant the election was ended and irrevocable, and Syme had received the paper proving his election, they all sprang to their feet, and the fiery groups moved and mixed in the room.
fr: Des que Syme eut recu le document qui authentiquait son election, tous se leverent, et les assistants se disseminerent dans la salle en groupes animes.

eng: Syme found himself, somehow or other, face to face with Gregory, who still regarded him with a stare of stunned hatred.
fr: Syme se trouva a l'improviste face a face avec Gregory, qui le regardait avec haine.

eng: They were silent for many minutes.
fr: Ils se regarderent en silence.

eng: "You are a devil!"
fr: -- Vous etes un demon !

eng: "And you are a gentleman," said Syme with gravity.
fr: -- Vous etes un honnete homme ! ~~~ repliqua Syme, gravement.

eng: "It was you that entrapped me," began Gregory, shaking from head to foot, "entrapped me into " "Talk sense," said Syme shortly.
fr: -- C'est vous qui m'avez force a... Gregory ne put achever ; il tremblait des pieds a la tete.

eng: "Into what sort of devils' parliament have you entrapped me, if it comes to that?
fr: -- Soyez raisonnable, fit Syme avec autorite.

eng: You made me swear before I made you.
fr: Pourquoi m'avez-vous amene dans cet infernal parlement ?

eng: Perhaps we are both doing what we think right.
fr: Vous avez exige mon serment avant que j'exigeasse le votre.
Sans doute, nous agissons l'un et l'autre selon l'idee que nous nous faisons du bien et du mal.

eng: But what we think right is so damned different that there can be nothing between us in the way of concession.
fr: Mais, de votre conception a la mienne, il y a une si formidable distance que nous ne saurions admettre de compromis.

eng: There is nothing possible between us but honour and death," and he pulled the great cloak about his shoulders and picked up the flask from the table.
fr: Il ne peut y avoir entre nous que l'honneur et la mort. ~~~ Et il jeta sur ses epaules la grande pelerine en saisissant la bouteille.

eng: "The boat is quite ready," said Mr. Buttons, bustling up.
fr: -- Le bateau est pret, dit le President, s'interposant.

eng: "Be good enough to step this way."
fr: Ayez la bonte de me suivre.

eng: Close to the opening lay a dark, dwarfish steam-launch, like a baby dragon with one red eye.
fr: Le long de la rive se tenait tout noir le petit bateau a vapeur, pareil a quelque jeune dragon a l'oeil rouge, unique.

eng: Almost in the act of stepping on board, Gabriel Syme turned to the gaping Gregory.
fr: Sur le point d'y monter, Gabriel Syme, dont le visage etait dans l'ombre, se retourna vers Gregory : -- Vous avez tenu votre parole, dit-il doucement, vous etes un homme d'honneur, et je vous remercie.

eng: "You have kept your word," he said gently, with his face in shadow.
fr: Vous avez tenu votre parole jusqu'au bout et dans les moindres details.

eng: "You are a man of honour, and I thank you. ~~~ You have kept it even down to a small particular.
fr: Je pense particulierement a la promesse que vous m'avez faite au debut de toute cette affaire, et que vous avez tenue.

eng: There was one special thing you promised me at the beginning of the affair, and which you have certainly given me by the end of it."
"What do you mean?"
fr: -- Que voulez-vous dire ?

eng: cried the chaotic Gregory.
fr: Que vous ai-je promis ?

eng: "What did I promise you?"
fr: -- Une soiree bien interessante, repondit Syme en montant dans l'embarcation.

eng: "A very entertaining evening," said Syme, and he made a military salute with the sword-stick as the steamboat slid away.
fr: Et, comme elle prenait sa course, il fit de sa canne a epee le salut militaire a Gregory.

eng: He was one of those who are driven early in life into too conservative an attitude by the bewildering folly of most revolutionists.
fr: Il etait un de ceux que la stupefiante folie de la plupart des revolutionnaires amene a un conservatisme excessif.

eng: He had not attained it by any tame tradition.
fr: Ce n'etait pas la tradition qui l'y avait amene.
Son amour des convenances avait ete spontane et soudain.

eng: His respectability was spontaneous and sudden, a rebellion against rebellion.
fr: Il tenait pour l'ordre etabli par rebellion contre la rebellion.
Il sortait d'une famille d'originaux, dont les membres les plus anciens avaient toujours eu sur toutes choses les notions les plus neuves.

eng: He came of a family of cranks, in which all the oldest people had all the newest notions.
fr: L'un de ses oncles avait l'habitude de ne jamais se promener que sans chapeau.

eng: One of his uncles always walked about without a hat, and another had made an unsuccessful attempt to walk about with a hat and nothing else.
fr: Un autre avait essaye, d'ailleurs sans succes, de ne s'habiller que d'un chapeau.

eng: His father cultivated art and self-realisation; his mother went in for simplicity and hygiene.
fr: Son pere etait artiste, et cultivait son moi. ~~~ Sa mere etait ferue d'hygiene et de simplicite.

eng: The more his mother preached a more than Puritan abstinence the more did his father expand into a more than pagan latitude; and by the time the former had come to enforcing vegetarianism, the latter had pretty well reached the point of defending cannibalism.
fr: Plus sa mere prechait une abstinence ultra-puritaine, plus son pere preconisait une licence ultra-paienne, et, tandis que l'une imposait chez elle le vegetarisme, l'autre n'etait pas loin de prendre la defense du cannibalisme.

eng: Being surrounded with every conceivable kind of revolt from infancy, Gabriel had to revolt into something, so he revolted into the only thing left sanity.
fr: Entoure qu'il etait depuis son enfance par toutes les formes possibles de la revolte, il etait fatal que Gabriel se revoltat aussi contre quelque chose ou en faveur de quelque chose.

eng: But there was just enough in him of the blood of these fanatics to make even his protest for common sense a little too fierce to be sensible.
fr: C'est ce qu'il fit en faveur du bon sens, ou du sens commun. ~~~ Mais il avait dans ses veines trop de sang fanatique pour que sa conception du sens commun fut tout a fait sensee.

eng: His hatred of modern lawlessness had been crowned also by an accident.
fr: Un accident exaspera sa haine du moderne anarchisme.

eng: It happened that he was walking in a side street at the instant of a dynamite outrage.
fr: Il traversait je ne sais quelle rue de Londres au moment ou une bombe y eclata.

eng: He poured perpetually into newspapers and their waste-paper baskets a torrent of tales, verses and violent articles, warning men of this deluge of barbaric denial.
fr: Il deversait sans repit dans les journaux, et aussi dans les paniers des salles de redaction, un torrent de nouvelles, de vers et de violents articles, ou il denoncait ce deluge de barbarie et de negation.

eng: But he seemed to be getting no nearer his enemy, and, what was worse, no nearer a living.
fr: Mais, malgre tant d'efforts, il ne parvenait pas a atteindre son ennemie, ni meme, ce qui est plus grave, a se faire une situation sociale.

eng: As he paced the Thames embankment, bitterly biting a cheap cigar and brooding on the advance of Anarchy, there was no anarchist with a bomb in his pocket so savage or so solitary as he.
fr: Quand il se promenait sur les quais de la Tamise, mordant amerement un cigare a bas prix et meditant sur les progres de l'Anarchie, il n'y avait pas d'anarchiste, bombe en poche, plus sauvage d'aspect que ce solitaire ami de l'ordre.

eng: Indeed, he always felt that Government stood alone and desperate, with its back to the wall.
fr: Il se persuadait que le gouvernement, la societe, etaient isoles, dans une situation desesperee, au pied du mur.

eng: He was too quixotic to have cared for it otherwise.
fr: Il ne fallait rien moins que cette situation desesperee pour apitoyer ce Don Quichotte.

eng: He walked on the Embankment once under a dark red sunset.
fr: Ce soir-la, le soleil se couchait dans le sang.

eng: The red river reflected the red sky, and they both reflected his anger.
fr: L'eau rouge refletait le ciel rouge, et, dans le ciel et dans l'eau, Syme reconnaissait la couleur de sa colere.

eng: The sky, indeed, was so swarthy, and the light on the river relatively so lurid, that the water almost seemed of fiercer flame than the sunset it mirrored.
fr: Le ciel etait si charge et le fleuve si brillant que le ciel palissait aupres du flot de feu liquide, s'ecoulant a travers les vastes cavernes d'une mysterieuse region souterraine.

eng: It looked like a stream of literal fire winding under the vast caverns of a subterranean country.
fr: Syme, a cette epoque, manquait d'argent.

eng: Syme was shabby in those days. ~~~ He wore an old-fashioned black chimney-pot hat; he was wrapped in a yet more old-fashioned cloak, black and ragged; and the combination gave him the look of the early villains in Dickens and Bulwer Lytton.
fr: Il portait un chapeau haut de forme demode, un manteau noir et dechire encore plus demode, et cette tenue lui donnait l'air des traitres de Dickens et de Bulwer Lytton.

eng: Also his yellow beard and hair were more unkempt and leonine than when they appeared long afterwards, cut and pointed, on the lawns of Saffron Park.
fr: Sa barbe et ses cheveux blonds se herissaient.

eng: A long, lean, black cigar, bought in Soho for twopence, stood out from between his tightened teeth, and altogether he looked a very satisfactory specimen of the anarchists upon whom he had vowed a holy war.
fr: On n'eut guere pressenti en ce personnage leonin, le parfait gentleman qui, longtemps apres, devait penetrer dans les jardinets de Saffron Park ; entre ses dents serrees il tenait un long cigare noir qu'il avait achete quatre sous dans Soho, il ressemblait assez a l'un de ces anarchistes contre lesquels il menait la guerre sainte.

eng: Syme, at a crisis of his morbid fears for humanity, seemed stung by the mere stolidity of the automatic official, a mere bulk of blue in the twilight.
fr: Syme, en raison des inquietudes maladives que lui causait le sort precaire de l'humanite, fut interloque par la placide assurance de l'automatique factionnaire qui faisait dans le crepuscule une large tache bleue.

eng: "A good evening is it?" ~~~ he said sharply.
fr: -- En verite, dit-il d'un ton cassant, le soir est-il si bon ou si beau ?

eng: "You fellows would call the end of the world a good evening.
fr: Pour vous autres, la fin du monde aussi serait un beau soir...

eng: I tell you that if that were literally human blood, spilt and shining, you would still be standing here as solid as ever, looking out for some poor harmless tramp whom you could move on.
fr: Je vous le dis : ce fleuve charrierait du sang humain, des flots lumineux de sang, que vous seriez la comme vous etes ce soir, solide et calme, occupe a guetter quelque pauvre vagabond inoffensif, pour le faire circuler.

eng: You policemen are cruel to the poor, but I could forgive you even your cruelty if it were not for your calm."
fr: Vous autres policemen, vous etes cruels pour les pauvres ! ~~~ Encore vous pardonnerais-je votre cruaute.
C'est votre calme qui est intolerable.

eng: "If we are calm," replied the policeman, "it is the calm of organised resistance."
fr: -- Si nous sommes calmes, repliqua le policeman, c'est le calme de la resistance organisee.

eng: "The composure of an army is the anger of a nation."
fr: Le calme d'une armee est fait de la furie d'un peuple.

eng: "Good God, the Board Schools!"
said Syme.
fr: -- Dieu bon !

eng: "Is this undenominational education?"
fr: s'ecria Syme, voila l'enseignement qu'on donne dans les ecoles !

eng: "No," said the policeman sadly, "I never had any of those advantages.
fr: Est-ce la ce qu'on appelle l'education non confessionnelle et egale pour tous ?
-- Non, fit tristement le policeman, je n'ai pas eu le benefice d'une telle education.

eng: The Board Schools came after my time.
fr: Les Boardschools sont venues apres moi.

eng: What education I had was very rough and old-fashioned, I am afraid."
fr: L'education que j'ai recue fut tres sommaire, et maintenant elle serait tres demodee, je le crains.

eng: "Where did you have it?"
fr: -- Ou l'avez-vous recue ?

eng: asked Syme, wondering.
fr: demanda Syme etonne. ~~~ -- Oh !

eng: "Oh, at Harrow," said the policeman The class sympathies which, false as they are, are the truest things in so many men, broke out of Syme before he could control them.
fr: dit le policeman, a Harrow. ~~~ Les sympathies de classe qui, pour fausses qu'elles soient, sont pourtant chez bien des gens ce qu'il y a de moins faux, eclaterent dans Syme avant qu'il put les maitriser.

eng: The policeman sighed and shook his head. ~~~ "I know," he said solemnly, "I know I am not worthy."
fr: Le policeman secoua la tete et soupira : -- Je sais, dit-il solennellement, je ne suis pas digne.

eng: "But why did you join the police?"
fr: -- Mais pourquoi y etre entre ?

eng: asked Syme with rude curiosity.
fr: interrogea Syme assez indiscretement.

eng: "For much the same reason that you abused the police," replied the other.
fr: -- A peu pres pour la meme raison qui vous la fait calomnier.

eng: "I found that there was a special opening in the service for those whose fears for humanity were concerned rather with the aberrations of the scientific intellect than with the normal and excusable, though excessive, outbreaks of the human will.
fr: J'ai reconnu qu'il y a dans cette organisation des emplois pour ceux dont les inquietudes touchant l'humanite visent les aberrations du raisonnement scientifique plutot que les eruptions normales et, malgre leurs exces, excusables, des passions humaines.

eng: How comes a man like you to be talking philosophy in a blue helmet on the Thames embankment?"
fr: Comment se fait-il qu'un homme comme vous vienne parler philosophie sous un casque bleu, sur les quais de la Tamise ?

eng: "You have evidently not heard of the latest development in our police system," replied the other. ~~~ "I am not surprised at it.
fr: -- Il est evident que vous n'etes pas informe des recents developpements de notre systeme de police, repliqua l'autre.

eng: We are keeping it rather dark from the educated class, because that class contains most of our enemies.
fr: Je n'en suis pas surpris, d'ailleurs, car nous les cachons a la classe cultivee, ou se recrutent la plupart de nos ennemis.

eng: But you seem to be exactly in the right frame of mind.
fr: Mais il me semble que vous avez des dispositions... que vous pourriez etre des notres... -- Etre des votres !

eng: I think you might almost join us."
fr: demanda Syme, et pour quoi ?

eng: "Join you in what?"
fr: -- Je vais vous dire...

eng: asked Syme.
fr: Voici la situation.

eng: "I will tell you," said the policeman slowly. ~~~ "This is the situation: The head of one of our departments, one of the most celebrated detectives in Europe, has long been of opinion that a purely intellectual conspiracy would soon threaten the very existence of civilisation. ~~~ He is certain that the scientific and artistic worlds are silently bound in a crusade against the Family and the State.
fr: Depuis longtemps le chef de notre Division, l'un des plus fameux detectives d'Europe, estime qu'une conspiration intellectuelle, purement intellectuelle, ne tardera pas a menacer l'existence meme de la civilisation : la Science et l'Art ont entrepris une silencieuse croisade contre la Famille et l'Etat.

eng: He has, therefore, formed a special corps of policemen, policemen who are also philosophers.
fr: C'est pourquoi il a cree un corps special de policemen-philosophes.

eng: It is their business to watch the beginnings of this conspiracy, not merely in a criminal but in a controversial sense.
fr: Leur role est de surveiller les initiateurs de cette conspiration, de les surveiller non seulement par les moyens dont nous disposons pour reprimer les crimes, mais de les surveiller et de les combattre aussi par la polemique, par la controverse.

eng: I am a democrat myself, and I am fully aware of the value of the ordinary man in matters of ordinary valour or virtue.
fr: Je suis, pour mon compte, un democrate, et je sais tres bien quel est, dans le peuple, le niveau normal du courage et de la vertu.

eng: But it would obviously be undesirable to employ the common policeman in an investigation which is also a heresy hunt."
fr: Mais il serait peu prudent de confier a des policemen ordinaires des recherches qui constituent une chasse aux heresies.

eng: Compared to him, burglars and bigamists are essentially moral men; my heart goes out to them.
fr: Compares a lui, le voleur et le bigame sont des gens d'une parfaite moralite. ~~~ Combien mon coeur les lui prefere !

eng: They accept the essential ideal of man; they merely seek it wrongly.
fr: Ils ne nient pas l'essentiel ideal de l'homme.

eng: Thieves respect property.
fr: Tout leur tort est de ne pas savoir le chercher ou il est.

eng: They merely wish the property to become their property that they may more perfectly respect it.
fr: Le voleur respecte la propriete ; c'est pour la respecter mieux encore qu'il desire devenir proprietaire.

eng: But philosophers dislike property as property; they wish to destroy the very idea of personal possession.
fr: Le philosophe deteste la propriete en soi : il veut detruire l'idee meme de la propriete individuelle.

eng: But philosophers hate life itself, their own as much as other people's."
fr: Le philosophe hait la vie, la vie en soi ; il la hait en lui-meme comme en autrui.

eng: Syme struck his hands together.
fr: -- Comme cela est vrai !

eng: "How true that is," he cried.
fr: s'ecria Syme en battant des mains.

eng: "I have felt it from my boyhood, but never could state the verbal antithesis.
fr: C'est ce que j'ai pense des mon enfance ; mais je n'etais pas parvenu a formuler l'antithese verbale.

eng: The common criminal is a bad man, but at least he is, as it were, a conditional good man.
fr: Oui, tout mechant qu'il soit, le criminel ordinaire est du moins, pour ainsi dire, conditionnellement un brave homme.

eng: He says that if only a certain obstacle be removed say a wealthy uncle he is then prepared to accept the universe and to praise God.
fr: Il suffirait qu'un certain obstacle -- disons un oncle riche -- fut ecarte pour qu'il acceptat l'univers tel qu'il est et louat Dieu.

eng: He is a reformer, but not an anarchist.
fr: C'est un reformateur ; ce n'est pas un anarchiste.

eng: He wishes to cleanse the edifice, but not to destroy it.
fr: Il veut reparer l'edifice, il ne veut pas le demolir.

eng: But the evil philosopher is not trying to alter things, but to annihilate them.
fr: Mais le mauvais philosophe ne se propose pas de modifier : il veut aneantir.

eng: The moderns say we must not punish heretics.
fr: Les modernes nient qu'on ait le droit de punir les heretiques.

eng: My only doubt is whether we have a right to punish anybody else."
fr: Je me demande, moi, si nous avons le droit de punir qui que ce soit qui ne l'est pas.

eng: "But this is absurd!"
fr: -- Mais c'est absurde !

eng: cried the policeman, clasping his hands with an excitement uncommon in persons of his figure and costume, "but it is intolerable!
fr: fit le policeman avec une ardeur peu commune chez les personnes de sa profession et de sa corpulence. ~~~ Mais c'est intolerable !

eng: I don't know what you're doing, but you're wasting your life.
fr: J'ignore quel metier vous faites, mais quel qu'il soit, je sais que vous manquez votre vocation.

eng: You must, you shall, join our special army against anarchy.
fr: Il faut que vous vous enroliez dans notre brigade de philosophes antianarchistes, et vous le ferez.

eng: But, beastly as they are, they generally have the one merit of disagreeing with each other.
fr: Mais tout degoutants qu'ils soient, ils ont generalement le merite d'etre en desaccord les uns avec les autres.

eng: How can you talk of their leading one army or hurling one bolt.
fr: Comment pouvez-vous parler d'une armee organisee par eux et du coup qu'ils sont sur le point de frapper ?

eng: What is this anarchy?"
fr: Qu'est-ce que cette anarchie-la ?

eng: You might even call the outer ring the laity and the inner ring the priesthood.
fr: On pourrait meme designer le cercle exterieur par le mot << laic >> et le cercle interieur par le mot << sacerdotal >>.

eng: I prefer to call the outer ring the innocent section, the inner ring the supremely guilty section.
fr: Je prefere ces deux etiquettes, plus claires : section des innocents et section des criminels.

eng: The outer ring the main mass of their supporters are merely anarchists; that is, men who believe that rules and formulas have destroyed human happiness.
fr: Les premiers, les plus nombreux, sont de simples anarchistes, des gens convaincus que les lois et les formules ont detruit le bonheur de l'humanite.

eng: They believe that all the evil results of human crime are the results of the system that has called it crime.
fr: Ils croient que les sinistres effets de la perversite sont produits par le systeme precisement qui admet la notion de la perversite.

eng: They do not believe that the crime creates the punishment. ~~~ They believe that the punishment has created the crime.
fr: Ils ne croient pas que le crime engendre la peine : ils croient que la peine engendre le crime.

eng: They believe that if a man picked a pocket he would naturally feel exquisitely good.
fr: Selon eux, le pickpocket aurait l'impression d'etre d'une exquise bonte.

eng: These I call the innocent section."
fr: Voila ma section des Innocents.

eng: "Oh!"
fr: -- Oh !

eng: said Syme.
fr: fit Syme.

eng: "Naturally, therefore, these people talk about a happy time coming'; the paradise of the future'; mankind freed from the bondage of vice and the bondage of virtue,' and so on. ~~~ And so also the men of the inner circle speak the sacred priesthood.
fr: -- Naturellement, ces gens-la parlent de l'heureux temps qui s'annonce, d'un avenir paradisiaque d'une humanite delivree du joug de la vertu et du vice, etc. Ceux du cercle interieur, du cercle sacerdotal, tiennent le meme langage.

eng: They also speak to applauding crowds of the happiness of the future, and of mankind freed at last.
fr: Eux aussi, devant les foules delirantes, parlent de felicite future, de delivrance finale.

eng: But in their mouths" and the policeman lowered his voice "in their mouths these happy phrases have a horrible meaning.
fr: Mais, dans leur bouche -- et ici le policeman baissa la voix -- ces mots ont un sens epouvantable.

eng: They are under no illusions; they are too intellectual to think that man upon this earth can ever be quite free of original sin and the struggle.
fr: Car ils ne se font pas d'illusions ; ils sont trop intelligents pour croire que l'homme, en ce monde, puisse jamais etre tout a fait libere du peche originel et de la lutte.

eng: And they mean death.
fr: Ils pensent a la mort.

eng: When they say that mankind shall be free at last, they mean that mankind shall commit suicide.
fr: Quand ils parlent de la delivrance finale de l'humanite, ils pensent au suicide de l'humanite.

eng: When they talk of a paradise without right or wrong, they mean the grave."
fr: Quand ils parlent d'un paradis sans mal et sans bien, ils pensent a la tombe.

eng: "They have but two objects, to destroy first humanity and then themselves.
fr: Ils n'ont que deux buts : detruire les autres hommes, puis se detruire eux-memes.

eng: That is why they throw bombs instead of firing pistols.
fr: C'est pourquoi ils lancent des bombes au lieu de tirer des coups de revolver.

eng: asked Syme, with a sort of passion.
fr: demanda Syme passionnement.

eng: "I know for a fact that there is a vacancy at the moment," said the policeman, "as I have the honour to be somewhat in the confidence of the chief of whom I have spoken.
fr: -- Je sais qu'il y a une vacance en ce moment, ayant l'honneur d'etre un peu dans les confidences du chef dont je vous ai parle.

eng: You should really come and see him.
fr: Voulez-vous venir le voir ?

eng: Or rather, I should not say see him, nobody ever sees him; but you can talk to him if you like." ~~~ "Telephone?"
fr: Ou plutot je ne dis pas que vous le verrez, personne ne l'ayant jamais vu, mais vous pourrez causer avec lui, si vous voulez.

eng: inquired Syme, with interest.
fr: -- Par le telephone, donc ? ~~~ -- Non.

eng: "No," said the policeman placidly, "he has a fancy for always sitting in a pitch-dark room.
fr: Il a la fantaisie de vivre dans une chambre tres obscure.

eng: "Are you the new recruit?"
fr: -- C'est vous la nouvelle recrue ?

eng: asked a heavy voice.
fr: interrogea une voix puissante.

eng: And in some strange way, though there was not the shadow of a shape in the gloom, Syme knew two things: first, that it came from a man of massive stature; and second, that the man had his back to him.
fr: Et, mysterieusement, bien qu'il ne put percevoir dans ces tenebres l'ombre meme d'une forme humaine, Syme eut conscience de deux choses : d'abord, que la voix etait celle d'un homme de massive stature, puis, que cet homme lui tournait le dos.

eng: "Are you the new recruit?"
fr: -- C'est vous la nouvelle recrue ?

eng: said the invisible chief, who seemed to have heard all about it.
fr: repeta le chef, qui semblait etre au courant de tout.

eng: "All right.
fr: C'est bien.

eng: You are engaged."
fr: Vous etes enrole.

eng: Syme, quite swept off his feet, made a feeble fight against this irrevocable phrase.
fr: Syme, qui sentait ses jambes se derober sous lui, se defendit faiblement contre l'irrevocable.

eng: "No one has any experience," said the other, "of the Battle of Armageddon."
fr: -- Personne n'a aucune experience, repondit la voix, de la bataille d'Armaggedon.

eng: "But I am really unfit " "You are willing, that is enough," said the unknown.
fr: -- Mais... ~~~ Je suis tout a fait incapable. ~~~ -- Vous avez la bonne volonte.

eng: "Well, really," said Syme, "I don't know any profession of which mere willingness is the final test." ~~~ "I do," said the other "martyrs.
fr: Cela suffit. ~~~ -- Pardon, mais... je ne connais aucun metier ou la bonne volonte soit suffisante... -- J'en connais un, moi : celui de martyr.

eng: He put this carefully in his upper waistcoat pocket, lit a cigarette, and went forth to track and fight the enemy in all the drawing-rooms of London.
fr: Il la placa soigneusement dans la poche superieure de son gilet, alluma une cigarette et se mit a la poursuite de l'ennemi a travers tous les salons de Londres.

eng: Where his adventure ultimately led him we have already seen.
fr: Nous avons vu ou son aventure finit par l'amener : vers une heure et demie, une nuit de fevrier, il voyageait dans une legere embarcation sur la Tamise.

eng: At about half-past one on a February night he found himself steaming in a small tug up the silent Thames, armed with swordstick and revolver, the duly elected Thursday of the Central Council of Anarchists.
fr: Arme de la canne a epee et du revolver, il etait le Jeudi regulierement elu au Conseil Central Anarchiste.

eng: The moon was so strong and full that (by a paradox often to be noticed) it seemed like a weaker sun.
fr: Une lune puissante et pleine, plutot comparable a un soleil pali qu'a une lune normale ; et cela suggerait l'idee d'un jour mort plutot que celle d'une belle nuit de lune.

eng: It gave, not the sense of bright moonshine, but rather of a dead daylight.
fr: Sur tout le paysage se repandait cette decoloration lumineuse et irreelle, ce crepuscule de desastre que Milton a observe pendant les eclipses de soleil.

eng: Over the whole landscape lay a luminous and unnatural discoloration, as of that disastrous twilight which Milton spoke of as shed by the sun in eclipse; so that Syme fell easily into his first thought, that he was actually on some other and emptier planet, which circled round some sadder star.
fr: En sorte que Syme se confirma dans cette pensee, qu'il etait bien sur une autre planete, moins vivante que la notre, gravitant autour d'une etoile plus triste que la notre.

eng: Even the common things he carried with him the food and the brandy and the loaded pistol took on exactly that concrete and material poetry which a child feels when he takes a gun upon a journey or a bun with him to bed.
fr: Jusqu'aux choses communes qu'il portait dans ses poches, sandwichs, brandy, pistolet charge, s'animaient de cette poesie concrete et materielle dont s'exalte un enfant, quand il emporte un fusil a la promenade ou un gateau dans son lit.

eng: The sword-stick and the brandy-flask, though in themselves only the tools of morbid conspirators, became the expressions of his own more healthy romance.
fr: La canne a epee et la gourde de brandy, ces obligatoires et ridicules accessoires de tout conspirateur, devenaient pour lui l'expression de son propre romantisme.

eng: The sword-stick became almost the sword of chivalry, and the brandy the wine of the stirrup-cup.
fr: La canne a epee, c'etait le glaive du chevalier, et le brandy, le coup de l'etrier !

eng: The clear moon that had lit up Chiswick had gone down by the time that they passed Battersea, and when they came under the enormous bulk of Westminster day had already begun to break.
fr: Le clair de lune qui avait brille a Chiswick s'eteignit a Battersea, et, quand on arriva sous la masse enorme de Westminster, le jour commencait a poindre.
De grandes barres de plomb apparurent dans le ciel, puis s'effacerent sous des barres d'argent qui prirent bientot l'eclat du metal chauffe a blanc.

eng: It broke like the splitting of great bars of lead, showing bars of silver; and these had brightened like white fire when the tug, changing its onward course, turned inward to a large landing stage rather beyond Charing Cross.
fr: L'embarcation, changeant de cours, se dirigea vers un grand escalier, un peu au-dela de Charing Cross. ~~~ Les grandes pierres du quai apparurent, gigantesques et sombres, opposant leur masse noire a la blanche aurore.

eng: The great stones of the Embankment seemed equally dark and gigantic as Syme looked up at them.
fr: Syme crut aborder aux marches colossales de quelque palais d'Egypte. ~~~ L'idee lui plut.

eng: They were big and black against the huge white dawn.
fr: Ne pensait-il pas, en effet, monter a l'assaut des trones massifs ou siegeaient d'horribles rois paiens !

eng: They made him feel that he was landing on the colossal steps of some Egyptian palace; and, indeed, the thing suited his mood, for he was, in his own mind, mounting to attack the solid thrones of horrible and heathen kings.
fr: Il sauta a terre et se tint un instant immobile sur la dalle humide et glissante, sombre et fragile figure perdue dans cet immense amas de pierres de taille.

eng: He leapt out of the boat on to one slimy step, and stood, a dark and slender figure, amid the enormous masonry.
fr: Les deux hommes firent reculer le bateau et commencerent a remonter le fleuve.

eng: The two men in the tug put her off again and turned up stream.
fr: Pendant toute la duree du voyage, ils n'avaient pas prononce une parole.
* * * CHAPITRE V LE REPAS EPOUVANTABLE Tout d'abord, Syme crut l'escalier de pierre desert comme une pyramide.
Mais, avant d'avoir atteint le dernier degre, il se rendit compte qu'il y avait un homme accoude au parapet, et que cet homme regardait le fleuve.

eng: They had never spoken a word.
fr: Son aspect etait tres ordinaire.

eng: CHAPTER V. THE FEAST OF FEAR At first the large stone stair seemed to Syme as deserted as a pyramid; but before he reached the top he had realised that there was a man leaning over the parapet of the Embankment and looking out across the river.
fr: Il portait un chapeau de soie et une redingote correcte ; il avait une fleur rouge a la boutonniere.

eng: As a figure he was quite conventional, clad in a silk hat and frock-coat of the more formal type of fashion; he had a red flower in his buttonhole.
fr: De marche en marche, la distance diminuait entre eux ; l'homme ne bougeait pas.

eng: As Syme drew nearer to him step by step, he did not even move a hair; and Syme could come close enough to notice even in the dim, pale morning light that his face was long, pale and intellectual, and ended in a small triangular tuft of dark beard at the very point of the chin, all else being clean-shaven.
fr: Syme put l'approcher d'assez pres pour observer, a la pale lumiere du matin, que la figure de l'inconnu etait longue, bleme, intelligente et se terminait par une touffe de barbe noire, les levres et les joues etant soigneusement rasees, et ces quelques poils semblaient oublies la, par simple negligence.

eng: This scrap of hair almost seemed a mere oversight; the rest of the face was of the type that is best shaven clear-cut, ascetic, and in its way noble.
fr: Cette figure anguleuse, ascetique, noble a sa facon, etait de celles auxquelles la barbe ne sied pas.

eng: Syme drew closer and closer, noting all this, and still the figure did not stir.
fr: Et, tout en faisant ces remarques, Syme se rapprochait toujours ; et l'homme restait toujours immobile.

eng: At first an instinct had told Syme that this was the man whom he was meant to meet.
fr: Au premier regard, Syme avait eu l'intuition que cet homme etait la pour l'attendre.

eng: Then, seeing that the man made no sign, he had concluded that he was not.
fr: Puis, ne lui voyant faire aucun signe, il avait cru s'etre trompe.

eng: And now again he had come back to a certainty that the man had something to do with his mad adventure.
fr: Mais, de nouveau, il revenait a la certitude que cet homme devait jouer un role dans sa folle aventure.

eng: He was as motionless as a wax-work, and got on the nerves somewhat in the same way.
fr: Il etait aussi inerte et a peu pres aussi enervant, par la meme, qu'une poupee de cire.

eng: Syme looked again and again at the pale, dignified and delicate face, and the face still looked blankly across the river.
fr: Syme considerait toujours cette figure pale, delicate et digne, dont le regard eteint ne se detournait pas de la riviere, et tout a coup, tirant de sa poche le document qui lui conferait le titre de Jeudi, il le mit sous les yeux tristes et doux de l'inconnu.

eng: Then he took out of his pocket the note from Buttons proving his election, and put it before that sad and beautiful face.
fr: Alors, celui-ci sourit, d'un sourire inquietant, d'un sourire << d'un seul cote >>, qui haussait la joue droite et abaissait la gauche.

eng: Then the man smiled, and his smile was a shock, for it was all on one side, going up in the right cheek and down in the left.
There was nothing, rationally speaking, to scare anyone about this.
fr: Raisonnablement, toutefois, il n'y avait la rien d'effroyable.

eng: Many people have this nervous trick of a crooked smile, and in many it is even attractive.
fr: Bien des gens ont ce tic nerveux, ce rictus grimacant, et il en est meme chez qui c'est une grace.

eng: But in all Syme's circumstances, with the dark dawn and the deadly errand and the loneliness on the great dripping stones, there was something unnerving in it.
fr: Mais, dans les circonstances ou se trouvait Syme, sous l'influence de cette aurore menacante, avec la mission meurtriere dont il etait charge, dans la solitude de ces grandes pierres ruisselantes, il recut de cet accueil une impression etrange, qui le glaca, qui le paralysa.

eng: There was the silent river and the silent man, a man of even classic face. ~~~ And there was the last nightmare touch that his smile suddenly went wrong.
fr: Ce fleuve silencieux, cet homme silencieux, au visage classique... Et, comme touche finale au cauchemar, ce sourire grimacant.

eng: The spasm of smile was instantaneous, and the man's face dropped at once into its harmonious melancholy.
fr: Mais cette grimace s'effaca instantanement, et la physionomie de l'anarchiste reprit son expression d'harmonieuse melancolie.

eng: He spoke without further explanation or inquiry, like a man speaking to an old colleague.
fr: Sans plus de questions ni d'explications, il parla comme on parle a un vieux collegue.

eng: "If we walk up towards Leicester Square," he said, "we shall just be in time for breakfast.
fr: -- En nous dirigeant tout de suite vers Leicester Square, dit-il, nous arriverons juste a temps pour dejeuner.

eng: Sunday always insists on an early breakfast.
fr: Dimanche tient beaucoup a dejeuner de bon matin.

eng: Have you had any sleep?"
fr: Avez-vous dormi ?

eng: "No," said Syme.
fr: -- Non.

eng: "Nor have I," answered the man in an ordinary tone.
fr: -- Moi non plus, repondit l'autre d'une voix egale.

eng: "I shall try to get to bed after breakfast."
fr: Je tacherai de dormir apres dejeuner.

eng: He spoke with casual civility, but in an utterly dead voice that contradicted the fanaticism of his face.
fr: Il parlait avec une civilite negligente, mais d'une voix extremement monotone qui faisait un vif contraste avec l'ardeur fanatique de sa physionomie.

eng: It seemed almost as if all friendly words were to him lifeless conveniences, and that his only life was hate. ~~~ After a pause the man spoke again.
fr: On eut jure qu'il s'acquittait de ces gestes et propos de bonne grace comme d'insignifiantes obligations, et qu'il ne vivait que de haine.

eng: "Of course, the Secretary of the branch told you everything that can be told.
But the one thing that can never be told is the last notion of the President, for his notions grow like a tropical forest.
fr: Apres un silence, il reprit : -- Sans nul doute, le president de la section vous a dit tout ce qu'il pouvait vous dire.

eng: So in case you don't know, I'd better tell you that he is carrying out his notion of concealing ourselves by not concealing ourselves to the most extraordinary lengths just now.
fr: Mais la seule chose qu'on ne puisse jamais dire, c'est la derniere idee de Dimanche car ses idees se multiplient comme les vegetations d'une foret tropicale.

eng: Originally, of course, we met in a cell underground, just as your branch does.
fr: Pour le cas ou vous ne le sauriez pas, je vous dirai donc qu'il a resolu de nous cacher en ne nous cachant pas du tout.

eng: Then Sunday made us take a private room at an ordinary restaurant.
fr: Au debut, naturellement, nous nous reunissions sous terre, dans une cave, comme font les membres de votre section.

eng: He said that if you didn't seem to be hiding nobody hunted you out.
fr: Puis, Dimanche nous convoqua dans un cabinet de restaurant.

eng: Well, he is the only man on earth, I know; but sometimes I really think that his huge brain is going a little mad in its old age.
fr: Il disait que, si nous ne paraissions pas nous dissimuler, personne ne se defierait de nous.

eng: For now we flaunt ourselves before the public. ~~~ We have our breakfast on a balcony on a balcony, if you please overlooking Leicester Square."
fr: Je sais bien qu'il n'a pas son pareil au monde ; mais, vraiment, je crains parfois que son vaste cerveau ne se detraque un peu, avec l'age : car, maintenant, nous nous exposons aux yeux du public, nous dejeunons sur un balcon -- un balcon, remarquez-le bien, qui domine Leicester Square.

eng: "And what do the people say?"
fr: -- Et que disent les gens ?

eng: asked Syme.
fr: demanda Syme.

eng: "It's quite simple what they say," answered his guide. ~~~ "They say we are a lot of jolly gentlemen who pretend they are anarchists."
fr: -- Ils disent, reprit son guide, que nous sommes de gais compagnons, des gentlemen qui se pretendent anarchistes.

eng: "It seems to me a very clever idea," said Syme.
fr: -- L'idee de Dimanche me parait tres ingenieuse.

eng: But as he turned that corner, and saw the trees and the Moorish cupolas, he could have sworn that he was turning into an unknown Place de something or other in some foreign town.
fr: Mais, ce jour-la, en decouvrant au tournant du coin les coupoles mauresques et les arbres, il eut jure qu'il debouchait sur la << Place de Chose ou Machin >> de quelque ville etrangere.

eng: At one corner of the square there projected a kind of angle of a prosperous but quiet hotel, the bulk of which belonged to a street behind.
fr: En angle, au coin du square, se profilait un hotel, dont la facade principale donnait sur une rue laterale.

eng: In the wall there was one large French window, probably the window of a large coffee-room; and outside this window, almost literally overhanging the square, was a formidably buttressed balcony, big enough to contain a dining-table.
fr: Au-dessus d'une grande porte-fenetre, sans doute la porte d'un cafe, un balcon enorme faisait saillie, dominant le square, un balcon assez spacieux pour qu'une table y fut mise.

eng: Then, as Syme continued to stare at them, he saw something that he had not seen before.
fr: Puis, comme il ne pouvait detourner son regard de ce groupe, il y remarqua quelque chose qui tout d'abord lui avait echappe.

eng: He had not seen it literally because it was too large to see.
fr: Et cela lui avait echappe, parce que c'etait trop grand pour etre vu tout d'abord.

eng: At the nearest end of the balcony, blocking up a great part of the perspective, was the back of a great mountain of a man.
fr: A l'une des extremites du balcon, interceptant la perspective, c'etait le dos d'une gigantesque montagne humaine.

eng: His vastness did not lie only in the fact that he was abnormally tall and quite incredibly fat. ~~~ This man was planned enormously in his original proportions, like a statue carved deliberately as colossal.
fr: Et ce n'etait pas seulement parce qu'il etait extraordinairement haut de stature, et incroyablement gros, que cet homme paraissait si ample : la cause reelle de l'impression d'excessif qu'il produisait etait dans l'ordonnance des plans de sa personne, dans les proportions originales selon lesquelles cette statue vivante avait ete executee.

eng: His head, crowned with white hair, as seen from behind looked bigger than a head ought to be.
fr: Vue de derriere comme la voyait Syme, la tete, couronnee de cheveux blancs, paraissait plus haute et plus large que nature, les oreilles paraissaient plus grandes que des oreilles humaines.

eng: The ears that stood out from it looked larger than human ears.
fr: Tout etait en proportion.

eng: He was enlarged terribly to scale; and this sense of size was so staggering, that when Syme saw him all the other figures seemed quite suddenly to dwindle and become dwarfish.
fr: Aupres de ce colosse, tous les autres hommes se rapetissaient, devenaient des nains.

eng: They were still sitting there as before with their flowers and frock-coats, but now it looked as if the big man was entertaining five children to tea.
fr: A les voir, assis tous les cinq autour de la table, on eut dit que le grand homme offrait le the a des enfants.

eng: As Syme and the guide approached the side door of the hotel, a waiter came out smiling with every tooth in his head.
fr: Comme Syme et son guide approchaient de l'hotel, un garcon vint a eux souriant de toutes ses dents.

eng: "The gentlemen are up there, sare," he said. ~~~ "They do talk and they do laugh at what they talk. ~~~ They do say they will throw bombs at ze king."
fr: -- Ces messieurs sont la-haut, dit-il ; ils causent joyeusement ; ils pretendent qu'ils veulent jeter des bombes sur le roi !

eng: And the waiter hurried away with a napkin over his arm, much pleased with the singular frivolity of the gentlemen upstairs.
fr: Et le garcon, sa serviette sous le bras, s'eloigna rapidement, fort amuse lui-meme de l'exceptionnelle frivolite de ces messieurs.

eng: The two men mounted the stairs in silence.
fr: Les deux hommes gravirent l'escalier en silence.

eng: Syme had never thought of asking whether the monstrous man who almost filled and broke the balcony was the great President of whom the others stood in awe.
fr: Syme n'avait pas un instant songe a demander si ce monstre qui remplissait le balcon etait bien le grand President dont les anarchistes ne pouvaient prononcer le nom sans trembler.

eng: He knew it was so, with an unaccountable but instantaneous certainty.
fr: Il le savait, il l'avait su immediatement, sans qu'il lui eut ete possible de preciser les motifs de sa certitude.

eng: The men greeted him with good-humoured raillery as if they had always known him.
fr: Les autres le saluerent avec bonne humeur, avec familiarite, comme s'ils l'avaient connu de longue date.
Il retrouva un peu de serenite en constatant que ses voisins etaient convenablement et normalement vetus, que la cafetiere etait brillante et solide.

eng: He sobered himself a little by looking at their conventional coats and solid, shining coffee-pot; then he looked again at Sunday.
fr: Puis, il jeta de nouveau un regard sur Dimanche : oui, son visage etait fort grand, mais il ne depassait tout de meme pas les proportions permises a l'humanite.

eng: His face was very large, but it was still possible to humanity.
fr: Comparee au President, toute la compagnie avait l'air passablement vulgaire.

eng: In the presence of the President the whole company looked sufficiently commonplace; nothing about them caught the eye at first, except that by the President's caprice they had been dressed up with a festive respectability, which gave the meal the look of a wedding breakfast.
fr: Rien de frappant, a premiere vue, sinon que, pour obeir au caprice du maitre, tous les membres du Conseil etaient mis comme pour un gala, si bien qu'on se fut cru a un festin de noce.

eng: The effect of this figure was not terrible like that of the President, but it had every diablerie that can come from the utterly grotesque.
fr: Cette figure n'etait pas terrifiante, comme celle du President ; mais elle avait toute cette diablerie qui est un effet de l'extreme grotesque.

eng: If out of that stiff tie and collar there had come abruptly the head of a cat or a dog, it could not have been a more idiotic contrast.
fr: Si de ce col avait surgi une tete de chat ou de chien, le contraste n'eut pas ete plus deconcertant. ~~~ Cet homme, parait-il, se nommait Gogol.

eng: The man's name, it seemed, was Gogol; he was a Pole, and in this circle of days he was called Tuesday.
fr: Il etait polonais et, dans ce cycle des jours de la semaine, portait le nom de Mardi.

eng: His soul and speech were incurably tragic; he could not force himself to play the prosperous and frivolous part demanded of him by President Sunday.
fr: Sa physionomie et son langage etaient incurablement tragiques, et il n'etait point en etat de jouer le role frivole et joyeux que lui imposait Dimanche.

eng: And, indeed, when Syme came in the President, with that daring disregard of public suspicion which was his policy, was actually chaffing Gogol upon his inability to assume conventional graces.
fr: Justement, comme Syme entrait, le President, avec ce mepris audacieux de la suspicion publique dont il avait fait un principe, etait en train de railler Gogol, lui reprochant d'etre refractaire aux manieres et graces mondaines.

eng: "Our friend Tuesday," said the President in a deep voice at once of quietude and volume, "our friend Tuesday doesn't seem to grasp the idea.
fr: -- Notre ami Mardi, disait le President de sa voix profonde et calme, ne saisit pas bien mon idee.

eng: He dresses up like a gentleman, but he seems to be too great a soul to behave like one.
fr: Il s'habille comme un gentleman, mais on voit qu'il a l'ame trop grande pour se tenir comme un gentleman.

eng: He insists on the ways of the stage conspirator.
fr: Il ne peut renoncer aux attitudes des conspirateurs de melodrame.

eng: Now if a gentleman goes about London in a top hat and a frock-coat, no one need know that he is an anarchist.
fr: Qu'un gentleman coiffe du haut-de-forme, vetu de la redingote classique, se promene dignement dans Londres, personne ne soupconnera en lui un anarchiste.

eng: "I am not good at concealment," said Gogol sulkily, with a thick foreign accent; "I am not ashamed of the cause."
fr: -- Che ne suis bas habile a me teguiser, fit Gogol d'un air farouche, avec un fort accent etranger. ~~~ Che n'ai bas honte de la gause.

eng: "Yes you are, my boy, and so is the cause of you," said the President good-naturedly.
fr: -- Mais si ! ~~~ repliqua le President avec gaite, et la cause a honte de vous.

eng: "You hide as much as anybody; but you can't do it, you see, you're such an ass!
fr: Vous vous efforcez autant qu'un autre de vous cacher, mais vous n'y reussissez pas, parce que vous etes un ane.

eng: You try to combine two inconsistent methods.
fr: Vous pretendez concilier deux methodes inconciliables.

eng: When a householder finds a man under his bed, he will probably pause to note the circumstance.
fr: Quand un proprietaire trouve un homme sous son lit, naturellement il prend note de cette circonstance.

eng: But if he finds a man under his bed in a top hat, you will agree with me, my dear Tuesday, that he is not likely even to forget it.
fr: Mais, si c'est un homme coiffe du haut-de-forme qu'il trouve sous son lit, il est peu probable, vous en conviendrez avec moi, mon cher Mardi, qu'il l'oublie facilement.

eng: Now when you were found under Admiral Biffin's bed " "I am not good at deception," said Tuesday gloomily, flushing.
fr: Or, quand on vous trouva sous le lit de l'amiral Biffin... -- Je ne suis pas habile a tromper le monde... repondit Gogol rougissant.

eng: "Right, my boy, right," said the President with a ponderous heartiness, "you aren't good at anything."
fr: -- Parfaitement, mon ami, parfaitement, mon ami, interrompit le President avec une lourde bonhomie : vous n'etes habile a rien.

eng: While this stream of conversation continued, Syme was looking more steadily at the men around him.
fr: Tandis que la conversation se poursuivait, Syme examinait les hommes qui l'entouraient.

eng: As he did so, he gradually felt all his sense of something spiritually queer return.
fr: Et de nouveau il se sentait opprime par l'horreur que lui causaient toujours les monstruosites psychiques.

eng: He had thought at first that they were all of common stature and costume, with the evident exception of the hairy Gogol.
fr: Les commensaux de Dimanche, Gogol excepte, lui avaient d'abord paru des gens assez normaux et meme vulgaires, somme toute.

eng: But as he looked at the others, he began to see in each of them exactly what he had seen in the man by the river, a demoniac detail somewhere.
fr: Mais, en les etudiant avec plus d'attention, il observait en chacun d'eux, comme chez l'homme qui l'avait attendu sur le quai, un caractere demoniaque.

eng: That lop-sided laugh, which would suddenly disfigure the fine face of his original guide, was typical of all these types.
fr: Au rictus grimacant qui defigurait soudain les traits de son guide correspondait chez tous quelque deformation.

eng: Each man had something about him, perceived perhaps at the tenth or twentieth glance, which was not normal, and which seemed hardly human.
fr: Ils avaient tous quelque chose d'exceptionnel, qui se derobait a la premiere analyse, et ce quelque chose d'exceptionnel etait quelque chose d'a peine humain.

eng: The only metaphor he could think of was this, that they all looked as men of fashion and presence would look, with the additional twist given in a false and curved mirror.
fr: Syme se formula a lui-meme sa propre pensee en se disant que ces gens-la lui apparaissaient comme auraient fait des gens a la mode et bien eleves avec la legere touche qu'y aurait ajoutee un miroir fausse, concave ou convexe.

eng: Only the individual examples will express this half-concealed eccentricity.
fr: Des precisions individuelles pourront seules rendre compte de cette secrete anomalie.

eng: Syme's original cicerone bore the title of Monday; he was the Secretary of the Council, and his twisted smile was regarded with more terror than anything, except the President's horrible, happy laughter.
fr: Le cicerone de Syme etait Lundi, secretaire du Conseil. ~~~ Apres le rire abominablement rejoui du President, rien de plus affreux que le rictus du secretaire.

eng: But now that Syme had more space and light to observe him, there were other touches.
fr: Mais, maintenant que Syme pouvait le considerer a loisir et au grand jour, il distinguait en lui d'autres singularites.

eng: His fine face was so emaciated, that Syme thought it must be wasted with some disease; yet somehow the very distress of his dark eyes denied this.
fr: Ce visage noble, mais invraisemblablement emacie, denoncait-il les ravages de la maladie ? ~~~ L'intensite meme de la detresse qu'on lisait dans ses yeux protestait contre cette hypothese.

eng: His eyes were alive with intellectual torture, as if pure thought was pain.
fr: Sa souffrance etait purement intellectuelle : c'etait sa pensee qui faisait sa torture.

eng: He was typical of each of the tribe; each man was subtly and differently wrong.
fr: Et ce trait apparentait entre eux tous les membres du Conseil.

eng: Next to him sat Tuesday, the tousle-headed Gogol, a man more obviously mad.
fr: La folie de Mardi se trahissait plus vite que celle de son voisin Lundi.

eng: Next was Wednesday, a certain Marquis de St. Eustache, a sufficiently characteristic figure.
fr: Mais n'etait-ce pas un fou aussi que Mercredi, -- un certain marquis de Saint-Eustache, figure aussi peu banale que les deux autres ?

eng: The first few glances found nothing unusual about him, except that he was the only man at table who wore the fashionable clothes as if they were really his own.
fr: Au premier abord, on ne trouvait rien d'inusite chez lui. ~~~ De tous, c'etait le seul qui portat ses habits elegants comme s'ils eussent ete vraiment les siens.

eng: He had a black French beard cut square and a black English frock-coat cut even squarer.
fr: Il arborait une barbe noire, taillee en carre, a la francaise ; mais sa redingote affectait la plus pure coupe britannique.

eng: But Syme, sensitive to such things, felt somehow that the man carried a rich atmosphere with him, a rich atmosphere that suffocated.
fr: Syme ne tarda pas a s'apercevoir qu'on respirait autour de ce personnage une atmosphere terriblement capiteuse, capiteuse a en etouffer.

eng: It reminded one irrationally of drowsy odours and of dying lamps in the darker poems of Byron and Poe.
fr: Cela faisait songer aux odeurs enivrantes, aux lampes mourantes des plus mysterieux poemes de Byron ou de Poe.

eng: And in the gloom and thickness of the beard his dark red mouth showed sensual and scornful.
fr: Dans l'epaisseur tenebreuse de cette barbe, la bouche, d'un rouge ardent, etincelait, sensuelle et meprisante.
D'ou qu'il vint, il n'etait certainement pas francais.

eng: Whatever he was he was not a Frenchman; he might be a Jew; he might be something deeper yet in the dark heart of the East.
fr: Peut-etre un juif ; mais, vraisemblablement ses racines plongeaient plus profondement encore au sombre coeur de l'Orient.

eng: Then came Syme, and next a very old man, Professor de Worms, who still kept the chair of Friday, though every day it was expected that his death would leave it empty.
fr: Puis venait Syme, et puis un tres vieux monsieur, l'illustre professeur de Worms, occupait le siege de Vendredi.

eng: Save for his intellect, he was in the last dissolution of senile decay.
fr: Du moins, il l'occupait encore, mais on pouvait chaque jour s'attendre a ce qu'il le laissat vacant.

eng: His face was as grey as his long grey beard, his forehead was lifted and fixed finally in a furrow of mild despair.
fr: Encore que son cerveau gardat toute son activite, le professeur penchait au dernier periode de la decadence senile.
Son visage etait aussi gris que sa longue barbe grise.

eng: In no other case, not even that of Gogol, did the bridegroom brilliancy of the morning dress express a more painful contrast.
fr: Une ride profonde, expression d'un doux desespoir, creusait son front. ~~~ Nul autre, pas meme Gogol, ne faisait avec son habit de fiance un contraste plus penible.

eng: For the red flower in his button-hole showed up against a face that was literally discoloured like lead; the whole hideous effect was as if some drunken dandies had put their clothes upon a corpse.
fr: La fleur rouge de sa boutonniere accusait, exagerait encore la lividite d'un visage litteralement decolore, plombe. ~~~ On eut dit un cadavre que quelques dandies ivres auraient affuble de leurs habits mondains.

eng: When he rose or sat down, which was with long labour and peril, something worse was expressed than mere weakness, something indefinably connected with the horror of the whole scene.
fr: Chaque fois qu'il devait se lever ou s'asseoir, ce qui n'allait pas sans peine, ses mouvements trahissaient quelque chose de pire qu'une simple faiblesse, quelque chose d'indefinissablement lie a l'horreur de toute la scene.

eng: It did not express decrepitude merely, but corruption.
fr: Une idee detestable traversa l'esprit fremissant de Syme.

eng: Another hateful fancy crossed Syme's quivering mind.
fr: Ce n'etait pas seulement de la decrepitude, c'etait deja de la pourriture !
Il ne put s'empecher de penser qu'a chaque mouvement le professeur pouvait tres bien laisser choir un de ses bras ou une de ses jambes.

eng: He could not help thinking that whenever the man moved a leg or arm might fall off.
fr: Samedi tenait le bout de la table. ~~~ Le plus simple de tous ; non pas le moins etonnant.

eng: Right at the end sat the man called Saturday, the simplest and the most baffling of all.
fr: Ce petit homme trapu, au visage carre et rase de pres, portait le nom de Bull : le docteur Bull.

eng: He was a short, square man with a dark, square face clean-shaven, a medical practitioner going by the name of Bull.
fr: On observait chez lui ce melange de desinvolture et de familiarite polie qui caracterise souvent les jeunes medecins.

eng: He had that combination of _savoir-faire_ with a sort of well-groomed coarseness which is not uncommon in young doctors.
fr: Il portait ses beaux habits hardiment plutot qu'avec aisance, et un sourire vague restait fige sur ses levres.

eng: He carried his fine clothes with confidence rather than ease, and he mostly wore a set smile.
fr: Seul signe particulier : il avait sur le nez une paire de lunettes aux verres noirs, presque opaques.
Pourquoi ces disques sombres epouvanterent-ils Syme ?

eng: There was nothing whatever odd about him, except that he wore a pair of dark, almost opaque spectacles.
fr: Peut-etre le crescendo d'imaginations delirantes qui l'agitait le predisposait-il a tout prendre au tragique.

eng: It may have been merely a crescendo of nervous fancy that had gone before, but those black discs were dreadful to Syme; they reminded him of half-remembered ugly tales, of some story about pennies being put on the eyes of the dead.
fr: Il se rememora aussitot une affreuse histoire, a demi oubliee, ou il etait question de sous qu'on incrustait dans les yeux des morts.

eng: Syme's eye always caught the black glasses and the blind grin.
fr: Le regard de Syme ne pouvait se detacher de ces lunettes noires, de ce sourire fige.

eng: Had the dying Professor worn them, or even the pale Secretary, they would have been appropriate.
fr: Sur le nez du vieux professeur ou du pale secretaire, elles ne l'eussent point surpris.
Elles ne convenaient pas a ce jeune homme rable, dont elles rendaient la physionomie bizarrement enigmatique.

eng: But on the younger and grosser man they seemed only an enigma.
fr: Elles cachaient pour ainsi dire ce qui en eut ete la cle.

eng: They took away the key of the face.
fr: Que signifiait son eternel sourire ?

eng: You could not tell what his smile or his gravity meant.
fr: Que voulait dire sa gravite ?

eng: Partly from this, and partly because he had a vulgar virility wanting in most of the others it seemed to Syme that he might be the wickedest of all those wicked men.
fr: Cette singularite, jointe a cette virilite vulgaire dont tous les autres, sauf Gogol, etaient prives, persuada Syme que le docteur aux yeux noirs devait etre le pire d'entre ces mauvais.

eng: Syme even had the thought that his eyes might be covered up because they were too frightful to see.
fr: Il pensa meme que le docteur ne se cachait ainsi les yeux que parce qu'ils etaient trop horribles a voir.

eng: CHAPTER VI.
fr: * * * CHAPITRE VI DEMASQUE !

eng: THE EXPOSURE Such were the six men who had sworn to destroy the world.
fr: Tels etaient les six hommes qui avaient jure la destruction du monde.

eng: Again and again Syme strove to pull together his common sense in their presence.
fr: A plusieurs reprises, Syme fit un grand effort pour reconquerir son sang-froid en leur presence.

eng: He could only fancy, as in some old-world fable, that if a man went westward to the end of the world he would find something say a tree that was more or less than a tree, a tree possessed by a spirit; and that if he went east to the end of the world he would find something else that was not wholly itself a tower, perhaps, of which the very shape was wicked.
fr: -- Un homme, songeait Syme, qui marcherait toujours vers l'ouest jusqu'au bout du monde, finirait sans doute par trouver quelque chose, par exemple un arbre, qui serait a la fois plus et moins qu'un arbre, soit un arbre possede par des esprits. ~~~ Et, de meme, en allant toujours vers l'est, jusqu'au bout du monde, il rencontrerait une certaine chose qui ne serait pas non plus tout a fait cette chose meme, une tour peut-etre, dont l'architecture deja serait un peche.

eng: So these figures seemed to stand up, violent and unaccountable, against an ultimate horizon, visions from the verge.
fr: C'est ainsi que les membres du Conseil, avec leurs silhouettes violentes et incomprehensibles, etaient pour Syme de vivantes visions de l'abime, et se detachaient sur un horizon ultime.

eng: The ends of the earth were closing in.
fr: En eux les deux bouts du monde se rejoignaient.

eng: Talk had been going on steadily as he took in the scene; and not the least of the contrasts of that bewildering breakfast-table was the contrast between the easy and unobtrusive tone of talk and its terrible purport.
fr: La conversation ne s'etait pas interrompue, et le ton aise et enjoue des causeurs faisait avec le sujet de l'entretien le plus etonnant des contrastes que reunissait cet etonnant dejeuner.

eng: They were deep in the discussion of an actual and immediate plot.
fr: Ils parlaient, a fond, d'un complot a realiser sans remise.

eng: The waiter downstairs had spoken quite correctly when he said that they were talking about bombs and kings.
fr: Le garcon ne se trompait pas en disant qu'il s'agissait de bombes et de rois.

eng: Only three days afterwards the Czar was to meet the President of the French Republic in Paris, and over their bacon and eggs upon their sunny balcony these beaming gentlemen had decided how both should die.
fr: Dans trois jours, le Tsar devait rencontrer le President de la Republique francaise a Paris, et, sur le balcon ensoleille, en consommant leur jambon et leurs oeufs, ces joyeux conspirateurs decidaient la mort de l'un et de l'autre.

eng: Ordinarily speaking, the proximity of this positive and objective crime would have sobered Syme, and cured him of all his merely mystical tremors.
fr: Dans des circonstances moins extraordinaires, l'imminence de la realite objective, positive, du crime aurait calme Syme et dissipe ses craintes purement mystiques.

eng: He would have thought of nothing but the need of saving at least two human bodies from being ripped in pieces with iron and roaring gas.
fr: Il n'aurait plus pense qu'a la necessite de sauver les deux hommes des fragments de fer et de la deflagration de la poudre qui menacait de les dechiqueter.

eng: But the truth was that by this time he had begun to feel a third kind of fear, more piercing and practical than either his moral revulsion or his social responsibility.
fr: Mais le fait est qu'en ce moment precis, il commencait a ressentir une crainte personnelle, immediate, ou s'evanouissaient ses sentiments de repulsion et meme le souci de ses responsabilites sociales.

eng: Very simply, he had no fear to spare for the French President or the Czar; he had begun to fear for himself.
fr: Ce n'etait plus pour le Tsar et le President de la Republique qu'il tremblait : c'etait pour lui-meme.

eng: Most of the talkers took little heed of him, debating now with their faces closer together, and almost uniformly grave, save when for an instant the smile of the Secretary ran aslant across his face as the jagged lightning runs aslant across the sky.
fr: La plupart des anarchistes, passionnement interesses par la discussion, ne se preoccupaient guere de Syme. ~~~ Serres les uns contre les autres, ils etaient tous tres graves.

eng: But there was one persistent thing which first troubled Syme and at last terrified him.
fr: A peine le rictus du secretaire passait-il parfois sur son visage, comme un eclair dans le ciel.

eng: The President was always looking at him, steadily, and with a great and baffling interest.
fr: Mais Syme fit une remarque qui d'abord le troubla et bientot le terrifia : le President ne cessait de le regarder fixement, de le devisager, avec un interet persistant.

eng: But he remembered that he was still tied to Gregory by a great promise. ~~~ He had promised never to do the very thing that he now felt himself almost in the act of doing.
fr: Mais il se rappelait aussi qu'il restait lie a Gregory par une promesse intransgressible : il lui avait promis de ne pas faire precisement ce qu'il avait ete sur le point de faire.

eng: He had promised not to jump over that balcony and speak to that policeman.
fr: Il lui avait promis de ne pas enjamber le balcon, de ne pas appeler ce policeman.
