eng: He took his cold hand off the cold stone balustrade.
fr: Il retira sa main glacee de la froide balustrade de pierre.

eng: First, it never occurred to him to doubt that the President and his Council could crush him if he continued to stand alone.
fr: D'abord, il ne lui arriva pas un instant de mettre en doute que le President et son Conseil ne pussent l'aneantir, s'il restait la, seul, parmi ces miserables.

eng: The place might be public, the project might seem impossible.
fr: Sans doute, sur une place publique une telle execution eut pu paraitre impossible.

eng: But Sunday was not the man who would carry himself thus easily without having, somehow or somewhere, set open his iron trap.
fr: Mais Dimanche n'etait pas homme a montrer tant d'aisance sans avoir, quelque part et de quelque maniere, prepare son piege.

eng: Either by anonymous poison or sudden street accident, by hypnotism or by fire from hell, Sunday could certainly strike him.
fr: Poison anonyme ou brusque accident, fortuit en apparence, hypnotisme, feu infernal : peu importait comment, mais certainement Dimanche pouvait le frapper.

eng: They were a balconyful of gentlemen overlooking a bright and busy square; but he felt no more safe with them than if they had been a boatful of armed pirates overlooking an empty sea.
fr: Mais son salut n'exigeait certainement pas moins. ~~~ Il y avait la, sur un balcon, au-dessus d'un square passager, quelques gentlemen, parmi lesquels Syme ne se sentait pas plus en securite qu'il ne l'eut ete, au milieu de la mer deserte, dans une chaloupe pleine de pirates armes.

eng: There was a second thought that never came to him.
fr: Et il n'eut pas davantage l'idee qu'il pourrait etre gagne a l'ennemi.

eng: It never occurred to him to be spiritually won over to the enemy. ~~~ Many moderns, inured to a weak worship of intellect and force, might have wavered in their allegiance under this oppression of a great personality.
fr: Beaucoup d'autres, en ce temps, habitues a honorer de toute leur faiblesse l'intelligence et la force, auraient pu hesiter dans leur loyaute, ceder au prestige oppressif de la puissante personnalite de Dimanche.

eng: They might have called Sunday the super-man.
fr: Ils auraient salue en lui le Surhomme.

eng: If any such creature be conceivable, he looked, indeed, somewhat like it, with his earth-shaking abstraction, as of a stone statue walking.
fr: Et, en effet, si le Surhomme est concevable, Dimanche lui ressemblait beaucoup, avec son energie capable d'ebranler la terre dans un moment de distraction.
C'etait une statue de pierre en mouvement.

eng: He might have been called something above man, with his large plans, which were too obvious to be detected, with his large face, which was too frank to be understood.
fr: Oui, cet etre aux plans vastes, trop visibles pour etre vus, au visage trop ouvert, trop explicite pour qu'on le comprit, pouvait faire penser qu'il y avait la plus qu'un homme.

eng: The men were eating as they talked, and even in this they were typical.
fr: Les anarchistes mangeaient en causant, et jusque dans leur maniere de manger se revelait le caractere de chacun.

eng: Dr. Bull and the Marquis ate casually and conventionally of the best things on the table cold pheasant or Strasbourg pie.
fr: Le docteur Bull et le marquis chipotaient avec negligence les meilleurs morceaux, du faisan froid, du pate de Strasbourg.

eng: But the Secretary was a vegetarian, and he spoke earnestly of the projected murder over half a raw tomato and three quarters of a glass of tepid water.
fr: Le secretaire etait vegetarien, et discutait de bombes et de meurtres tout en absorbant une tomate crue, arrosee d'un verre d'eau tiede.

eng: The old Professor had such slops as suggested a sickening second childhood.
fr: Le vieux professeur avait des hoquets precurseurs d'un prochain gatisme.

eng: And even in this President Sunday preserved his curious predominance of mere mass.
fr: Le President gardait, la comme en tout, la superiorite incontestable de sa masse.
Il mangeait comme vingt !

eng: For he ate like twenty men; he ate incredibly, with a frightful freshness of appetite, so that it was like watching a sausage factory.
fr: Il mangeait incroyablement ! ~~~ On eut cru en le regardant devorer, assister a la manoeuvre d'une fabrique de saucisses.

eng: Yet continually, when he had swallowed a dozen crumpets or drunk a quart of coffee, he would be found with his great head on one side staring at Syme.
fr: Et apres avoir enfourne une douzaine de petits pains en quelques bouchees et bu toute une pinte de cafe, il recommencait, la tete penchee, a surveiller Syme.

eng: "I have often wondered," said the Marquis, taking a great bite out of a slice of bread and jam, "whether it wouldn't be better for me to do it with a knife.
fr: -- Je me suis demande souvent, dit le marquis, en mordant dans une tartine de confiture, si je ne ferais pas mieux d'employer le couteau, de preference a la bombe.

eng: Most of the best things have been brought off with a knife.
fr: Le couteau a servi a couper d'excellentes choses. ~~~ Quelle exquise sensation !

eng: And it would be a new emotion to get a knife into a French President and wriggle it round."
fr: Enfoncer un couteau dans le dos d'un President de la Republique et retourner le fer dans la plaie !

eng: "You are wrong," said the Secretary, drawing his black brows together.
fr: -- Vous avez tort, protesta le secretaire en froncant les sourcils.

eng: "The knife was merely the expression of the old personal quarrel with a personal tyrant.
fr: Le couteau convenait a l'antique querelle personnelle d'un individu contre un tyran.

eng: Dynamite is not only our best tool, but our best symbol.
fr: La dynamite n'est pas seulement notre instrument le meilleur, elle est aussi notre meilleur symbole.

eng: It is as perfect a symbol of us as is incense of the prayers of the Christians.
fr: Un aussi parfait symbole de l'anarchie que peut l'etre l'encens pour les prieres des chretiens.

eng: It expands; it only destroys because it broadens; even so, thought only destroys because it broadens.
fr: La dynamite se repand et ne tue que parce qu'elle se repand. ~~~ La pensee aussi ne detruit que parce qu'elle se repand.

eng: A man's brain is a bomb," he cried out, loosening suddenly his strange passion and striking his own skull with violence. ~~~ "My brain feels like a bomb, night and day.
fr: Le cerveau est une bombe ! ~~~ s'ecria-t-il en s'abandonnant soudain a sa passion et en se frappant le crane avec violence : mon cerveau est une bombe que je sens sur le point, sans cesse, d'eclater !

eng: It must expand!
fr: Il veut se repandre !

eng: It must expand!
fr: Il faut qu'il se repande !

eng: A man's brain must expand, if it breaks up the universe."
fr: Il faut que la pensee se repande, l'univers en fut-il reduit en poussiere.

eng: "I don't want the universe broken up just yet," drawled the Marquis. ~~~ "I want to do a lot of beastly things before I die.
fr: -- Je ne desire pas que l'univers saute en ce moment, dit le marquis, tres bas : je veux faire autant de mal que je pourrai avant de mourir.

eng: I thought of one yesterday in bed."
fr: J'y pensais hier soir, dans mon lit.

eng: "No, if the only end of the thing is nothing," said Dr. Bull with his sphinx-like smile, "it hardly seems worth doing."
fr: -- En effet, dit le docteur Bull avec son sourire de sphinx, si le neant est le but unique de tout, cela vaut-il le moindre effort ?

eng: The old Professor was staring at the ceiling with dull eyes.
fr: Le vieux professeur regardait au plafond de ses yeux morts.

eng: "Every man knows in his heart," he said, "that nothing is worth doing."
fr: -- Chacun sait, dit-il, chacun sait, au fond de son coeur, que rien ne vaut aucun effort.

eng: There was a singular silence, and then the Secretary said "We are wandering, however, from the point.
fr: Il se fit un etrange silence, puis : -- Nous nous ecartons de la question, observa le secretaire.

eng: The only question is how Wednesday is to strike the blow.
fr: La question est celle de savoir comment Mercredi frappera son coup.

eng: I take it we should all agree with the original notion of a bomb.
fr: Il me semble que nous devons nous en tenir a l'idee premiere : la bombe.

eng: As to the actual arrangements, I should suggest that tomorrow morning he should go first of all to " The speech was broken off short under a vast shadow.
fr: Quant aux details, je suis d'avis que, des demain matin, notre camarade s'embarque pour... ~~~ Le secretaire s'interrompit brusquement : une ombre vaste venait de s'allonger sur la table.

eng: President Sunday had risen to his feet, seeming to fill the sky above them.
fr: Le President Dimanche s'etait leve, et il n'y avait plus de ciel au-dessus du balcon.

eng: "Before we discuss that," he said in a small, quiet voice, "let us go into a private room.
fr: -- Avant d'en venir a discuter ce point, dit-il d'une voix etrangement flutee, je vous prie de m'accompagner dans un cabinet particulier.

eng: The instant of choice had come at last, the pistol was at his head.
fr: Le moment de choisir etait venu ; le pistolet etait sur sa tempe.

eng: On the pavement before he could hear the policeman idly stir and stamp, for the morning, though bright, was cold.
fr: En bas, le policeman se promenait paresseusement tout en tapant de la semelle, car la matinee etait belle, mais froide.

eng: A barrel-organ in the street suddenly sprang with a jerk into a jovial tune.
fr: Soudain, dans la rue voisine, un orgue de Barbarie attaqua une ritournelle.

eng: Syme stood up taut, as if it had been a bugle before the battle.
fr: Syme se redressa fierement, comme s'il eut entendu le clairon sonner la bataille.

eng: He found himself filled with a supernatural courage that came from nowhere.
fr: Il sentit affluer en lui, il ne savait d'ou, un courage surnaturel.

eng: And this high pride in being human had lifted him unaccountably to an infinite height above the monstrous men around him.
fr: Et cette grande gloire d'etre simplement un homme l'exaltait, sans qu'il put dire pourquoi ni comment, a une hauteur incommensurable au-dessus des monstres qui l'entouraient.

eng: For an instant, at least, he looked down upon all their sprawling eccentricities from the starry pinnacle of the commonplace.
fr: Un instant, du moins, il jugea leur bizarrerie ignoble, du haut de ce point de vue celeste : le lieu commun.

eng: He felt towards them all that unconscious and elementary superiority that a brave man feels over powerful beasts or a wise man over powerful errors.
fr: Il avait sur eux tous cette inconsciente et elementaire superiorite d'un brave homme sur des betes puissantes, d'un sage sur des erreurs puissantes.

eng: The President led them down an irregular side stair, such as might be used by servants, and into a dim, cold, empty room, with a table and benches, like an abandoned boardroom.
fr: Le President les conduisit, par un escalier de service, dans une chambre vide, froide, mal eclairee. ~~~ Il y avait une table et quelques bancs.

eng: When they were all in, he closed and locked the door.
fr: On se fut cru dans une chambre de bord abandonnee.

eng: The first to speak was Gogol, the irreconcilable, who seemed bursting with inarticulate grievance. ~~~ "Zso! ~~~ Zso!"
fr: Quand tous furent entres, Dimanche ferma la porte et tourna la clef dans la serrure.

eng: he cried, with an obscure excitement, his heavy Polish accent becoming almost impenetrable.
fr: Le premier, Gogol l'irreductible prit la parole.

eng: "You zay you nod ide.
fr: Il paraissait etouffer de fureur.
-- Voila donc, s'ecria-t-il -- et, inarticule, son anglais-polonais devenait presque incomprehensible -- voila donc comment vous renoncez a vous cacher !

eng: You zay you show himselves.
fr: Vous dites que vous vous montrez !

eng: It is all nuzzinks.
fr: Vous vous moquez de nous !

eng: Ven you vant talk importance you run yourselves in a dark box!"
fr: Quand il s'agit de parler serieusement, vous ne manquez pas de vous enfermer dans une boite obscure !

eng: The President seemed to take the foreigner's incoherent satire with entire good humour.
fr: Le President subit avec toute sa bonne humeur l'incoherente diatribe de l'etranger.

eng: "You can't get hold of it yet, Gogol," he said in a fatherly way.
fr: -- Vous ne comprenez pas encore, Gogol, dit-il paternellement.

eng: "When once they have heard us talking nonsense on that balcony they will not care where we go afterwards.
fr: Les gens qui nous ont entendus dire des betises sur le balcon ne se soucient plus de savoir ou nous allons ensuite.

eng: If we had come here first, we should have had the whole staff at the keyhole.
fr: Si nous avions commence par nous cacher ici, tous les garcons seraient venus ecouter a la porte... Vous ne connaissez pas les hommes.

eng: You don't seem to know anything about mankind."
fr: -- Je meurs pour eux, s'ecria le Polonais !

eng: "I die for zem," cried the Pole in thick excitement, "and I slay zare oppressors.
fr: Je tue leurs oppresseurs !

eng: I care not for these games of gonzealment.
fr: Mais je n'aime pas le jeu de cache-cache.

eng: I would zmite ze tyrant in ze open square."
fr: Je voudrais frapper les tyrans en plein square.

eng: "I see, I see," said the President, nodding kindly as he seated himself at the top of a long table.
fr: -- C'est bien, c'est bien, dit le President en s'asseyant au bout de la table.

eng: "You die for mankind first, and then you get up and smite their oppressors.
fr: Vous commencez par mourir pour l'humanite, et puis vous ressuscitez pour frapper les tyrans.

eng: So that's all right.
fr: C'est a merveille.

eng: And now may I ask you to control your beautiful sentiments, and sit down with the other gentlemen at this table.
fr: Permettez-moi, maintenant, de vous prier de maitriser vos beaux sentiments et de vous asseoir avec ces messieurs.

eng: For the first time this morning something intelligent is going to be said."
fr: Pour la premiere fois, ce matin, vous allez entendre une parole sensee.

eng: Syme, with the perturbed promptitude he had shown since the original summons, sat down first.
fr: Avec la promptitude empressee qu'il avait montree des le debut, Syme fut le premier a s'asseoir.

eng: Gogol sat down last, grumbling in his brown beard about gombromise.
fr: Gogol s'assit le dernier, maugreant toujours dans sa barbe brune, et a plusieurs reprises on put percevoir le mot << gompromis >>.

eng: No one except Syme seemed to have any notion of the blow that was about to fall.
fr: Nul, excepte Syme, n'avait l'air de se douter du coup qui allait etre frappe.

eng: Comrades, we were discussing plans and naming places. ~~~ I propose, before saying anything else, that those plans and places should not be voted by this meeting, but should be left wholly in the control of some one reliable member.
fr: nous discutions tout a l'heure des plans d'action ; nous proposions des lieux... Avant d'aller plus loin, je vous demande de confier entierement et sans controle la decision a l'un de nous, a un seul : le camarade Samedi, le docteur Bull.

eng: I suggest Comrade Saturday, Dr. ~~~ Bull."
fr: Tous les regards etaient fixes sur Dimanche.

eng: They all stared at him; then they all started in their seats, for the next words, though not loud, had a living and sensational emphasis.
fr: Brusquement, les membres du Conseil se leverent, car les paroles qui suivirent, sans etre prononcees a haute voix, le furent avec une energie qui fit sensation.

eng: Sunday struck the table.
fr: Dimanche frappa du poing sur la table.

eng: "Not one word more about the plans and places must be said at this meeting.
fr: -- Pas un mot de plus, aujourd'hui, sur nos plans !

eng: Not one tiny detail more about what we mean to do must be mentioned in this company."
fr: Pas la plus mince revelation de nos projets dans cette societe !

eng: Sunday had spent his life in astonishing his followers; but it seemed as if he had never really astonished them until now.
They all moved feverishly in their seats, except Syme.
fr: Dimanche avait passe sa vie a etonner ses compagnons.

eng: He sat stiff in his, with his hand in his pocket, and on the handle of his loaded revolver.
fr: On eut pourtant dit, a les voir, qu'ils subissaient pour la premiere fois cette impression d'etonnement.

eng: When the attack on him came he would sell his life dear.
fr: Ils s'agitaient sur leurs sieges, febrilement, tous, excepte Syme.

eng: He would find out at least if the President was mortal.
fr: Immobile, il serrait, dans sa poche, la crosse de son revolver, s'appretant a vendre cherement sa vie : on saurait enfin si le President etait mortel.

eng: Sunday went on smoothly "You will probably understand that there is only one possible motive for forbidding free speech at this festival of freedom.
fr: Dimanche reprit, d'une voix egale : -- Vous le devinez sans doute : pour proscrire, de ce festival de la liberte, la liberte de la parole, je ne puis avoir qu'un seul motif.

eng: But what would matter, even unto death, is this, that there should be one actually among us who is not of us, who knows our grave purpose, but does not share it, who " The Secretary screamed out suddenly like a woman.
fr: Ce qui importe, ce qui a une importance capitale, c'est qu'il y a parmi nous un homme qui n'est pas des notres, un homme qui connait nos graves desseins et qui n'a pour eux aucune sympathie, un homme...

eng: "It can't be!"
fr: Le secretaire poussa un cri percant, un cri de femme, et se leva d'un bond : -- C'est impossible !...

eng: he cried, leaping.
fr: Il est impossible que...

eng: "There can't " The President flapped his large flat hand on the table like the fin of some huge fish.
fr: Le President abattit sur la table sa main, large comme la nageoire d'un poisson enorme.

eng: "Yes," he said slowly, "there is a spy in this room.
fr: -- Oui, prononca-t-il avec lenteur, il y a dans cette chambre un espion.

eng: I will waste no more words.
fr: Je ne perdrai pas un mot de plus.

eng: His name " Syme half rose from his seat, his finger firm on the trigger.
fr: Il se nomme... Syme se leva a demi, le doigt sur la detente de son revolver.

eng: "His name is Gogol," said the President.
fr: -- Il se nomme Gogol, continua le President : c'est ce charlatan chevelu qui se pretend Polonais.

eng: "He is that hairy humbug over there who pretends to be a Pole."
fr: Gogol se dressa sur ses pieds, un revolver dans chaque main.

eng: Gogol sprang to his feet, a pistol in each hand.
fr: Au meme instant, trois hommes lui sautaient a la gorge.

eng: With the same flash three men sprang at his throat.
fr: Le professeur lui-meme fit un effort pour se lever.

eng: Even the Professor made an effort to rise.
fr: Mais Syme ne vit pas grand'chose de ce qui se passa ensuite.

eng: But Syme saw little of the scene, for he was blinded with a beneficent darkness; he had sunk down into his seat shuddering, in a palsy of passionate relief.
fr: Il etait comme aveugle par une obscurite bienfaisante. ~~~ Effondre sur son banc, il tremblait, comme epouvante de se sentir sauve.

eng: CHAPTER VII. ~~~ THE UNACCOUNTABLE CONDUCT OF PROFESSOR DE WORMS "Sit down!"
fr: * * * CHAPITRE VII CONDUITE INEXPLICABLE DU PROFESSEUR DE WORMS -- Assis !

eng: said Sunday in a voice that he used once or twice in his life, a voice that made men drop drawn swords.
fr: cria Dimanche d'une voix dont il se servait rarement, une voix qui faisait tomber des mains les epees menacantes.

eng: The three who had risen fell away from Gogol, and that equivocal person himself resumed his seat.
fr: Les trois hommes qui avaient apprehende Gogol le lacherent, et ce personnage equivoque reprit sa place.

eng: "Well, my man," said the President briskly, addressing him as one addresses a total stranger, "will you oblige me by putting your hand in your upper waistcoat pocket and showing me what you have there?"
fr: -- Eh bien ! ~~~ mon garcon, reprit le President, comme s'il se fut adresse a un inconnu, voulez-vous me faire le plaisir de fouiller la poche superieure de votre gilet et de me montrer ce que vous y trouverez ?

eng: said the late Gogol. ~~~ It made everyone jump to hear a clear, commercial and somewhat cockney voice coming out of that forest of foreign hair.
fr: Chacun fut surpris d'entendre une voix claire, commerciale pour ainsi dire et presque faubourienne, sortir de cette foret de cheveux exotiques.

eng: It was irrational, as if a Chinaman had suddenly spoken with a Scotch accent.
fr: C'etait tout aussi paradoxal que si, tout a coup, un Chinois eut parle anglais avec l'accent ecossais.

eng: "I gather that you fully understand your position," said Sunday.
fr: -- Je pense que vous vous rendez compte de votre position, continua Dimanche.

eng: "You bet," answered the Pole.
fr: -- Tu parles !

eng: "I see it's a fair cop.
fr: repliqua le Polonais.

eng: All I say is, I don't believe any Pole could have imitated my accent like I did his."
fr: Mais croyez-vous qu'un vrai Polonais aurait su etre aussi Polonais que moi ?

eng: "I concede the point," said Sunday.
fr: -- Je vous accorde ce point.

eng: "I believe your own accent to be inimitable, though I shall practise it in my bath.
fr: Votre accent d'ailleurs est inimitable ; pourtant, je m'y essaierai en prenant mon bain.

eng: Do you mind leaving your beard with your card?"
fr: Voyez-vous quelque inconvenient a laisser ici votre barbe avec votre carte ?

eng: "Not a bit," answered Gogol; and with one finger he ripped off the whole of his shaggy head-covering, emerging with thin red hair and a pale, pert face.
fr: -- Pas le moins du monde ! ~~~ Et, d'un coup, Gogol arracha tout son masque barbu et chevelu, d'ou emergea une figure pale et effrontee, au poil blond.

eng: "It was hot," he added.
fr: -- C'etait bien chaud, ajouta-t-il.

eng: "I will do you the justice to say," said Sunday, not without a sort of brutal admiration, "that you seem to have kept pretty cool under it.
fr: -- Je vous rendrai justice en disant que vous avez su, sous ce masque si chaud, garder votre sang-froid, fit Dimanche, avec une sorte d'admiration brutale.

eng: Now listen to me. ~~~ I like you.
fr: Ecoutez-moi ; vous me plaisez.

eng: The red-haired detective who had masqueraded as Gogol rose to his feet without a word, and walked out of the room with an air of perfect nonchalance.
fr: Le ci-devant Gogol, le detective aux cheveux roux se leva sans mot dire et quitta la chambre, lentement, avec un air de parfaite nonchalance.

eng: Yet the astonished Syme was able to realise that this ease was suddenly assumed; for there was a slight stumble outside the door, which showed that the departing detective had not minded the step.
fr: Mais Syme, stupefait, put se convaincre que cette aisance etait jouee, car un leger trebuchement l'avertit bientot que le detective n'avait pas pris garde a l'escalier.

eng: "Time is flying," said the President in his gayest manner, after glancing at his watch, which like everything about him seemed bigger than it ought to be.
fr: -- Le temps passe, dit le President de sa facon la plus enjouee en consultant une montre qui, comme lui-meme et comme tout ce qu'il portait sur lui, etait de dimensions anormales.

eng: "I must go off at once; I have to take the chair at a Humanitarian meeting."
fr: Il faut que je vous quitte sur-le-champ : j'ai l'obligation de presider une reunion humanitaire.

eng: The Secretary turned to him with working eyebrows.
fr: Le secretaire se tourna vers lui, les sourcils fronces.

eng: "Would it not be better," he said a little sharply, "to discuss further the details of our project, now that the spy has left us?"
fr: -- Ne vaudrait-il pas mieux, dit-il sechement, reprendre la discussion de notre projet, maintenant que nous sommes entre nous ?

eng: "No, I think not," said the President with a yawn like an unobtrusive earthquake.
fr: -- Je ne suis pas de votre avis, repondit le President, avec un baillement comparable a un discret tremblement de terre.

eng: "Leave it as it is.
fr: Laissons tout en plan.

eng: Let Saturday settle it.
fr: Samedi arrangera tout.

eng: I must be off.
fr: Je m'en vais.
Je suis presse.

eng: Breakfast here next Sunday."
fr: Nous dejeunerons ici dimanche prochain.

eng: But the late loud scenes had whipped up the almost naked nerves of the Secretary.
fr: Mais la scene dramatique a laquelle il venait d'assister avait singulierement surexcite le systeme nerveux du secretaire.

eng: He was one of those men who are conscientious even in crime.
fr: C'etait un de ces hommes qui sont consciencieux jusque dans le crime.

eng: "I must protest, President, that the thing is irregular," he said.
fr: -- J'ai le devoir de protester, President, contre cette irregularite !

eng: "It is a fundamental rule of our society that all plans shall be debated in full council.
fr: dit-il. ~~~ C'est une des regles fondamentales de notre societe, que tous les plans doivent etre discutes en plein conseil.

eng: Of course, I fully appreciate your forethought when in the actual presence of a traitor " "Secretary," said the President seriously, "if you'd take your head home and boil it for a turnip it might be useful.
fr: Sans doute, et je rends pleinement hommage a votre prudence, en presence d'un traitre... -- Secretaire, interrompit le President, tres serieusement, si vous rapportez votre tete chez vous, essayez donc de la faire cuire, comme un navet ; peut-etre alors sera-t-elle bonne a quelque chose.

eng: I can't say. ~~~ But it might."
fr: Toutefois, je n'affirme rien.

eng: The Secretary reared back in a kind of equine anger.
fr: Le secretaire etouffa un rugissement de fureur.

eng: "I really fail to understand " he began in high offense.
fr: -- En verite, murmura-t-il, je ne puis comprendre... -- Parfaitement, dit le President en inclinant la tete a plusieurs reprises, c'est bien cela !

eng: "That's it, that's it," said the President, nodding a great many times.
fr: vous ne pouvez comprendre, et cela vous arrive assez souvent.

eng: "That's where you fail right enough.
fr: Voyons ! ~~~ ane bate que vous etes !

eng: You fail to understand.
fr: rugit-il en se levant.

eng: Why, you dancing donkey," he roared, rising, "you didn't want to be overheard by a spy, didn't you?
fr: Vous ne vouliez pas qu'un espion nous entendit, hein ?

eng: How do you know you aren't overheard now?"
fr: Or, que savez-vous si, en ce moment meme, un espion ne nous entend pas ?

eng: And with these words he shouldered his way out of the room, shaking with incomprehensible scorn.
fr: Sur ces mots, il quitta la piece en haussant les epaules.

eng: Four of the men left behind gaped after him without any apparent glimmering of his meaning.
fr: Des cinq hommes qui restaient dans le cabinet, quatre ouvraient la bouche, ecarquillaient les yeux ; ils paraissaient au comble de l'etonnement.

eng: Syme alone had even a glimmering, and such as it was it froze him to the bone.
fr: Syme seul se doutait de la verite, et ce doute le faisait frissonner jusque dans la moelle de ses os.

eng: If the last words of the President meant anything, they meant that he had not after all passed unsuspected.
fr: Si les paroles du President n'etaient pas denuees de sens, elles signifiaient que Syme etait, tout au moins, soupconne.

eng: They meant that while Sunday could not denounce him like Gogol, he still could not trust him like the others.
fr: Peut-etre Dimanche n'avait-il pas la certitude de pouvoir le demasquer, comme il avait fait de Gogol, mais il se mefiait !

eng: The other four got to their feet grumbling more or less, and betook themselves elsewhere to find lunch, for it was already well past midday.
fr: Les quatre autres finirent par s'en aller, a la recherche de leur lunch, car il etait plus de midi.

eng: The Professor went last, very slowly and painfully.
fr: Le professeur gagna la porte tres lentement, tres peniblement.

eng: Syme sat long after the rest had gone, revolving his strange position.
fr: Syme resta longtemps seul, a mediter sur son etrange situation.

eng: At last he rose and made his way out of the hotel into Leicester Square.
fr: Enfin, il sortit et gagna Leicester Square.

eng: The bright, cold day had grown increasingly colder, and when he came out into the street he was surprised by a few flakes of snow.
fr: La temperature s'etait refroidie. ~~~ Syme eprouva quelque ennui a voir tomber des flocons de neige.

eng: While he still carried the sword-stick and the rest of Gregory's portable luggage, he had thrown the cloak down and left it somewhere, perhaps on the steam-tug, perhaps on the balcony.
fr: Il avait toujours la canne a epee et le reste des bagages de Gregory, mais sa pelerine etait restee il ne savait ou, dans le bateau peut-etre, ou sur le balcon.

eng: Hoping, therefore, that the snow-shower might be slight, he stepped back out of the street for a moment and stood up under the doorway of a small and greasy hair-dresser's shop, the front window of which was empty, except for a sickly wax lady in evening dress.
fr: Esperant que la rafale ne durerait pas, il se refugia sous l'auvent d'une petite boutique de coiffeur, dont la vitrine ne contenait qu'une maladive figure de femme en cire, decolletee. ~~~ Pourtant, la neige tombait de plus en plus dense.

eng: Snow, however, began to thicken and fall fast; and Syme, having found one glance at the wax lady quite sufficient to depress his spirits, stared out instead into the white and empty street.
fr: Syme, agace par le sourire fade de la figurine, se retourna vers la rue et regarda les paves blanchir. ~~~ Il ne fut pas peu surpris de voir un homme arrete devant la vitrine et qui se tenait la, immobile, comme hypnotise par l'insupportable statuette.

eng: He was considerably astonished to see, standing quite still outside the shop and staring into the window, a man.
fr: Son chapeau etait blanc comme celui du pere Noel, et la neige s'epaississait autour de ses souliers.

eng: His top hat was loaded with snow like the hat of Father Christmas, the white drift was rising round his boots and ankles; but it seemed as if nothing could tear him away from the contemplation of the colourless wax doll in dirty evening dress.
fr: Mais il semblait que rien ne put l'arracher a la contemplation de cette poupee fanee. ~~~ Il etait assez etrange qu'un etre humain quelconque se tint par un pareil temps en observation devant une telle boutique.

eng: Syme was ready to believe anything about the perversions of this dehumanized brotherhood; but even he could not believe that the Professor had fallen in love with that particular wax lady.
fr: Syme etait pret a admettre n'importe quoi d'invraisemblable sur le compte de n'importe lequel des << deshumanises >> qui composaient le Conseil.

eng: He could only suppose that the man's malady (whatever it was) involved some momentary fits of rigidity or trance.
fr: Mais il ne pouvait croire que le vieux professeur fut amoureux de cette poupee de cire.

eng: He was not inclined, however, to feel in this case any very compassionate concern. ~~~ On the contrary, he rather congratulated himself that the Professor's stroke and his elaborate and limping walk would make it easy to escape from him and leave him miles behind.
fr: Il prefera s'expliquer le cas en supposant que le malade etait sujet a des acces de catalepsie, de rigidite subite, et meme il se felicita, n'etant nullement enclin a la pitie envers un tel individu, de pouvoir, par une fuite rapide, le distancer tout de suite.

eng: For Syme thirsted first and last to get clear of the whole poisonous atmosphere, if only for an hour.
fr: Car Syme avait besoin d'echapper, ne fut-ce que pour une heure, a l'atmosphere empoisonnee qu'il respirait depuis la veille.

eng: He had taken his seat in the upper room of the restaurant, which was full of the chink of knives and the chatter of foreigners.
fr: Il avait choisi sa place dans la salle du premier etage, ou retentissaient indiscontinument le cliquetis des couteaux et des fourchettes et le bruit des conversations, en langues etrangeres.

eng: He remembered that in old days he had imagined that all these harmless and kindly aliens were anarchists.
fr: Il se rappela que, jadis, il avait soupconne d'anarchisme ces braves et inoffensifs etrangers, et il frissonna en songeant a ce que c'etait qu'un veritable anarchiste.

eng: He shuddered, remembering the real thing. ~~~ But even the shudder had the delightful shame of escape.
fr: Mais, tout en frissonnant, il songea aussi qu'il avait fui, et il en eut une impression melee de quelque honte et de beaucoup de plaisir.

eng: The wine, the common food, the familiar place, the faces of natural and talkative men, made him almost feel as if the Council of the Seven Days had been a bad dream; and although he knew it was nevertheless an objective reality, it was at least a distant one.
fr: Le vin, la nourriture, qui n'avait rien d'extraordinaire, le caractere familier de l'endroit, les visages de ces hommes bavards et simples, tout le rassurait, et il etait tente de croire que le Conseil des Sept n'etait qu'un mauvais reve !

eng: Tall houses and populous streets lay between him and his last sight of the shameful seven; he was free in free London, and drinking wine among the free.
fr: Bien qu'il fut oblige de convenir en lui-meme que le terrible Conseil n'avait rien de chimerique, ce n'etait, du moins, pour l'instant, qu'une realite lointaine.

eng: With a somewhat easier action, he took his hat and stick and strolled down the stair into the shop below.
fr: De grandes maisons, des rues populeuses, le separaient des maudits Sept.

eng: When he entered that lower room he stood stricken and rooted to the spot.
fr: Il etait libre, dans une ville libre, et il buvait son vin parmi des hommes libres.
Avec un soupir de soulagement, il prit son chapeau et sa canne, et descendit dans la salle du rez-de-chaussee, qu'il devait traverser pour sortir.
En penetrant dans cette piece, il crut sentir que ses pieds prenaient racine dans le plancher.

eng: At a small table, close up to the blank window and the white street of snow, sat the old anarchist Professor over a glass of milk, with his lifted livid face and pendent eyelids.
fr: A une petite table, tout pres de la fenetre et de la rue blanche de neige, le vieux professeur anarchiste etait assis devant un verre de lait, avec ses paupieres mi-closes, et son visage livide.

eng: For an instant Syme stood as rigid as the stick he leant upon.
fr: Un instant, Syme resta droit, rigide comme la canne sur laquelle il s'appuyait.

eng: One comfort is, with a little brisk walking I can put a man like that as far away as Timbuctoo.
fr: Heureusement qu'en hatant un peu le pas, je puis sans peine mettre entre lui et moi la distance d'ici a Tombouctou... Du reste, ma supposition n'est pas raisonnable.

eng: Or am I too fanciful?
fr: Pourquoi me suivrait-il ?

eng: Was he really following me? ~~~ Surely Sunday would not be such a fool as to send a lame man?"
fr: Si Dimanche me faisait surveiller, il n'aurait pas charge de cette mission un paralytique.

eng: He set off at a smart pace, twisting and whirling his stick, in the direction of Covent Garden.
fr: D'un bon pas, tout en faisant tournoyer sa canne entre ses doigts, il prit la direction de Covent Garden.

eng: As he crossed the great market the snow increased, growing blinding and bewildering as the afternoon began to darken.
fr: Comme il traversait le Grand Marche, la rafale de neige se fit plus abondante.

eng: The snow-flakes tormented him like a swarm of silver bees.
fr: Elle devenait aveuglante a mesure que le jour baissait.

eng: Getting into his eyes and beard, they added their unremitting futility to his already irritated nerves; and by the time that he had come at a swinging pace to the beginning of Fleet Street, he lost patience, and finding a Sunday teashop, turned into it to take shelter.
fr: Les flocons le piquaient comme d'innombrables essaims d'abeilles argentees, penetrant dans ses yeux, dans sa barbe, surexcitant ses nerfs deja fort tendus. ~~~ A l'entree de Fleet Street, il perdit patience, et, se trouvant devant une maison de the ouverte le dimanche, il s'y refugia.

eng: He ordered another cup of black coffee as an excuse.
fr: Par contenance, il commanda une seconde tasse de cafe noir.

eng: Scarcely had he done so, when Professor de Worms hobbled heavily into the shop, sat down with difficulty and ordered a glass of milk.
fr: A peine l'avait-il commandee que le professeur de Worms, peniblement et en trebuchant, ouvrait la porte de la boutique et, s'asseyant avec difficulte, demandait une tasse de lait.

eng: Syme's walking-stick had fallen from his hand with a great clang, which confessed the concealed steel.
fr: La canne de Syme lui echappa des mains et fit en tombant un bruit metallique qui revela la presence de l'epee.

eng: But the Professor did not look round.
fr: Le professeur ne parut pas avoir entendu.

eng: Syme, who was commonly a cool character, was literally gaping as a rustic gapes at a conjuring trick.
fr: Syme qui etait un homme plutot calme le regardait, bouche bee, comme un paysan qui assiste a un tour de passe-passe.

eng: He had seen no cab following; he had heard no wheels outside the shop; to all mortal appearances the man had come on foot.
fr: Il n'avait remarque aucun cab derriere lui ; il n'en avait pas entendu s'arreter devant la boutique.

eng: But the old man could only walk like a snail, and Syme had walked like the wind.
fr: Selon toute apparence, le professeur etait venu a pied. ~~~ Mais quoi ?

eng: He started up and snatched his stick, half crazy with the contradiction in mere arithmetic, and swung out of the swinging doors, leaving his coffee untasted.
fr: Le vieillard n'allait guere plus vite qu'un escargot, et Syme avait file comme le vent ! ~~~ Affole par l'invraisemblance materielle du fait, il se leva, ramassa sa canne et s'esquiva, sans avoir touche a son cafe.

eng: An omnibus going to the Bank went rattling by with an unusual rapidity.
fr: Un omnibus se dirigeant vers la Banque passait a grande allure.

eng: He had a violent run of a hundred yards to reach it; but he managed to spring, swaying upon the splash-board and, pausing for an instant to pant, he climbed on to the top.
fr: Syme dut faire une centaine de pas en courant pour l'atteindre. ~~~ Il sauta sur le marchepied, respira un instant, puis monta a l'imperiale.

eng: When he had been seated for about half a minute, he heard behind him a sort of heavy and asthmatic breathing.
fr: Il y etait installe depuis une demi-minute, a peu pres, quand il entendit venir d'en bas un souffle d'asthmatique.

eng: Turning sharply, he saw rising gradually higher and higher up the omnibus steps a top hat soiled and dripping with snow, and under the shadow of its brim the short-sighted face and shaky shoulders of Professor de Worms.
fr: Se retournant aussitot, il vit s'elever graduellement sur les marches de l'omnibus un chapeau haut de forme, blanc de neige, puis le visage de myope, puis les epaules tremblantes du vieux professeur de Worms.

eng: He let himself into a seat with characteristic care, and wrapped himself up to the chin in the mackintosh rug.
fr: Il s'avanca a tout petits pas, se laissa tomber sur la banquette en poussant de legers soupirs et s'enveloppa lentement dans les plis de la bache de laine.

eng: He moved by inches, he let himself down with little gasps of caution. ~~~ And yet, unless the philosophical entities called time and space have no vestige even of a practical existence, it appeared quite unquestionable that he had run after the omnibus.
fr: Et pourtant, a moins d'admettre que les entites philosophiques appelees espace et temps fussent depourvues de toute realite, il etait infiniment probable que ce vieillard avait du courir apres l'omnibus.

eng: Syme sprang erect upon the rocking car, and after staring wildly at the wintry sky, that grew gloomier every moment, he ran down the steps.
fr: Syme se dressa de toute sa hauteur et, jetant un regard affole sur ce ciel d'hiver, qui d'instant en instant devenait plus sombre, se laissa glisser, plutot qu'il ne descendit, le long de l'escalier.

eng: He had repressed an elemental impulse to leap over the side.
fr: Il avait du reprimer un mouvement impulsif qu'il avait eu de se jeter en bas, du haut de l'imperiale.

eng: Too bewildered to look back or to reason, he rushed into one of the little courts at the side of Fleet Street as a rabbit rushes into a hole.
fr: Sans regarder en arriere, sans reflechir, il s'engagea a l'aveuglette, comme un lievre dans un trou, dans l'une des petites cours qui avoisinent Fleet Street.

eng: Somewhere behind Red Lion Court, however, he noticed a place where some energetic citizen had cleared away the snow for a space of about twenty yards, leaving the wet, glistening cobble-stones.
fr: Quelque part, toutefois, derriere Red Lion Court il avait remarque en passant qu'un citoyen energique avait balaye la neige sur l'espace d'une vingtaine de metres ; la le gravier apparaissait, humide et luisant.

eng: He thought little of this as he passed it, only plunging into yet another arm of the maze.
fr: Il n'en avait pas tenu grand compte d'abord.

eng: But when a few hundred yards farther on he stood still again to listen, his heart stood still also, for he heard from that space of rugged stones the clinking crutch and labouring feet of the infernal cripple.
fr: Et il allait reprendre sa course, quand son coeur cessa de battre : il entendait resonner, dans cet endroit deblaye, la bequille de l'infernal perclus.

eng: The sky above was loaded with the clouds of snow, leaving London in a darkness and oppression premature for that hour of the evening.
fr: Le ciel, couvert de nuages, versait sur Londres un crepuscule dense, insolite a cette heure peu avancee de l'apres-midi.

eng: On each side of Syme the walls of the alley were blind and featureless; there was no little window or any kind of eve.
fr: A la droite et a la gauche de Syme, les murs de l'allee etaient unis et sans caractere ; pas une fenetre, rien qui fit penser a un oeil.

eng: He felt a new impulse to break out of this hive of houses, and to get once more into the open and lamp-lit street.
fr: Il eprouva de nouveau le besoin de gagner les rues larges et eclairees, de sortir de ce dedale de maisons tristes.

eng: Yet he rambled and dodged for a long time before he struck the main thoroughfare.
fr: Mais il erra longtemps encore en tous sens avant de gagner la grande artere, et, quand il y parvint, il se trouva beaucoup plus loin qu'il n'aurait pense, dans la vaste solitude de Ludgate-Circus.

eng: When he did so, he struck it much farther up than he had fancied.
fr: Il apercut la cathedrale de Saint-Paul assise en plein ciel.

eng: He came out into what seemed the vast and void of Ludgate Circus, and saw St. Paul's Cathedral sitting in the sky.
fr: Il fut d'abord etonne de la solitude de ces grandes voies. ~~~ C'etait comme si la peste eut decime la population.

eng: At first he was startled to find these great roads so empty, as if a pestilence had swept through the city.
fr: Puis, il reflechit que la tempete de neige etait un danger.

eng: Then he told himself that some degree of emptiness was natural; first because the snow-storm was even dangerously deep, and secondly because it was Sunday.
fr: Enfin il se rappela que c'etait dimanche. ~~~ En prononcant tout bas ce mot, il se mordit la levre.

eng: And at the very word Sunday he bit his lip; the word was henceforth for hire like some indecent pun.
fr: Dimanche ! ~~~ Ces syllabes comportaient desormais pour lui un jeu de mots sacrilege.

eng: Under the white fog of snow high up in the heaven the whole atmosphere of the city was turned to a very queer kind of green twilight, as of men under the sea.
fr: Sous l'epais brouillard qui planait, la ville prenait une etrange couleur verdatre et comme sous-marine.

eng: The sealed and sullen sunset behind the dark dome of St. Paul's had in it smoky and sinister colours colours of sickly green, dead red or decaying bronze, that were just bright enough to emphasise the solid whiteness of the snow.
fr: Derriere Saint-Paul, le soleil, comme un disque de metal, avait des teintes fumeuses et sinistres, morbides, des teintes d'un rouge fletri, d'un bronze terni, qui faisaient ressortir la blancheur opaque de la neige.

eng: But right up against these dreary colours rose the black bulk of the cathedral; and upon the top of the cathedral was a random splash and great stain of snow, still clinging as to an Alpine peak.
fr: Sur ce fond morne, la masse noire de la cathedrale s'elevait, et a son sommet, on distinguait une grande tache de neige, comme sur un pic alpestre.

eng: When Syme saw it he suddenly straightened himself, and made with his sword-stick an involuntary salute.
fr: A cette vue, Syme se raidit involontairement, il fit de la canne-epee le salut militaire.

eng: He knew that that evil figure, his shadow, was creeping quickly or slowly behind him, and he did not care.
fr: Il savait que le hideux compere le suivait toujours comme son ombre ; mais il ne s'en souciait plus.

eng: It seemed a symbol of human faith and valour that while the skies were darkening that high place of the earth was bright.
fr: C'etait comme un symbole de la foi et de la vertu, ce haut lieu de la terre qui restait resplendissant dans les cieux assombris.

eng: Syme waited for him as St. George waited for the dragon, as a man waits for a final explanation or for death.
fr: Syme l'attendait comme saint Georges attendit le dragon, comme un homme qui va provoquer une explication finale, ou la mort.

eng: And the old Professor came right up to him and passed him like a total stranger, without even a blink of his mournful eyelids.
fr: Et le vieux professeur alla droit a Syme, et passa devant lui comme devant un inconnu, sans un regard de ses yeux eplores.

eng: There was something in this silent and unexpected innocence that left Syme in a final fury.
fr: Ce silence, cette sorte d'innocence jouee, exaspererent Syme.

Le vieillard semblait protester, tacitement, par son visage ferme, par ses manieres, en quelque sorte incolores, qu'il ne poursuivait personne et que toutes ces rencontres avaient ete de simples et insignifiantes coincidences.

eng: The man's colourless face and manner seemed to assert that the whole following had been an accident.
fr: Syme se sentit galvanise par une soudaine energie, nuancee de fureur et d'ironie.

eng: Syme was galvanised with an energy that was something between bitterness and a burst of boyish derision.
fr: Il fit un geste violent, qui faillit faire tomber le chapeau du professeur, cria quelque chose comme : << Attrape-moi si tu peux !

eng: He made a wild gesture as if to knock the old man's hat off, called out something like "Catch me if you can," and went racing away across the white, open Circus.
fr: >> et se mit a courir a travers le large et blanc Circus. ~~~ Impossible maintenant de se cacher.

eng: Concealment was impossible now; and looking back over his shoulder, he could see the black figure of the old gentleman coming after him with long, swinging strides like a man winning a mile race.
fr: En se retournant, il put voir le vieillard qui le poursuivait a grandes enjambees. ~~~ On eut dit deux hommes se defiant a la course.

eng: CHAPTER VIII. ~~~ THE PROFESSOR EXPLAINS When Gabriel Syme found himself finally established in a chair, and opposite to him, fixed and final also, the lifted eyebrows and leaden eyelids of the Professor, his fears fully returned.
fr: * * * CHAPITRE VIII EXPLICATIONS DU PROFESSEUR Quand il se trouva assis enfin et en face de lui les sourcils leves du professeur qui le regardait fixement sous ses paupieres plombees, Syme se sentit de nouveau pris de terreur.

eng: This incomprehensible man from the fierce council, after all, had certainly pursued him.
fr: Donc, et sans qu'aucun doute la-dessus fut possible, cet etre incomprehensible le poursuivait.

eng: If the man had one character as a paralytic and another character as a pursuer, the antithesis might make him more interesting, but scarcely more soothing.
fr: Qu'il eut le privilege de reunir en sa personne les deux caracteres du paralytique et du coureur, cela le rendait fort interessant, mais encore plus inquietant.

eng: It would be a very small comfort that he could not find the Professor out, if by some serious accident the Professor should find him out.
fr: La compensation serait mince, pour Syme, s'il parvenait a penetrer le mystere du professeur, pendant que, de son cote, le professeur lui arracherait son propre secret.

eng: He emptied a whole pewter pot of ale before the professor had touched his milk.
fr: Syme avait deja vide son pot de biere : le verre de lait du professeur etait encore intact.

eng: One possibility, however, kept him hopeful and yet helpless.
fr: Une seule explication rassurante, mais si peu probable !

Peut-etre le poursuivait-on sans l'epier, a proprement parler, sans le soupconner ; peut-etre y avait-il la une sorte de rite, comme un signe de l'entree en fonctions du nouveau conseiller ; peut-etre le nouveau Jeudi etait-il et devait-il etre ainsi poursuivi le long de Cheapside, ainsi que le nouveau lord-maire y est escorte.

eng: It was just possible that this escapade signified something other than even a slight suspicion of him.
fr: Et Syme cherchait comment il pourrait bien entamer la conversation avec le vieux professeur, quand celui-ci lui adressa la parole.

eng: Perhaps it was some regular form or sign. ~~~ Perhaps the foolish scamper was some sort of friendly signal that he ought to have understood.
fr: Sans le moindre preambule, avant que Syme eut formule la question diplomatique qu'il venait enfin de trouver : -- Etes-vous un policeman ?

eng: Perhaps it was a ritual.
fr: lui demanda le vieil anarchiste.

eng: Perhaps the new Thursday was always chased along Cheapside, as the new Lord Mayor is always escorted along it.
He was just selecting a tentative inquiry, when the old Professor opposite suddenly and simply cut him short.
Before Syme could ask the first diplomatic question, the old anarchist had asked suddenly, without any sort of preparation "Are you a policeman?"
fr: Si pret a tout que fut Syme, il ne pouvait s'attendre a une telle question, si directe, si brutale.

eng: Whatever else Syme had expected, he had never expected anything so brutal and actual as this. ~~~ Even his great presence of mind could only manage a reply with an air of rather blundering jocularity.
fr: Malgre toute sa presence d'esprit, il ne trouva sur le moment rien de mieux que de repeter, en eclatant de rire, d'un rire force : -- Un policeman !

eng: "A policeman?"
fr: Un policeman !

eng: he said, laughing vaguely.
fr: Et il continuait de rire.

eng: "Whatever made you think of a policeman in connection with me?"
fr: Puis il reprit : -- Qu'y a-t-il donc en moi qui vous fasse penser a un policeman ?

eng: "The process was simple enough," answered the Professor patiently.
fr: -- C'est tres simple, dit le professeur, avec insistance, vous avez l'air d'un policeman.

eng: "I thought you looked like a policeman.
fr: Je l'ai vu tout de suite et je le vois encore.

eng: I think so now." ~~~ "Did I take a policeman's hat by mistake out of the restaurant?"
fr: -- Aurais-je pris par erreur, en quittant le restaurant, le chapeau d'un policeman ?

eng: asked Syme, smiling wildly.
fr: Porte-je quelque part sur moi un numero ?

eng: "Have I by any chance got a number stuck on to me somewhere?
fr: Mes chaussures ont-elles cette physionomie vigilante qui caracterise celles de policiers ?

eng: Have my boots got that watchful look?
fr: Pourquoi serais-je un policeman ?

eng: Why must I be a policeman? ~~~ Do, do let me be a postman."
fr: Pourquoi ne serais-je pas plutot un facteur ?

eng: The old Professor shook his head with a gravity that gave no hope, but Syme ran on with a feverish irony.
fr: Le vieux professeur branlait la tete avec une gravite desesperante.

eng: "But perhaps I misunderstood the delicacies of your German philosophy.
fr: Syme reprit, sur un ton d'ironie febrile : -- Peut-etre certaines finesses de votre philosophie teutonique m'echappent-elles ?

eng: Perhaps policeman is a relative term.
fr: Peut-etre, dans votre esprit, << policeman >> est-il un terme tout relatif ?

eng: In an evolutionary sense, sir, the ape fades so gradually into the policeman, that I myself can never detect the shade.
fr: Du point de vue de l'evolution, monsieur, le singe se transforme en policeman par des degres si insensibles, que je n'aurai sans doute pas percu toutes ces delicates nuances.

eng: The monkey is only the policeman that may be.
fr: Le singe est le policeman qui sera peut-etre un jour.

eng: Perhaps a maiden lady on Clapham Common is only the policeman that might have been.
fr: La vieille fille de Clapham Common est peut-etre le policeman qu'elle aurait pu etre.

eng: I don't mind being anything in German thought." ~~~ "Are you in the police service?"
fr: Peu m'importe d'etre quoi que ce soit selon la philosophie allemande... -- Etes-vous au service de la police ?

eng: said the old man, ignoring all Syme's improvised and desperate raillery.
fr: interrogea froidement le vieillard, qui n'avait pas meme ecoute les plaisanteries improvisees et desesperees de Syme.

eng: "Are you a detective?"
fr: Etes-vous un detective ?

eng: Syme's heart turned to stone, but his face never changed.
fr: Le coeur de Syme cessa de battre, mais son visage ne changea pas d'expression.

eng: "Your suggestion is ridiculous," he began.
fr: -- Votre supposition est ridicule, dit-il, pourquoi, jamais ?...

eng: "Why on earth " The old man struck his palsied hand passionately on the rickety table, nearly breaking it.
fr: Le vieillard frappa de sa main paralysee la table bancale, qui chancela.

eng: "Did you hear me ask a plain question, you pattering spy?"
fr: -- Vous avez entendu ma question, espion trembleur !

eng: he shrieked in a high, crazy voice. ~~~ "Are you, or are you not, a police detective?"
fr: fit-il d'une voix rauque : etes-vous un detective, oui ou non ?

eng: "No!"
fr: -- Non !

eng: answered Syme, like a man standing on the hangman's drop.
fr: repondit Syme, avec l'accent d'un homme qui serait sur le point d'etre pendu.

eng: "You swear it," said the old man, leaning across to him, his dead face becoming as it were loathsomely alive.
fr: -- Vous le jurez ? ~~~ dit le vieillard en s'accoudant sur la table, et son regard prit soudain une intensite menacante.

eng: "You swear it!
fr: Vous le jurez ?

eng: You swear it!
fr: Syme se taisait.

eng: If you swear falsely, will you be damned?
fr: -- Le jurez-vous ? ~~~ repeta le professeur.

eng: Will you be sure that the devil dances at your funeral?
fr: Si vous vous parjurez, savez-vous que vous serez damne ?

eng: Will you see that the nightmare sits on your grave?
fr: Savez-vous que le diable dansera a votre enterrement ?
Savez-vous que le grand cauchemar vous attend deja au bord de votre tombe ?

eng: Will there really be no mistake?
fr: Pas d'erreur entre nous, n'est-ce pas !

eng: You are an anarchist, you are a dynamiter!
fr: Vous etes bien un anarchiste !

eng: Above all, you are not in any sense a detective?
fr: Vous etes bien un dynamiteur et non pas un detective !

eng: You are not in the British police?"
fr: Vous n'appartenez en aucune facon a la police britannique !

eng: He leant his angular elbow far across the table, and put up his large loose hand like a flap to his ear.
fr: Et il fit de sa main large ouverte un porte-voix a son oreille, comme pour ne rien perdre de la reponse attendue.

eng: "I am not in the British police," said Syme with insane calm.
fr: -- Je n'appartiens pas a la police britannique, articula Syme avec le calme de la folie.

eng: Professor de Worms fell back in his chair with a curious air of kindly collapse.
fr: Le professeur de Worms se laissa retomber sur sa chaise de l'air etrange d'un homme qui s'evanouit gentiment.

eng: Syme sprang up straight, sending back the bench behind him with a crash.
fr: Syme se dressa en faisant choir bruyamment son banc.

eng: "Because you are what?"
fr: -- Vous etes quoi ?

eng: he said thickly.
fr: murmura-t-il d'une voix tremblante.

eng: "You are what?"
fr: Qu'etes-vous ?

eng: "I am a policeman," said the Professor with his first broad smile, and beaming through his spectacles.
fr: -- Un policeman, dit le professeur, qui sourit pour la premiere fois, tandis que ses yeux rayonnaient derriere ses lunettes.

eng: "But as you think policeman only a relative term, of course I have nothing to do with you.
fr: Puisque vous estimez que le mot policeman n'a qu'un sens relatif, nous ne pouvons nous entendre.
Je suis de la police britannique et vous n'en etes pas.

eng: I am in the British police force; but as you tell me you are not in the British police force, I can only say that I met you in a dynamiters' club.
fr: Je n'ai donc qu'une chose a vous dire : je vous ai rencontre dans un club de dynamiteurs, et je pense que mon devoir est de vous arreter.

eng: I suppose I ought to arrest you."
fr: Et il deposa sur la table l'exact fac-simile de la carte bleue que Syme portait dans la poche de son gilet.

eng: And with these words he laid on the table before Syme an exact facsimile of the blue card which Syme had in his own waistcoat pocket, the symbol of his power from the police.
fr: Syme eut, un instant, l'impression que l'univers avait fait un demi-tour sur lui-meme, que les arbres poussaient vers le sol et qu'il avait les etoiles sous ses pieds.

eng: Syme had for a flash the sensation that the cosmos had turned exactly upside down, that all trees were growing downwards and that all stars were under his feet.
fr: Puis, peu a peu, il revint a la conviction contraire : pendant les dernieres vingt-quatre heures l'univers etait retourne sens dessus dessous, et c'etait maintenant, tout a coup, qu'il reprenait son equilibre.

eng: Then came slowly the opposite conviction.
fr: Ce diable qu'il avait fui des heures durant, voila que c'etait un frere aine !

eng: For the last twenty-four hours the cosmos had really been upside down, but now the capsized universe had come right side up again.
fr: Et il considerait avec stupeur ce bon diable qui, lui-meme, le considerait en riant.

eng: This devil from whom he had been fleeing all day was only an elder brother of his own house, who on the other side of the table lay back and laughed at him.
fr: Il ne fit aucune question. ~~~ Il ne s'enquit d'aucun detail.

eng: He did not for the moment ask any questions of detail; he only knew the happy and silly fact that this shadow, which had pursued him with an intolerable oppression of peril, was only the shadow of a friend trying to catch him up.
fr: Il se contenta du fait indeniable et heureux que cette ombre tant redoutee etait devenue bienfaisante.

eng: He knew simultaneously that he was a fool and a free man.
fr: Et il constata avec plaisir qu'il etait lui-meme un sot et un homme libre.

eng: There comes a certain point in such conditions when only three things are possible: first a perpetuation of Satanic pride, secondly tears, and third laughter.
fr: Dans ces crises, il vient un moment ou il faut choisir entre trois choses : ou bien on s'obstine dans un orgueil satanique, ou bien on pleure, ou bien on rit.

eng: Syme's egotism held hard to the first course for a few seconds, and then suddenly adopted the third.
fr: L'egotisme de Syme fit qu'il s'arreta d'abord au premier parti, puis, sans transition, il adopta le troisieme.

eng: Taking his own blue police ticket from his own waist coat pocket, he tossed it on to the table; then he flung his head back until his spike of yellow beard almost pointed at the ceiling, and shouted with a barbaric laughter.
fr: Tirant de la poche de son gilet sa propre carte bleue, il la jeta, lui aussi, sur la table, puis il leva la tete de telle facon que la pointe de sa barbe menacait le ciel, et il eclata de rire, d'un rire de barbare.

eng: Even in that close den, perpetually filled with the din of knives, plates, cans, clamorous voices, sudden struggles and stampedes, there was something Homeric in Syme's mirth which made many half-drunken men look round.
fr: Meme dans cette taverne peu sonore, ou l'on n'entendait guere que le bruit des couteaux, des assiettes, des pots et des voix avinees, le rire homerique de Syme retentit si fort que plusieurs individus ivres a moitie se retournerent.

eng: "What yer laughing at, guv'nor?"
fr: -- De quoi riez-vous, monsieur ?

eng: asked one wondering labourer from the docks.
fr: demanda un debardeur.

eng: "At myself," answered Syme, and went off again into the agony of his ecstatic reaction.
fr: -- De moi-meme, repondit Syme, et il s'abandonna de nouveau a son acces de folle hilarite.

eng: "Pull yourself together," said the Professor, "or you'll get hysterical.
fr: -- Revenez a vous, conseilla le professeur, vous allez avoir une crise de nerfs !

eng: Have some more beer.
fr: Demandez encore de la biere.

eng: I'll join you."
fr: Je vais en faire autant.

eng: "You haven't drunk your milk," said Syme.
fr: -- Vous n'avez pas bu votre lait, observa Syme.

eng: We're all Christians in this room, though perhaps," he added, glancing around at the reeling crowd, "not strict ones.
fr: Nous sommes entre chretiens, ici, quoique tous, continua-t-il en examinant la foule des consommateurs, ne soient pas de la plus stricte observance.

eng: Finish my milk?
fr: Boire ce lait !

eng: Great blazes!
fr: Dieu du ciel !

eng: yes, I'll finish it right enough!"
and he knocked the tumbler off the table, making a crash of glass and a splash of silver fluid.
fr: Attendez... Et il fit tomber le verre, qui se brisa bruyamment en repandant le liquide argente.

eng: Syme was staring at him with a happy curiosity.
fr: Syme le contemplait avec sympathie.

eng: "I understand now," he cried; "of course, you're not an old man at all."
fr: -- Je comprends maintenant ! ~~~ s'ecria-t-il.

eng: "I can't take my face off here," replied Professor de Worms.
fr: Naturellement, vous n'etes pas du tout un vieillard.

eng: "It's rather an elaborate make-up. ~~~ As to whether I'm an old man, that's not for me to say. ~~~ I was thirty-eight last birthday."
fr: -- Je ne puis oter ma << figure >> ici, repliqua le professeur : c'est une machine plutot compliquee.

eng: "Yes, but I mean," said Syme impatiently, "there's nothing the matter with you."
fr: Quant a savoir si je suis un vieillard, ce n'est pas a moi d'en juger.

eng: "Yes," answered the other dispassionately.
fr: Lors de mon dernier anniversaire, j'avais trente-huit ans.

eng: "I am subject to colds."
fr: -- Et vous n'etes pas malade non plus.

eng: Syme's laughter at all this had about it a wild weakness of relief.
fr: -- Si, repondit l'autre, flegmatiquement, je suis sujet aux rhumes.

eng: He laughed at the idea of the paralytic Professor being really a young actor dressed up as if for the foot-lights.
fr: Syme rit encore. ~~~ Il s'egayait a penser que le vieux professeur etait, en realite, un jeune comedien, grime comme au moment de paraitre sur la scene.

eng: No, I didn't know it," answered Syme in some surprise.
fr: Non, je ne savais pas, repondit Syme avec surprise.

eng: "But didn't you?"
fr: Mais, vous, l'ignoriez-vous donc ?

eng: "I knew no more than the dead," replied the man who called himself de Worms.
fr: -- Je n'en savais pas plus la-dessus que les morts du cimetiere.

eng: "I thought the President was talking about me, and I rattled in my boots."
fr: Je croyais que le President voulait parler de moi, et je tremblais dans mes bottes.

eng: "And I thought he was talking about me," said Syme, with his rather reckless laughter.
fr: -- Et moi de meme ! ~~~ Je croyais qu'il parlait de moi !

eng: "I had my hand on my revolver all the time."
fr: Tout le temps, j'avais la main sur mon revolver.

eng: "So had I," said the Professor grimly; "so had Gogol evidently."
fr: -- C'est ce que je faisais aussi, dit le professeur, et c'est evidemment ce que faisait aussi Gogol.

eng: Syme struck the table with an exclamation.
fr: Syme frappa du poing la table : -- Trois !

eng: "Why, there were three of us there!"
fr: s'ecria-t-il, nous etions trois !

eng: he cried.
"Three out of seven is a fighting number.
fr: Trois contre quatre, on peut se battre !

eng: If we had only known that we were three!"
fr: Si nous avions su que nous etions trois !
La figure du professeur s'assombrit ; il baissa les yeux.

eng: The face of Professor de Worms darkened, and he did not look up.
fr: -- Eussions-nous ete trois cents, dit-il, nous ne pouvions rien.

eng: "We were three," he said.
fr: -- Comment ?

eng: "If we had been three hundred we could still have done nothing."
fr: fit Syme interloque, a trois cents contre quatre.

eng: "Not if we were three hundred against four?"
fr: -- Non, repondit le professeur, trois cents hommes ne pourraient venir a bout de Dimanche.

eng: asked Syme, jeering rather boisterously.
fr: A ce seul nom, Syme redevint subitement grave.

eng: "No," said the Professor with sobriety, "not if we were three hundred against Sunday."
fr: Le rire etait mort dans son coeur avant d'expirer sur ses levres.

eng: And the mere name struck Syme cold and serious; his laughter had died in his heart before it could die on his lips.
fr: Les traits de l'inoubliable President se presenterent a son imagination avec toute la nettete d'une photographie en couleurs.

eng: The face of the unforgettable President sprang into his mind as startling as a coloured photograph, and he remarked this difference between Sunday and all his satellites, that their faces, however fierce or sinister, became gradually blurred by memory like other human faces, whereas Sunday's seemed almost to grow more actual during absence, as if a man's painted portrait should slowly come alive.
fr: Et il remarqua cette difference entre Dimanche et ses satellites, que leurs visages, si feroces qu'ils fussent, s'etaient peu a peu estompes deja dans sa memoire, tandis que celui de Dimanche y restait present avec l'inalterable energie de la realite.

eng: They were both silent for a measure of moments, and then Syme's speech came with a rush, like the sudden foaming of champagne.
fr: Bien plus, l'absence semblait le rendre plus energique et vivant encore.

eng: "Professor," he cried, "it is intolerable.
fr: C'etait comme un portrait qui s'eveillerait a la vie.

eng: Are you afraid of this man?"
fr: Ils resterent silencieux pendant quelques instants.

eng: The Professor lifted his heavy lids, and gazed at Syme with large, wide-open, blue eyes of an almost ethereal honesty.
fr: Puis Syme parla, et ce fut comme la mousse qui s'echappe d'une bouteille de champagne.

eng: "Yes, I am," he said mildly.
fr: -- Professeur !

eng: "So are you."
fr: s'ecria-t-il, cela n'est pas tolerable !

eng: Syme was dumb for an instant.
fr: Auriez-vous peur de cet homme ?

eng: Then he rose to his feet erect, like an insulted man, and thrust the chair away from him.
fr: Le professeur leva ses lourdes paupieres et appuya sur Syme le regard de ses yeux bleus, grands ouverts, ou se lisait une franchise etheree.

eng: "Yes," he said in a voice indescribable, "you are right.
fr: -- Oui, dit-il doucement, et vous aussi.

eng: I am afraid of him.
fr: Syme, d'abord, resta muet.
Mais, se dressant soudain de toute sa hauteur, comme un homme insulte, il repoussa violemment sa chaise : -- Vous avez raison, commenca-t-il d'une voix que rien ne peut rendre, j'ai peur de lui.

eng: Therefore I swear by God that I will seek out this man whom I fear until I find him, and strike him on the mouth.
fr: C'est pourquoi je jure devant Dieu que je chercherai cet homme et que je le frapperai sur la bouche.

eng: If heaven were his throne and the earth his footstool, I swear that I would pull him down."
fr: Quand le ciel serait son trone et la terre son tabouret, je jure que je l'en arracherai.

eng: "How?"
fr: -- Comment ?

eng: asked the staring Professor. ~~~ "Why?"
fr: demanda le professeur, et pourquoi ?

eng: "Because I am afraid of him," said Syme; "and no man should leave in the universe anything of which he is afraid."
fr: -- Precisement parce que j'ai peur de lui. ~~~ On ne doit pas laisser vivre un etre dont on a peur.

eng: De Worms blinked at him with a sort of blind wonder.
fr: Le professeur de Worms lorgna Syme et fit un effort pour parler.

eng: He made an effort to speak, but Syme went on in a low voice, but with an undercurrent of inhuman exaltation "Who would condescend to strike down the mere things that he does not fear?
fr: Mais Syme reprit aussitot, a voix basse mais avec une exaltation continue : -- Qui donc condescendrait a frapper seulement les etres dont il n'a pas peur ?

eng: Who would debase himself to be merely brave, like any common prizefighter?
fr: Qui donc voudrait etre brave a la facon d'un lutteur forain !

eng: Who would stoop to be fearless like a tree?
fr: Qui donc voudrait ignorer la peur, comme un arbre ?

eng: Fight the thing that you fear.
fr: Il faut lutter contre ceux que l'on craint.

eng: So I say to you, strike upwards, if you strike at the stars."
fr: >> L'avis est bon, en effet : frappez de bas en haut, si vous voulez atteindre les etoiles !

eng: The other looked at the ceiling, one of the tricks of his pose.
fr: -- Dimanche est une etoile fixe, dit le professeur, le regard au plafond.

eng: "Sunday is a fixed star," he said.
fr: -- Vous verrez que ce sera une etoile filante et tombee, conclut Syme en prenant son chapeau.

eng: "You shall see him a falling star," said Syme, and put on his hat.
fr: La decision de ce geste determina le professeur a se lever.

eng: The decision of his gesture drew the Professor vaguely to his feet.
fr: -- Avez-vous une idee ? ~~~ demanda-t-il avec bienveillance.

eng: "Have you any idea," he asked, with a sort of benevolent bewilderment, "exactly where you are going?"
fr: Savez-vous exactement ou vous allez ?

eng: "Yes," replied Syme shortly, "I am going to prevent this bomb being thrown in Paris."
fr: -- Oui, repondit Syme tres vite.

eng: "Have you any conception how?"
fr: Je vais les empecher de jeter leur bombe a Paris !

eng: inquired the other.
fr: -- Vous avez un moyen ?

eng: "No," said Syme with equal decision.
fr: -- Non. ~~~ Syme ne voyait aucun moyen ; il n'en etait pas moins tres decide.

eng: "You remember, of course," resumed the soi-disant de Worms, pulling his beard and looking out of the window, "that when we broke up rather hurriedly the whole arrangements for the atrocity were left in the private hands of the Marquis and Dr. Bull.
fr: -- Vous vous rappelez, reprit le professeur en se tirant la barbe et en regardant par la fenetre d'un air desinteresse, qu'un peu avant de lever si precipitamment la seance, Dimanche avait confie tous les preparatifs de l'attentat au docteur Bull et au marquis.

eng: The Marquis is by this time probably crossing the Channel.
fr: En ce moment, le marquis, probablement, est en train de passer le detroit.

eng: But where he will go and what he will do it is doubtful whether even the President knows; certainly we don't know.
fr: Mais, que fera-t-il et ou ira-t-il ? ~~~ On peut douter que Dimanche lui-meme le sache.

eng: The only man who does know is Dr.
fr: Ce qui est sur, c'est que nous l'ignorons.

eng: Bull." ~~~ "Confound it!"
fr: Le seul homme qui soit au courant de l'affaire, c'est le docteur Bull.

eng: cried Syme.
fr: -- Malheur !

eng: "And we don't know where he is."
fr: Et nous ne savons ou le prendre ?

eng: "Yes," said the other in his curious, absent-minded way, "I know where he is myself."
fr: -- Si, dit l'autre, de sa maniere etrange et distraite ; pour moi, je sais ou le prendre.

eng: "Will you tell me?"
fr: -- Me le direz-vous ?

eng: asked Syme with eager eyes.
"I will take you there," said the Professor, and took down his own hat from a peg.
fr: -- Je vous y menerai, dit le professeur en decrochant son chapeau de la patere.

eng: "What do you mean?"
fr: -- Que voulez-vous dire ?

eng: he asked sharply.
fr: M'accompagnerez-vous ?

eng: "Will you join me? ~~~ Will you take the risk?"
fr: Partagerez-vous les risques avec moi ?

eng: "Young man," said the Professor pleasantly, "I am amused to observe that you think I am a coward.
fr: -- Jeune homme, repondit le professeur avec gaite, je vois que vous me prenez pour un lache, et cela m'amuse.

eng: As to that I will say only one word, and that shall be entirely in the manner of your own philosophical rhetoric.
fr: Je ne vous dirai qu'un mot, un mot tout a fait dans le gout de votre rhetorique philosophique : vous croyez qu'il est possible d'abattre le President ; je sais que c'est impossible, et je vais essayer de le faire. ~~~ Il ouvrit la porte de la taverne.

eng: You think that it is possible to pull down the President.
fr: Une bouffee d'air marin penetra dans la salle.

eng: I know that it is impossible, and I am going to try it," and opening the tavern door, which let in a blast of bitter air, they went out together into the dark streets by the docks.
fr: Les deux detectives prirent l'une des rues sombres qui avoisinent les docks.

eng: Most of the snow was melted or trampled to mud, but here and there a clot of it still showed grey rather than white in the gloom.
fr: La neige fondue s'etait changee en boue. ~~~ Par places, dans le crepuscule, par petits tas, elle faisait des taches grises plutot que blanches.

eng: Syme felt almost dazed as he stepped through this growing confusion of lights and shadows; but his companion walked on with a certain briskness, towards where, at the end of the street, an inch or two of the lamplit river looked like a bar of flame.
fr: Syme eprouva une sorte d'etourdissement en penetrant dans cette confusion de lumieres et d'arbres. ~~~ Mais son compagnon se dirigeait, d'un pas assez rapide, vers l'extremite de la rue, ou le fleuve, illumine par les lampes, faisait comme une boue de flamme.

eng: "Where are you going?"
fr: -- Ou allons-nous ?

eng: Syme inquired.
fr: demanda Syme.

eng: "Just now," answered the Professor, "I am going just round the corner to see whether Dr. Bull has gone to bed.
fr: -- Nous allons tourner le coin et voir si le docteur Bull est deja couche. ~~~ Il se couche tot.

eng: He is hygienic, and retires early."
fr: Il a un grand respect pour les lois de l'hygiene.

eng: "Dr. ~~~ Bull!"
fr: -- Le docteur habite ici ?

eng: exclaimed Syme.
fr: -- Non.

eng: "Does he live round the corner?"
fr: Il habite assez loin, de l'autre cote du fleuve.

eng: "No," answered his friend.
fr: Mais, d'ici, nous pourrons voir s'il est couche.

eng: "As a matter of fact he lives some way off, on the other side of the river, but we can tell from here whether he has gone to bed."
fr: Tout en parlant, ils atteignirent l'endroit que designait le professeur.

eng: Turning the corner as he spoke, and facing the dim river, flecked with flame, he pointed with his stick to the other bank.
fr: Celui-ci, de sa canne, montra, par-dela la nappe tachee de lumiere, la rive opposee.

eng: On the Surrey side at this point there ran out into the Thames, seeming almost to overhang it, a bulk and cluster of those tall tenements, dotted with lighted windows, and rising like factory chimneys to an almost insane height.
fr: C'etait cette masse de hautes maisons, pointillees de fenetres eclairees, qu'on voit, du cote de Surrey, s'elever, comme des cheminees d'usine, a des hauteurs insensees.

eng: Their special poise and position made one block of buildings especially look like a Tower of Babel with a hundred eyes.
fr: En particulier, un corps de batiment semblait une Tour de Babel aux cent yeux.

eng: Syme had never seen any of the sky-scraping buildings in America, so he could only think of the buildings in a dream.
fr: Syme n'avait jamais vu les skyscrapers americains ; aussi ne songea-t-il, devant ce gigantesque batiment, qu'aux tours dont il avait reve.

eng: Even as he stared, the highest light in this innumerably lighted turret abruptly went out, as if this black Argus had winked at him with one of his innumerable eyes.
fr: Juste en cet instant, la lumiere la plus haute de cette tour aux innombrables yeux s'eteignit brusquement, comme si ce noir Argus avait cligne de l'une de ses paupieres.

eng: Come along and get some dinner.
fr: Venez, allons souper.

eng: We must call on him tomorrow morning."
fr: Nous irons le voir demain matin.

eng: Without further parley, he led the way through several by-ways until they came out into the flare and clamour of the East India Dock Road.
fr: Ils suivirent plusieurs ruelles et gagnerent les lumieres et le bruit d'East India Dock Road.

eng: The Professor, who seemed to know his way about the neighbourhood, proceeded to a place where the line of lighted shops fell back into a sort of abrupt twilight and quiet, in which an old white inn, all out of repair, stood back some twenty feet from the road.
fr: Le professeur, qui paraissait bien connaitre ces parages, se dirigea vers un endroit ou la ligne illuminee des boutiques etait subitement brisee par un bloc d'ombre et de silence. ~~~ Un vieil hotel recrepi, mais delabre, occupait ce retrait, a vingt pas de la rue.

eng: "You can find good English inns left by accident everywhere, like fossils," explained the Professor.
fr: -- On trouve un peu partout, expliqua le professeur de Worms, de bons vieux hotels anglais abandonnes comme des fossiles.

eng: "I once found a decent place in the West End."
fr: Il m'est arrive de decouvrir un hotel tres convenable dans le West End.

eng: "I suppose," said Syme, smiling, "that this is the corresponding decent place in the East End?"
fr: -- Je pense, dit Syme en souriant, que voici le pendant de celui-ci dans l'East End.

eng: "It is," said the Professor reverently, and went in.
fr: -- Vous avez devine, repondit poliment le professeur en entrant.

eng: In that place they dined and slept, both very thoroughly.
fr: Ils dinerent, puis dormirent, et s'acquitterent tres consciencieusement de ces deux fonctions.

eng: The beans and bacon, which these unaccountable people cooked well, the astonishing emergence of Burgundy from their cellars, crowned Syme's sense of a new comradeship and comfort.
fr: Des haricots et du lard appretes a merveille, un excellent bourgogne qui s'etonnait de sortir de pareilles caves, acheverent de donner a Syme la confortable assurance qu'il possedait un nouvel ami.

eng: Through all this ordeal his root horror had been isolation, and there are no words to express the abyss between isolation and having one ally.
fr: Tout au long de cette epreuve, sa crainte la plus vive avait ete de rester isole. ~~~ Aucun mot ne saurait exprimer la difference qu'il y a entre l'alliance de deux hommes et l'isolement de chacun d'eux.

eng: It may be conceded to the mathematicians that four is twice two.
fr: On peut conceder aux mathematiciens que deux et deux font quatre.

eng: But two is not twice one; two is two thousand times one.
fr: Mais, deux, ce n'est pas l'addition de un et un : deux, c'est deux mille fois un !

eng: That is why, in spite of a hundred disadvantages, the world will always return to monogamy.
fr: C'est pourquoi l'humanite restera toujours fidele a la monogamie, malgre tous les inconvenients qu'elle comporte.

eng: Syme was able to pour out for the first time the whole of his outrageous tale, from the time when Gregory had taken him to the little tavern by the river.
